Executive Summary: We managed to get our new packaging tool LAMP into production at the very end of February after considerable UAT.  New markets have been added to FactGenie, including Japanese just in time for a huge client event in Tokyo so we were able to present it to the market to great acclaim. Several customers are asking if they can buy our tools direct!
Key Risks and Issues:
We have had good success integrating AI into people's workflows but there are now some new UI requirements to make AI work properly in the flow of people's work so we are needing to think about much more product development than product integration. That bangs up against resource constraints.
There are more needs than we can currently service so we need better training on Open Arena and other tools so that more of our journalists can build their own AI tools to use in their daily work.
Progress on Use Case this period:
FactGenie - expanded to include Hong Kong, New Zealand and Malaysia. The feeds will be switched on to users once the FY reporting season is finished. Completed bug fixes for the TSE Japan feed. Leveraging Sonnet 3.5 for enhanced processing of other Japanese releases (JSE and CIS). Working on adding web sources to the top of the funnel. GREEN
LEON - Launched working prototype of Error Catcher editing tool in LEON and gathered requirements for semi-automated drafting.  GREEN
Packaging - launched the first version of our AI packaging tool on March 1 with three packages in scope! Feb was mostly QA, improvements to UI and writing user guide. Lauched live transcription which was a key user ask! - GREEN
VESPA - Second version of shotlists with more video analysis done but still unsure it will meet needs in current form (RED). Synthetic voices was due to launch in early March but have been held up by TR Procurement (AMBER)

This will answer some of the requirements from our previous polling about helping people to solve their specific problems and empowering people to use AI for themselves rather than it happening to them.
Path Forward:
FactGenie - test new relevance model in training environment to ensure it classifies alerts correctly without removing important ones. (This is to reduce the noise and focus only on the most important alerts, a key step on the way to automation)
LEON - build drafting prototype. Create new UI for editing tool (highlighting where the error is). Reworking UI for translation to ensure highlighting of changes (focusing on French first to roll out in sequence). Aiming to test mid-March. Also looking at being able to share these functionalities with our video editing tool VESPA. 
Packaging - Expand number of packages and teams working through LAMP to about 20 in the next month
VESPA - Rethinking the need as it may be better to start afresh and use AI to modernise all our workflow and output rather than shoehorn it in to existing work.

In 2025 The CXDT AI portfolio of initiatives continues to center on 3 main pillars:
1.  Customer Self Service - a suite of initiatives to incorporate AI into our customers self-help experience with the goal of getting them the answers they need quickly and accurately without the need to contact an agent
2.  Agent Support - a suite of initiatives to enhance agent productivity through AI by handling routine tasks, providing personalized knowledge recommendations and answers, with the goal to improve customer service outcomes and overall productivity
3.  Employee Support - a suite of initiatives leveraging AI to support productivity improvements across other groups within CXDT.  There are multiple initiatives under each pillar and in total will achieve the cost savings target set for CXDT in 2025.  
Key updates since the last report include: the deployment of the Intelligent Assistant to support agents during the Spring Tax Peak, resulting in a 14% reduction in average handle time despite increased call volumes. Improved training modules and integrated support content have boosted performance, with plans to train new agents post-spring peak and introduce language localization. The completion of the AEM to Salesforce connection hotfix and ongoing efforts to enhance content categorization and knowledge search are also noted. Teams are preparing for the rollout of Salesforce Einstein GPT and AI knowledge for Legal CTS and CS Canada agents ahead of the fall peak. The Service Cloud Voice deployment for Reference Attorneys and Customer Service has been slightly delayed to April 25th due to dependencies, with plans for further development and training. The WhatsApp-based AI self-service tool for the LatAm region shows steady call deflection and positive customer engagement trends. The WhatsApp India Project aims to improve customer satisfaction through AI-driven support, with a target go-live date of May 5, 2025. Other initiatives include the transition to Adobe's cloud solution, automation of payment applications, and the use of AI to predict customer queries. The March report also addresses key risks and issues impacting AI knowledge tools and outlines mitigation strategies. Finally, the path forward includes continued development and deployment of planned AI initiatives, communication and governance efforts, and acceleration opportunities to enhance AI integration across the organization.
Key Risks and Issues:
Effectiveness of our AI knowledge tools is being impacted by several issues.
Issue:  Help and Support content was written for web presentation to customers and is not categorized in a way that Salesforce understands, leading to inefficiencies in search and in some cases resulting in incorrect articles being returned by Einstein
Mitigation: Implement a robust categorization system that aligns with Salesforce's requirements. Enhance search functionalities by making filters sticky and improving the initial global search results. Regularly review and update the categorization to ensure it remains effective

Issue:  Intelligent Assistant and Salesforce Einstein are exclusively limited to knowledge articles and do not utilize other data sources in their AI grounding.  This restricts the range of accessible information as 1) migration of knowledge articles to AEM Guides is not yet complete, resulting in gaps within the knowledge base and 2) doesn’t leverage other possible sources like Salesforce and Flash cases and Flash cases
Mitigation: Complete the migration process by reviewing, categorizing, and publishing all articles in AEM Guides. Explore configurations to enable Salesforce Einstein and Intelligent Assistant to access other data sources like Salesforce cases and Flash cases, thereby enhancing the knowledge base
Progress on Use Case this period:
•	The Intelligent Assistant was deployed to Accounting CS, Practice CS, and UltraTax CS agentsi January to support them through Sprin Tax Peak. Usage has been around 20% from December to February. In February, it reduced average handle time (AHT) by 14%, despite a 15% increase in call volume. Improved training modules and integrated support content have boosted performance. Efforts continue to expand usage and enhance capabilities.  Plans include training new agents post-spring peak, adding new content for content the Web Services and Fixed Asset products and internal content in April, and introducing language localization. Additional for Roll out is planned for 36 additional agents supporting Cloud Audit Suite in June. 
•	The AEM to Salesforce connection hotfix is complete and signed off. Content is being pushed from AEM to Salesforce and monitored. Efforts continue to clean up article duplication, apply content categorization tagging, and improve knowledge search before further roll-outs. Teams are preparing for the rollout of Salesforce Einstein GPT and AI knowledge for Legal CTS and CS Canada agents ahead of the fall peak. The focus is on building a robust knowledge base, aiming for full content population by July 1 to allow time for rollout and training before peak season.
•	The Service Cloud Voice deployment for Reference Attorneys and Customer Service has been slightly delayed to April 25th due to dependencies on fixes by Genesys and Salesforce Development teams and to allow sufficient time for agent training and change management. Teams continue to process on related development including Einstein Next Best Action, targeted for the same April release.  The Q2 Service Cloud Voice deployment for Product Support teams remains on track, and a kick-off with Product Support leadership will occur in the next few weeks.
•	In February, the call deflection for the WhatsApp-based AI self-service tool for the LatAm region was 33%, remaining steady month over month, with 50% of requests resolved without human interaction. Early abandoned contact was 16%, a decrease of 1 percentage point month over month, indicating a positive trend in customer engagement. The usage of the Product Support Assistant embedded within the product increased by 85% month over month for TaxOne and 833% for LegalOne. Customer engagement is indicated by 32% of distinct users opening cases.
•	The WhatsApp India Project aims to provide extended support for India-based Global 7 and other Extended support subscribers in India for ONESOURCE Income Tax and GoSystem beyond U.S. hours. Customer support volumes have increased by approximately 33% for calls (23%) and chats (61%) for ONESOURCE Income Tax and GoSystem customers, with 70% of customers using mobile devices. The WhatsApp India Project intends to deflect 10% of current call volumes and improve customer satisfaction through reduced wait times by implementing AI-driven WhatsApp support as an additional touch point for customers, leveraging the platform's widespread popularity in India. The target date for going live is May 5, 2025.
•	The Help and Support content team is working to plan and schedule the transition to Adobe's cloud solution (AEM Cloud). This multi-tenant transition must be managed to ensure smooth migration. The team is evaluating an AI solution to identify relevant knowledge base articles for updates and the AI tools that Adobe will provide after migration. These tools are part of our agreement with Adobe. Initial analysis indicates that Adobe's functionality will suffice and offer AI tools for faster authoring and publishing.   
•	Two high- impact initiatives are underway in C2C.  The UI/Suspense Payment Application initiative is designed to automate the matching of payments to customer accounts through the utilization of AI and bots. Previously a manual process, it now employs AI and bots to identify accounts with unapplied and suspense payments, after which the Cash Applications team reallocates the balance to the appropriate customer account. This process is currently overseen by the Automation Center of Excellence team to ensure stability, with plans for the business to trigger the automation as needed in the future. The application has been deployed in the US Legal and LatAm regions, while development and testing are ongoing for the ANZ, UK, and Ireland regions, with an expected deployment in Q2. This initiative aims to reduce UI/Suspense cases by 50% by improving speed, accuracy, and reducing human error.  The C2C Customer Queries initiative focuses on analyzing and predicting customer inquiries using LLM. Currently in the "Test and Learn" phase, the project employs the AI CARF model to enhance C2C customer support, managing approximately 20,000 queries monthly. This tool assists in identifying root issues and providing insights into customer behavior. It is expected to reduce resolution time from 5 days to 2 in 75% of cases, thereby decreasing dissatisfaction and churn rates for recurring queries. Future steps will involve developing workflows and resolving stability issues on the new platform.
Details on Change Management:
CXD has adopted the TR Enterprise AI OKR for 2025 and will ensure 50% of CXD employees are using Gen AI tools regularly as part of their daily task.  In February 40.6% of CXD employees used Ai tools regularly (+ 2.8 pp m/m increase).  We expect this number to continue to rise naturally as we deploy additional AI tools across our CSS agent population the year and use our AI communication channels to promote AI learning opportunities and innovative ways our colleagues are using AI in their day to day work.

To support the 2025 TR AI goal and address feedback from 2024, the CXD AI lead and HRBP are developing a department AI communications plan. This includes AI Champions and persona-based AI learning recommendations for 2025. The CXD AI Atrium page and the first monthly newsletter (AI Spark: AI Innovation in CXD) will be launched in mid-April and will be supported by an intake process for success stories across the group. The group has also adopted an AI co-worker avatar to include in communications about AI tools to support agents. This avatar communicates that the intent of the AI deployments is to support agents.

A working group has been formed to deploy the Idea Space tool as a way to capture and govern AI ideas across CSD.  The team held a kick-off and are in the process of documenting configuration and governance requirements. It is expected the tool will roll out across CXD in April.

Demand for MSFT  365 Copilot licenses remains high as groups find Copilot has proven to be an invaluable tool in streamlining our daily operations.  The approximate number of licenses held by CXD will be expanded to ~220 in Q2. Expansion of license availability is largely targeted at C2C leaders.
Path Forward:
Continued Development and Deployment of planned AI Initiatives
•	Intelligent Assistant: Continue expanding usage and enhancing capabilities, train new agents post-spring peak, add new content for Web Services and Fixed Asset products in April, and introduce language localization. Roll out to 36 additional agents for Cloud Audit Suite in June.
•	Salesforce Einstein GPT and AI knowledge: Clean up article duplication, apply content categorization tagging, improve knowledge search before further roll-outs, and prepare for the rollout of Salesforce Einstein GPT and AI knowledge for Legal CTS and CS Canada agents ahead of the fall peak, aiming for full content population by July 1.
•	Service Cloud Voice Deployment: Deploy for Reference Attorneys and Customer Service on April 25th, ensuring sufficient agent training and change management. Continue development for Einstein Next Best Action targeted for the same April release. Q2 deployment for Product Support teams remains on track.
•	WhatsApp-based AI Self-service Tool (LatAm Region): Maintain steady call deflection and resolution rates, with continued positive customer engagement trends.
•	WhatsApp India Project: Implement AI-driven WhatsApp support to deflect 10% of current call volumes and improve customer satisfaction, aiming to go live on May 5, 2025.
•	Help and Support Content Team: Plan and schedule the transition to Adobe's cloud solution (AEM Cloud), evaluate AI tools provided by Adobe to ensure smooth migration and faster authoring and publishing.
•	UI/Suspense Payment Application: Oversee the automation process by the Automation Center of Excellence team, deploy in ANZ, UK, and Ireland regions by Q2, aiming to reduce UI/Suspense cases by 50% through improved speed, accuracy, and reduced human error.
•	C2C Customer Queries: Continue "Test and Learn" phase with AI CARF model, aim to reduce resolution time from 5 days to 2 in 75% of cases, and develop workflows to resolve stability issues on the new platform.
Communication/Governance:
•	Deploy AI Spark:  AI Innovation in CXD newsletter and new CXD AI Atrium page to the CXD org by April 15th.    These communication vehicles will highlight success stories and measurable impacts across CXDT through multiple channels to inspire continued innovation and AI adoption.
•	Analyze and improve savings projections by comparing estimates and actuals to refine our future estimating.  Ongoing
Acceleration Opportunities:
•	Implement AIvolution tool (IdeaSpace Hub) to capture and prioritize AI innovation ideas from across CXD by April 30th.
•	Leadership discussions to explore additional ideas for AI/automation deployments and acceleration opportunities.  April 2025
•	Craft EPC 2026 aims to speed up the integration of AI across CXD by enabling strong self-service options for customers and deploying AI to handle routine customer support queries. This approach seeks to enhance the added value provided by agents through personalized service on more complex customer queries.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
As we move into 2025, our corporate AI strategy remains focused on leveraging internal and third-party tools to drive productivity gains, operational efficiencies, and enhanced customer satisfaction, ultimately improving Net Revenue Retention. Our key objectives are to maximize the potential of our existing tools, particularly Salesforce and Gainsight, and identify areas where additional solutions can further support our goals.

Current Progress and Initiatives:
We are optimizing the use of tools like MS Copilot, with expanded access across the organization, to enhance productivity and efficiency.
Our Professional Services team is actively working on two projects aimed at driving productivity gains, with an additional nine projects in the scoping phase for future development.

Gong: A pilot of Gong was conducted in Q4-2024, with 20 out of 40 participants actively engaging. As of February 27, 2025, Corporates is moving forward with 633 Gong licenses. Erin Brown provided an update on Monday, February 24. CE is currently working with sourcing to purchase the licenses and are connecting with Sara Donavan of the Corporates Transformation Team on Friday, February 28, 2025 to discuss the rollout plan. 

Future Direction:
Our strategy for 2025 is to continue to fully utilize our current tools and assess potential gaps that may be addressed through additional solutions.
We will prioritize initiatives that drive tangible productivity gains, operational efficiencies, and customer satisfaction improvements, ultimately supporting our Net Revenue Retention goals.

By building on our existing foundation and strategically investing in AI-powered tools and initiatives, we are well-positioned to drive business growth, improve customer satisfaction, and maintain our competitive edge in the market.
Key Risks and Issues:
The successful execution of our Corporate Internal Gen AI strategy is contingent upon centralized team support and end-user adoption enablement. 

Centralized Team Support: It was already called out and acknowledged in a February 4 meeting that more support is needed from centralized teams and product owners to drive AI adoption within the tools they support. To ensure end-users are aware of and proficient in using the Gen AI functionality, we require more active engagement and enablement from these teams. This includes supporting the roll out, providing training, documentation, and change management support to facilitate seamless adoption and optimal utilization of our AI-powered tools.

End-User Adoption and Enablement: The effective use of Gainsight, Salesforce, and Conversica, in particular, relies on end-users being aware of the Gen AI functionality and understanding how to leverage it to drive productivity gains and customer satisfaction improvements. Without sufficient training, support and enablement, we risk underutilization of these critical tools, which may negatively impact our ability to achieve our Net Revenue Retention goals.
Progress on Use Case this period:
Gong implementation starts April 7 with a six-week implementation period and 633 licenses for Account Executive (sales), Account Specialist (retention) and Customer Success roles. 

 
As of February 27, 2025, Corporates is moving forward with 633 Gong licenses. Erin Brown provided an update on Monday, February 24. CE is currently working with sourcing to purchase the licenses and are connecting with Sara Donavan of the Corporates Transformation Team on Friday, February 28, 2025 to discuss the rollout plan.
Details on Change Management: There has not been any new change management efforts since the start of 2025. The need has been raised above and will be the responsibility of all to consider the current state and how the solutions help address the current challenges.
Path Forward:
As we look to 2025, our path forward is focused on building on the foundation established in 2024, with a emphasis on optimizing the adoption of our current tools, expanding the use of AI-powered solutions, and driving business outcomes through targeted use cases. Key priorities include:

Optimizing Current Tools: We will focus on maximizing the potential of our existing tools, particularly Gainsight, enabling Einstein tools in Salesforce (particularly Revenue Intelligence to launch in late Q1), and Copilot to drive productivity gains, operational efficiencies, and customer satisfaction improvements.

Restarting and Expanding Conversica: We will restart and expand our use of Conversica, leveraging its capabilities to enhance our sales and customer engagement efforts and explore expansion across other teams in Corporates. 

Accelerating Professional Services Use Cases: We will prioritize the development of Professional Services use cases, focusing on internal process improvement initiatives that drive tangible business outcomes. 

Guidance from Corporate Leadership: We will seek guidance from Corporate leadership on the support and resources that will be provided to drive our Corporate Internal Gen AI strategy in 2025. This will ensure that our efforts are aligned with organizational priorities and that we have the necessary backing to achieve our objectives.

Gong: Rollout plan for Gong will follow as we move forward with 633 licenses to cover all Account Executives, Account Specialists, Customer Success Managers and their respective managers. 

Rev Intel and Collaborative Forecasting - tentative to launch May 12

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary: The Newsroom work is splitting into three main buckets of work: scaling (Fact Genie, LEON), launching tools that we started in 24 (LAMP, translating, shotlisting) and net new work (drafting).
Key Risks and Issues: The changes in underlying models can be great but can also deprecate performance or take a lot of time to test. This has been true of the new release of DeepL which was too clever for its own good. Also there are advantages to Sonnet but if the latency is worse, we can't take the risk as speed is so important to us. Our engineering teams are working this through.
Progress on Use Case this period:
FactGenie - Completed integration of all "content" feeds, including the final ones which needed more PDF cracking and have started on the releases which contain a URL so that the content on the link is surfaced in FactGenie. Expanded our testing of Sonnet vs GPT 4 but it seems that it is slower so we may roll back on that as speed is of the essence. May also look at whether we can expand limit rates on Sonnet to get it to run faster (GREEN)
LEON - development of highlighting AI edits is complete and will be released to beta users soon (for Error Catcher and Translation). Drafting has made it to initial prototype stage. . NB we had an issue with Translation when we moved to DeepL's newest model as it was changing titles and names of people to what was in its training set. We've had to roll back for now. (GREEN) 
LAMP - Added 7 more channels so we are now at 10/29. Retrained the Story Selection model to correct for missing US Politics stories and the Asset Association model to resolve an issue with logo shots not being picked up. (AMBER, should return to GREEN)
AVISTA - We still have issues in production around the length of time things take and the format in which they are produced. Our data science team has made several enhancements so we are going to do another limited test to see if the issues are manageable in order to get something to clients.  (AMBER). Still waiting to get synthetic voice contract signed (AMBER)
Github Copilot - We managed to get all our graphics team on to Github Copilot in March and the feedback is very positive in terms of time saved and more robust, checked coding.
Details on Change Management:
We are working on a plan to tweak our programme manager role into a hybrid programme/change manager role as she has specific skills in this area. Her goal will be to get the newsroom up to our TR goal of 50% adoption. In March we had a follow-up on comms and training in order to rethink our approach and get beyond the early adopters. This will include (a) setting up a group of AI Champions in Asia, which is often left out of discussions given time zone complexity, (b) starting to do much more focused workshops by team or workflow and (c) upping the case study communications in our W/AI Forward series of emails and website.
LAMP- we have created an Editorial User Guide and we have a SWOT team in place to evaluate the feedback from the team. Depending on the roll-out, this might be the first team where we can free up headcount and move people around. We are monitoring carefully and will take that into consideration as other roles come up in the Bangalore newsroom.
Path Forward:
FactGenie - finish integrating the "link-only" releases into FactGenie. Integrate a relevance score into FactGenie to help better filter the signal of what should be alerted from the noise of everything that is important in the release. Deliver content from our webwatcher and automations services to FactGenie via a new system to link the pieces together. This will expand FactGenie beyond corporate news to political and economic news and will be a big step forward. This is likely to be tested in Q2 and the rollout starting mid-year. 
LEON: Drafting - Next step is to tune the model to produce four specific story types. Error Catcher: release highlighting functionality to beta users. Translation - release AI editor to French translators and gather feedback to make next decisions e.g. on releasing it directly on to our auto-translations for LSEG. Based on feedback from French, move on to Spanish, Italian, Brazilian Portuguese.
LAMP: Release remaining English channels into LAMP (22 more to go) and release final piece of the AI tooling which ranks stories according to importance, relevance and timeliness. Move on to Top News tool for LSEG's Workspace which is similar but slightly different.
AVISTA - Expand testing group to include another 3-5 users and work out how to publish some of the output to users with disclaimer. Start work on what an AI-first editing tool would look like given limitations of what we have tried to integrate so far.  Hopefully start the Spanish and Portuguese videos...
Questions / Assistance Needed from the W: Are other teams experimenting with Deep Research and Operator on the public OpenAI? A couple of our team are impressed but we need guidelines given it isn't in OpenArena.

Executive Summary:
1. CoCounsel 2.0 and CoCounsel Drafting Implementation: CoCounsel 2.0 was deployed in Q1. CoCounsel Drafting will be deployed by end of Q2-2025. Initial CoCounsel 2.0 training sessions were completed on February 25 and 27. The CoCounsel Drafting strategy includes potential integrations with Contract Express for templates automation and Practical Law for legal playbooks automation. Procurement is partnering with Procurement Legal to establish a cross-functional working group focused on identifying efficiency opportunities in contracting processes, with primary focus on document comparison capabilities. A kick-off session is scheduled for April 3 to align on approach, define key use cases, and develop a plan to test, validate, and cascade standard prompts through the Prompts Library. While initially focusing on document comparison in CoCounsel, we will explore other Thomson Reuters AI solutions for contracting processes.

2. RFP Template Generation MVP: The MVP for collaborative RFP Template generation has been successfully configured in Kronos V2, our Sourcing Projects Management solution. UAT is scheduled for the third week of April (after the Holy week), engaging Sourcing SMEs from the RFP Optimization program. Go-live is set for the last week of April, with plans to expand RFP Template automation throughout Q2.

3. Services Gateway Chatbot Development: Development will proceed using Copilot Studio (Ask TR) following evaluation of the 'TR Ask Julius' chatbot. The initial MVP focusing on Travel & Expenses process is configured in Copilot Studio. Licensing and usage costs were discussed with Jacob Walls and team on March 6. We agreed to incorporate our Procurement use cases as part of the broader Ask TR solution. Our first priority use case remains the Travel & Expenses assistant, which will integrate travel booking, corporate card services, expense management, and travel safety resources into a unified conversational interface based on our internal policies, FAQs and procedures. Additional potential Procurement function use cases were also discussed.
Key Risks and Issues:
- Complex system integration risks: Integrating the AI solutions with existing systems, databases, and workflows.​
- User Adoption and change management risks: Resistance to change or difficulties in understanding and using the new solution could hinder project success.​
- Technical risk: Algorithm complexity could delay or impact the effectiveness of the solution."

Executive Summary: The CIO organization is consolidating AI initiatives across its operational pillars: Commercial Engineering, Customer Trust, Information Security & Risk Management, Service Management, Corporate Services, Employee Technology Services, Platform Engineering, and Enterprise Architecture. We are identifying and documenting approximately 10 high-priority AI use cases to drive innovation within CIO. Previously managed independently by individual teams, these initiatives are now coordinated by a central CIO AI team through a structured governance framework, steering committee oversight, and monthly progress reviews.
Key Risks and Issues: Implementation leads are systematically documenting risks and issues under the guidance of the CIO AI central team. This proactive approach allows us to address challenges before they impact delivery timelines or outcomes.
Progress on Use Case this period: Implementation of our governance framework, formation of the steering committee, and development of project charters for each AI use case is progressing well. We expect full implementation by May 2025, after which we will begin delivering measurable outcomes and regular progress reports.
Details on Change Management: We've established a robust change management process within each project charter. Implementation leads must submit formal change requests for any deviations in timelines, milestones, deliverables, financial requirements, or expected benefits. The steering committee and respective pillar heads review and approve all change requests to maintain governance integrity.
Path Forward: The central CIO AI team is guiding implementation leads in defining specific milestones and deliverables on monthly and quarterly timelines. This structured approach ensures alignment across all initiatives and maximizes resource efficiency.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
April has seen significant advancements in our AI initiatives across various departments, focusing on enhancing efficiency, customer satisfaction, and achieving our savings targets. Notable developments include:
•	Intelligent Assistant Expansion: Continued successful rollouts to Web Services, Cloud Audit Suite, and Fixed Assets products, with improved agent satisfaction and confirmed reduction in average handle times.
•	Service Cloud Voice Deployment: Deployment maintained as scheduled for Product Support teams, with new Einstein Next Best Actions successfully deployed.
•	AI Self-Service Tools: The WhatsApp-based AI self-service tool for the LatAm region continues to achieve high call deflection and resolution rates, while the WhatsApp India Project is pending further investigation.
•	Help and Support Content: Transition plans to Adobe's cloud solution (AEM Cloud) are underway, with AI tools under evaluation to enhance article management and publishing efficiency.
•	C2C Initiatives: The UI/Suspense Payment Application and Customer Queries initiatives are expanding to additional regions, with significant improvements in payment matching automation and resolution times.
•	AI Knowledge Tools: Issues around content categorization and data source access are being addressed to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of our AI knowledge tools.
•	AI Adoption and Savings Targets: On track to achieve the FY 2025 savings target of $1.8M, with AI tool adoption among CXD employees steadily increasing.
•	AI Communications and Idea Space: Successful execution of the 2025 AI Communications plan and the rollout of the Idea Space tool, with high engagement in the AI Spark newsletter and MSFT 365 Copilot licenses.
Overall, the progress made in April indicates a positive trajectory towards our 2025 goals, with enhanced operational efficiency and increased AI adoption across the organization. communication and governance.
Key Risks and Issues:
Effectiveness of our AI knowledge tools is being impacted by several issues.
Issue:  Help and Support content was written for web presentation to customers and is not categorized in a way that Salesforce understands, leading to inefficiencies in search and in some cases resulting in incorrect articles being returned by Einstein
Mitigation: Implement a robust categorization system that aligns with Salesforce's requirements. Enhance search functionalities by making filters sticky and improving the initial global search results. Regularly review and update the categorization to ensure it remains effective

Issue:  Intelligent Assistant and Salesforce Einstein are exclusively limited to knowledge articles and do not utilize other data sources in their AI grounding.  This restricts the range of accessible information as 1) migration of knowledge articles to AEM Guides is not yet complete, resulting in gaps within the knowledge base and 2) doesn’t leverage other possible sources like Salesforce and Flash cases and Flash cases
Mitigation: Complete the migration process by reviewing, categorizing, and publishing all articles in AEM Guides. Explore configurations to enable Salesforce Einstein and Intelligent Assistant to access other data sources like Salesforce cases and Flash cases, thereby enhancing the knowledge base
Progress on Use Case this period:
"•The Intelligent Assistant continues to expand its impact across our support operations, with successful rollouts to Web Services, Cloud Audit Suite, and Fixed Assets products, while training for Cloud Audit Suite representatives remains on track for completion by April's end. Agent satisfaction has improved significantly, with positive feedback increasing from 60% last year to 72% this year, alongside a continued correlation between assistant usage and reduced average handle time (previously observed as a 14% reduction during February despite increased call volumes). Usage rates have held steady at approximately 20% since December. Our upcoming enhancements include a feasibility study for integrating case data for non-GSI users, internal article search functionality scheduled for late Q2 delivery, new content for Web Services and Fixed Asset products, and language localization features. 
• Service Cloud Voice deployed Customer Service  on  April 25th. New  Einstein Next Best Actions,deployed in the same April release. The Q2 Service Cloud Voice deployment for Product Support teams remains on track, and a kick-offs with Product Support leadership teams are underway.
• In March, the call deflection for the WhatsApp-based AI self-service tool for the LatAm region was 30%, showing a slight decline from the previous month. Despite this, 50% of requests were resolved without human interaction, maintaining the same efficiency as in February. Early abandoned contact remained steady at 16%, indicating consistent customer engagement. The average time waiting to interact with an agent after AI interaction was 4.4 minutes, reflecting a satisfactory response rate. The usage of the Product Support Assistant embedded within the product has decreased by 25% month over month but customer engagement showed improvement, with 35% of distinct users opening cases.
• The WhatsApp India Project has been suspended pending  further investigation and legal considerations.  This is likely to be brought back as part of WhatsApp integration with Salesforce planned for 2026 or 2027.
• The Help and Support content team is working to plan and schedule the transition to Adobe's cloud solution (AEM Cloud). This multi-tenant transition must be managed to ensure smooth migration. The team is evaluating an AI solution to identify relevant knowledge base articles for updates and the AI tools that Adobe will provide after migration. These tools are part of our agreement with Adobe. Initial analysis indicates that Adobe's functionality will suffice and offer AI tools for faster authoring and publishing.
•Two initiatives are underway in C2C:
1. The UI/Suspense Payment Application automates payment matching with AI and bots. It reallocates balances to the correct accounts, aiming to reduce cases by 50%. Deployed in the US Legal and LatAm regions, it will expand to ANZ, UK, and Ireland in Q2.
2. The C2C Customer Queries initiative uses LLM to predict customer inquiries. It reduces resolution time from 5 days to 2 in 75% of cases. The project continues in ""Test and Learn"" and handles around 20,000 queries monthly.
Both initiatives focus on improving efficiency and customer satisfaction."
Details on Change Management:
CXD has adopted the TR Enterprise AI OKR for 2025 and will ensure 50% of CXD employees are using Gen AI tools regularly as part of their daily task.  In March  47.3% of CXD employees used AI tools regularly (+ 6.7 pp m/m increase).  We expect this number to continue to rise naturally as we deploy additional AI tools across our CSS agent population the year and use our AI communication channels to promote AI learning opportunities and share innovative and inspiring  ways our colleagues are using AI in their day to day work.  

2025 AI Communications plan was developed and Q1 and is being executed. The CXD AI Atrium page and the first monthly newsletter (AI Spark: AI Innovation in CXD) launched April 15th with AI success stories from across CXD and inspirational video of colleagues using AI in their dat to day tasks.  The first newsletter was a great success with a 76% open rate across ~2,300 recipients. Future newsletters will be supported by an intake process for success stories from across the group. 

A working group is partnering to stand up the Idea Space tool as a way to capture and govern AI ideas across CXD.  An initial version of the tool has been built and is being refined. It is expected the tool will roll out across CXD in May.

Demand for MSFT  365 Copilot licenses remains high as groups find Copilot has proven to be an invaluable tool in streamlining our daily operations. Usage of these licenses is being monitored and remains very high.
Path Forward:
•	Intelligent Assistant Expansion: Continue successful rollouts to Web Services, Cloud Audit Suite, and Fixed Assets, with a focus on enhancing agent satisfaction and reducing average handle times. Feasibility studies for integrating non-GSI case data and internal article searches will be key areas of focus.
•	Service Cloud Voice Deployment: Maintain the deployment schedule for Q2 in Product Support teams and continue coordinating with leadership teams to ensure smooth implementation and adoption.
•	AI Self-Service Tools: Continue to monitor and enhance call deflection rates and request resolution through AI self-service tools, particularly in the LatAm region, while exploring further integration opportunities with Salesforce for the WhatsApp India project.
•	Help and Support Content: Transition to Adobe's cloud solution (AEM Cloud) to improve knowledge base article management and publishing. Evaluate AI tools to enhance content relevance and authoring efficiency.
•	C2C Initiatives: Expand the UI/Suspense Payment Application and Customer Queries initiatives to additional regions, with a focus on automating payment matching and reducing resolution times to improve efficiency and customer satisfaction.
•	AI Knowledge Tools: Address inefficiencies by implementing a robust categorization system and enabling broader data source access for Salesforce Einstein and Intelligent Assistant to enhance the knowledge base.
•	AI Adoption and Savings Targets: Continue to promote AI tool usage among CXD employees to achieve the 2025 savings target of $1.8M and increase AI tool adoption rates.
•	AI Communications and Idea Space: Execute the 2025 AI Communications plan, roll out the Idea Space tool to capture and govern AI ideas across CXD, monitor impact of MSFT 365 Copilot licenses to streamline daily operations.
•	Craft EPC 2026 aims to speed up the integration of AI across CXD by enabling strong self-service options for customers and deploying AI to handle routine customer support queries. This approach seeks to enhance the added value provided by agents through personalized service on more complex customer queries.

Gong: A pilot of Gong was conducted in Q4-2024, with 20 out of 40 participants actively engaging. As of February 27, 2025, Corporates is moving forward with 633 Gong licenses and as of April 28, another 100 licenses has been requested and implementation has begun. 

Future Direction:
Our strategy for 2025 is to continue to fully utilize our current tools and assess potential gaps that may be addressed through additional solutions.
We will prioritize initiatives that drive tangible productivity gains, operational efficiencies, and customer satisfaction improvements, ultimately supporting our Net Revenue Retention goals.

By building on our existing foundation and strategically investing in AI-powered tools and initiatives, we are well-positioned to drive business growth, improve customer satisfaction, and maintain our competitive edge in the market.
Key Risks and Issues:
The successful execution of our Corporate Internal Gen AI strategy is contingent upon funding for tool access (another $200k scoped for Gong, waitlist building for Copilot), centralized team support and end-user adoption enablement. 

Revenue Intelligence: May 12 launch is dependent on successful release of enhancements 

Centralized Team Support: It was already called out and acknowledged in a February 4 meeting that more support is needed from centralized teams and product owners to drive AI adoption within the tools they support. To ensure end-users are aware of and proficient in using the Gen AI functionality, we require more active engagement and enablement from these teams. This includes supporting the roll out, providing training, documentation, and change management support to facilitate seamless adoption and optimal utilization of our AI-powered tools.

End-User Adoption and Enablement: The effective use of Gainsight, Salesforce, and Conversica, in particular, relies on end-users being aware of the Gen AI functionality and understanding how to leverage it to drive productivity gains and customer satisfaction improvements. Without sufficient training, support and enablement, we risk underutilization of these critical tools, which may negatively impact our ability to achieve our Net Revenue Retention goals.
Progress on Use Case this period:
Gong implementation started April 7 with a six-week implementation period and 633 licenses for Account Executive (sales), Account Specialist (retention) and Customer Success roles. Another 217 licenses is being scoped for Global Accounts, Solution Consulting and Partnership & Alliances teams - funding TBC. 

Revenue Intelligence: continued reginement on the tool in prep for May 12 launch, finalized channel roll out.
Details on Change Management: There has not been any new change management efforts since the start of 2025. The need has been raised above and will be the responsibility of all to consider the current state and how the solutions help address the current challenges.
Path Forward:
As we look to 2025, our path forward is focused on building on the foundation established in 2024, with a emphasis on optimizing the adoption of our current tools, expanding the use of AI-powered solutions, and driving business outcomes through targeted use cases. Key priorities include:

Optimizing Current Tools: We will focus on maximizing the potential of our existing tools, particularly Gainsight, enabling Einstein tools in Salesforce (particularly Revenue Intelligence to launch in late Q1), and Copilot to drive productivity gains, operational efficiencies, and customer satisfaction improvements.

Restarting and Expanding Conversica: We will restart and expand our use of Conversica, leveraging its capabilities to enhance our sales and customer engagement efforts and explore expansion across other teams in Corporates. 

Accelerating Professional Services Use Cases: We will prioritize the development of Professional Services use cases, focusing on internal process improvement initiatives that drive tangible business outcomes. 

Guidance from Corporate Leadership: We will seek guidance from Corporate leadership on the support and resources that will be provided to drive our Corporate Internal Gen AI strategy in 2025. This will ensure that our efforts are aligned with organizational priorities and that we have the necessary backing to achieve our objectives.

Gong: Rollout plan for Gong will follow as we move forward with 633 licenses to cover all Account Executives, Account Specialists, Customer Success Managers and their respective managers. 

Rev Intel and Collaborative Forecasting - to launch May 12
Questions / Assistance Needed from the W: (1) We still need access to the Copilot Viva dashboard.

For Tax Research (Content), we are hiring a Program Manager to work on identifying all use cases across the organization in order to prioritize, determine impact, and ascertain resources.  With the number of regulatory changes in Q1, we have not been able to spend as much time moving projects forward. This Program Manager will drive the cases in development.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary: AI-assisted Commentary copy editing is in use for more UK publications and the number of copy editing rules being automated is expanding. The MVP Judicial Filings workflow was delayed but UAT begins next week and the first jurisdiction is targeted for production release mid-May. A 'bring your own code' capability has been released in Content Console, allowing Operations users the ability to write custom code to automate select activities. The learning curve is still quite high and the capability is not particularly intuitive, requiring more assistance than was anticipated. We discovered that some previously written code is too complex for this capability and must be packaged as a 'Skill'. The Content Console workflow service will soon have the capability to call these Skills. Some use cases are progressing with the capabilities so far released, but we are working through a variety of blockers for many of the use cases.
Key Risks and Issues: Unknown unknowns related to capability needs and workflow configuration. Integrating with legacy technology is time-consuming and fraught with surprising issues that need to be dealt with on a case by case basis. [Mitigation: Expanding capabilities in (and subsequently migrating more content to) Content Console means that more of these issues are avoided or already resolved.]
Progress on Use Case this period:
Commentary: The Commentary copy editing team is seeing additional efficiencies as they expand utilization of the capability to additional publications and styling rules. They are making progress on other automation related to conversion and content delivery preparation (mock filings, insert verification).

Primary Law, Specialty, and other DIY: The first AI Assistant use case has launched in our Judicial Workbench. UK Pending Actions is one of the first use cases to successfully utilize the new DIY capabilities in Content Console. Previously manual effort to classify document types and rename files is now automated, with human review currently in place for accuracy.  US DOJ Private Files is another use case that has successfully utilized the DIY capabilities. Work that previously required 30-45 min per file can be completed in less than 10 min using DIY automation - but we are unable to put this in production until we get approval from the DOJ to use AI for this work. We continue to make progress on a number of other use cases, including ingest/conversion/normalization of law reviews, US Legislation, UK Cases, and US Regulations.

KM: Finalized KM standards and work continues on KM file cleanup and chatbot testing.
Details on Change Management: Program-level change management plan was approved. Project-specific change management plans are under review and being finalized. Some projects have plans underway and others are drafting plans.
Path Forward:
DIY AI capability focus: Release Content Console capability to allow a workflow to call a skill; improve workflow management and task management experience; test similarity service templates; train workflow architects on Content Console concepts.

Acquisition (Judicial Filings): UAT planned for OH Supreme Court briefs flowing through MVP workflow.
Primary Law - continue JWB development of AI assisted processing; further experiment and launch DIY use cases using newly released capabilities.
Commentary - expand implementation of copy editing solution; continue experimentation for content delivery solutions
Specialty - continue DIY use case development, launching/expanding automation for processing law reviews, news

KM - launch Ask Connie bot for general Content Operations use.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
TAP’S Internal AI Program has carried strong momentum through April 2025, with the overall status marked as green. v1 of the AI-Powered Pre-Call Planning released in January, utilizing Copilot in Edge. This solution is for whitespace discovery calls. v2 is in development in partnership with Commercial Excellence and will introduce existing customer data to the solution. It has been renamed to ACES - Agentic Customer Enhanced Signals. Planned pilot shifted from Q1 to early Q2 as we learn how specific guidance to the various agents must be to be effective. We have also begun exploring pre-call planning prompting in Gong through the use of Account AI

Copilot licenses have been extended to sales managers, bringing total deployment up to ~120 users. TAAP continues to see high utilization of Copilot were deployed, without a lot of change management emphasis. We attribute this to a clear understanding of potential use cases due to the users that have had access for a while and integration of Copilot into the tools users engage with daily.

Gong continues to get positive praise from the sales team, with call recording completion of Teams meetings sitting at 54%. This completion rate has remained fairly consistent throughout 2024. We are finding varied usage patterns of the functions within Gong. Some users favor Follow-up Email and Ask Anything, while others see the most benefit from using the Pipeline Intelligence area. And while average weekly logins remains steady at 2 logins per week, we want to drive DAILY use of Gong, even if only for a few features. All US-based SEs, CEs, and SDRs now have Gong access.

AI Sales Assistant (Commercial Policies): We have paused development of this assistant due to gaps in Copilot Studio knowledge and/or functionality resulting in inconsistent results. These results are not acceptable for Commercial Policy guidance. In pausing, we have ensured the updated documentation is stored in an accessible location in Advisor and made the sales floor aware of these updates. We continue to explore the use of Copilot Studio with lower-stake use cases, such as onboarding and training documentation.
Key Risks and Issues:
Copilot for Bing Pre-call Planning Assistant has been hallucinating lately, making it unreliable for complex planning.
There is an opportunity to increase Copilot Studio expertise. The platform is showing great potential that we just haven't been able to transform into reliable deployments in TAAP.
Progress on Use Case this period:
All use cases have progressed incrementally this period, each being refined and more embedded in daily work.

Notable exception is the AI Sales Assistant (Commercial Policy) which as been paused due to gaps in functionality and expertise of Copilot Studio, both within TR and at Microsoft. Please see Executive Summary for additional commentary.
Details on Change Management: Reinvigorating change management through the use an AI Habits Roadshow, designed to integrate specific AI habits into daily workflow. We have completed 15 of ~45 Roadshows. On pace to complete 100% by May. In addition, using weekly newsletter to put AI Use Cases, functionality, and education front and center for the sales floor.
Path Forward: Continue to drive daily AI habits, embedding tools into the daily workflow. Finalize Pre-Call Planning v2 alongside the emphasis on change management.
Questions / Assistance Needed from the W: Are there teams that have successfully deployed agents in Copilot Studio to non-M365 Copilot users?

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary: The Newsroom work is splitting into three main buckets of work: scaling (Fact Genie, LEON), launching tools that we started in 24 (LAMP, translating, shotlisting) and net new work (drafting).
Key Risks and Issues: The changes in underlying models can be great but can also deprecate performance or take a lot of time to test. This has been true of the new release of DeepL which was too clever for its own good. Also there are advantages to Sonnet but if the latency is worse, we can't take the risk as speed is so important to us. Our engineering teams are working this through.
Progress on Use Case this period:
FactGenie - Completed integration of all "content" feeds, including the final ones which needed more PDF cracking and have started on the releases which contain a URL so that the content on the link is surfaced in FactGenie. Expanded our testing of Sonnet vs GPT 4 but it seems that it is slower so we may roll back on that as speed is of the essence. May also look at whether we can expand limit rates on Sonnet to get it to run faster (GREEN)
LEON - development of highlighting AI edits is complete and will be released to beta users soon (for Error Catcher and Translation). Drafting has made it to initial prototype stage. . NB we had an issue with Translation when we moved to DeepL's newest model as it was changing titles and names of people to what was in its training set. We've had to roll back for now. (GREEN) 
LAMP - Added 7 more channels so we are now at 10/29. Retrained the Story Selection model to correct for missing US Politics stories and the Asset Association model to resolve an issue with logo shots not being picked up. (AMBER, should return to GREEN)
AVISTA - We still have issues in production around the length of time things take and the format in which they are produced. Our data science team has made several enhancements so we are going to do another limited test to see if the issues are manageable in order to get something to clients.  (AMBER). Still waiting to get synthetic voice contract signed (AMBER)
Github Copilot - We managed to get all our graphics team on to Github Copilot in March and the feedback is very positive in terms of time saved and more robust, checked coding.
Details on Change Management:
We are working on a plan to tweak our programme manager role into a hybrid programme/change manager role as she has specific skills in this area. Her goal will be to get the newsroom up to our TR goal of 50% adoption. In March we had a follow-up on comms and training in order to rethink our approach and get beyond the early adopters. This will include (a) setting up a group of AI Champions in Asia, which is often left out of discussions given time zone complexity, (b) starting to do much more focused workshops by team or workflow and (c) upping the case study communications in our W/AI Forward series of emails and website.
LAMP- we have created an Editorial User Guide and we have a SWOT team in place to evaluate the feedback from the team. Depending on the roll-out, this might be the first team where we can free up headcount and move people around. We are monitoring carefully and will take that into consideration as other roles come up in the Bangalore newsroom.
Path Forward:
FactGenie - finish integrating the "link-only" releases into FactGenie. Integrate a relevance score into FactGenie to help better filter the signal of what should be alerted from the noise of everything that is important in the release. Deliver content from our webwatcher and automations services to FactGenie via a new system to link the pieces together. This will expand FactGenie beyond corporate news to political and economic news and will be a big step forward. This is likely to be tested in Q2 and the rollout starting mid-year. 
LEON: Drafting - Next step is to tune the model to produce four specific story types. Error Catcher: release highlighting functionality to beta users. Translation - release AI editor to French translators and gather feedback to make next decisions e.g. on releasing it directly on to our auto-translations for LSEG. Based on feedback from French, move on to Spanish, Italian, Brazilian Portuguese.
LAMP: Release remaining English channels into LAMP (22 more to go) and release final piece of the AI tooling which ranks stories according to importance, relevance and timeliness. Move on to Top News tool for LSEG's Workspace which is similar but slightly different.
AVISTA - Expand testing group to include another 3-5 users and work out how to publish some of the output to users with disclaimer. Start work on what an AI-first editing tool would look like given limitations of what we have tried to integrate so far.  Hopefully start the Spanish and Portuguese videos...
Questions / Assistance Needed from the W: Are other teams experimenting with Deep Research and Operator on the public OpenAI? A couple of our team are impressed but we need guidelines given it isn't in OpenArena.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary: We continue to see interest among the commercial teams to know more about how they can leverage OpenArena and other tools. We kicked off the first learn & share series for the Reuters commercial teams, called "AI in action" this month. We aim to have it once a quarter, supplemented by focused sessions on AI use cases for certain functions and AI clinics (where experts can help troubleshoot and help with prompts and models). The first session saw great participation (200+ attendees). Marketing team have been exploring StoryKit, and we have also reached out to the team managing Adobe Firefly to see how we can get a better view of other use cases and/or trainings. There are also requests coming through various functions to understand how we can support them in building AI programs for specific use cases; e.g. Chat bot to manage customer queries, Automate reading and extracting information through multiple contracts etc. As we progress, building business cases around these use cases and exploring ways to partner with other TR teams would be great.
Key Risks and Issues:
Budget and prioritization come up in several of these conversations.
On OpenArena, while there are many ideas and use cases we could pursue, we need to find a way to support teams in building these out.
Progress on Use Case this period:
Marketing - StoryKit: Overall we are happy with the tool and it comes with great customer support, and the potential to save money for us in the long run. We are setting up more and more templates every day to streamline the process. The tool was used to quickly create the MLB demo for NAB in less than a week, and we are using it weekly for social media output. We’ve also started experimenting with product sizzles, with promising early results (we should have the first one in the next couple of weeks!). 
We have also introduced marketing team to Landon Balster's team to see how we can leverage Adobe Firefly

Executive Summary:
1. CoCounsel 2.0 and CoCounsel Drafting Implementation: CoCounsel 2.0 was deployed in Q1. CoCounsel Drafting will be deployed by end of Q2-2025. Initial CoCounsel 2.0 training sessions were completed on February 25 and 27. Procurement is partnering with Procurement Legal to establish a cross-functional working group focused on identifying efficiency opportunities in contracting processes, with primary focus on document comparison capabilities. While initially focusing on document comparison in CoCounsel, we will explore other Thomson Reuters AI solutions for contracting processes.

UAT is scheduled for the third week of April (after the Holy week), engaging Sourcing SMEs from the RFP Optimization program. Go-live is set for the last week of April, with plans to expand RFP Template automation throughout Q2.

The initial MVP focusing on Travel & Expenses process is configured in Copilot Studio. Licensing and usage costs were discussed with Jacob Walls and team on March 6. We agreed to incorporate our Procurement use cases as part of the broader Ask TR solution. Our first priority use case remains the Travel & Expenses assistant, which will integrate travel booking, corporate card services, expense management, and travel safety resources into a unified conversational interface based on our internal policies, FAQs and procedures. Additional potential Procurement function use cases were also discussed.

- User Adoption and change management risks: Resistance to change or difficulties in understanding and using the new solution could hinder project success.​
- Technical risk: Algorithm complexity could delay or impact the effectiveness of the solution."

AI Use Cases: Agent Knowledge: Einstein Knowledge workflow,Agent Productivity: Salesforce Einstein Gen AI replies and summarization,Agent Productivity: Service Cloud (Salesforce) Voice,Customer Self-Service: WhatsApp Support for LatAm,Internal Productivity: Customer to Cash,Internal Productivity: Help and Support Content Acceleration
Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary: The report highlights significant advancements in customer experience and support operations, emphasizing the adoption of AI tools and strategies to enhance efficiency and achieve 2025 targets. Key achievements include the successful rollout of Intelligent Assistant across product support operations, steady usage rates, and improved engagement metrics; enhanced call deflection and resolution rates through WhatsApp AI self-service tools; and ongoing deployment of Service Cloud Voice. Initiatives like C2C payment automation and query resolution have significantly reduced cases and improved handling times.  Communication efforts, including newsletters and innovation hubs, aim to foster AI adoption across teams, with high demand for Microsoft 365 Copilot licenses showcasing AI’s value in daily operations. The organization remains on track to achieve its 2025 savings goal of $1.8M, driven by strategic use of AI and innovative solutions.
Key Risks and Issues:
Effectiveness of our AI knowledge tools is being impacted by several issues.
Issue:  Help and Support content was written for web presentation to customers and is not categorized in a way that Salesforce understands, leading to inefficiencies in search and in some cases resulting in incorrect articles being returned by Einstein
Mitigation: Implement a robust categorization system that aligns with Salesforce's requirements. Enhance search functionalities by making filters sticky and improving the initial global search results. Regularly review and update the categorization to ensure it remains effective

Issue:  Intelligent Assistant and Salesforce Einstein are exclusively limited to knowledge articles and do not utilize other data sources in their AI grounding.  This restricts the range of accessible information as 1) migration of knowledge articles to AEM Guides is not yet complete, resulting in gaps within the knowledge base and 2) doesn’t leverage other possible sources like Salesforce and Flash cases and Flash cases
Mitigation: Complete the migration process by reviewing, categorizing, and publishing all articles in AEM Guides. Explore configurations to enable Salesforce Einstein and Intelligent Assistant to access other data sources like Salesforce cases and Flash cases, thereby enhancing the knowledge base
Progress on Use Case this period:
Intelligent Assistant
• The Intelligent Assistant continues to expand its presence across support operations for tax products. Rollouts to Web Services, Cloud Audit Suite, and Fixed Assets products have been successful. Training for Cloud Audit Suite representatives has been completed as planned in April.
• Data and Analytics has been analyzing usage data and found a couple interesting correlation:    Agents who attended live training sessions displayed significantly higher engagement scores (30%) compared to those who did not (7.6%), with engagement showing a compounding effect over time on metrics such as CSAT and Average Handle Time.
• Usage rates remain steady at around 20% since December.  Internal article search functionality (on track for late Q2 delivery).  A  feasibility study for integrating case data for non-GSI users concluded that inclusion in Intelligent Assistant isn't feasible and alternatives are being explored.
Service Cloud Voice
• Service Cloud Voice was successfully deployed to Customer Service teams on April 25th, alongside Einstein Next Best Actions.
• The Q2 Service Cloud Voice deployment for Product Support teams is progressing as scheduled, with ongoing kick-offs involving Product Support leadership teams.
WhatsApp AI Self-Service Tool
• Call deflection for the WhatsApp-based AI self-service tool in the LatAm region increase to 37% (+7pp m/m) in May.
• 51% (+1pp m/m) of requests were resolved without human interaction, maintaining efficiency levels observed in April. Early abandoned dipped slightly to 15%, indicating stable customer engagement.
• GSI/Open Arena Integration: Implemented. This integration provides the agents with a formatted solution for every case opened in GSI with the goal to reduce  AHT.
WhatsApp Integration with Salesforce
• The WhatsApp India Project remains suspended due to pending investigations and legal considerations. It is now tentatively planned for inclusion in the broader WhatsApp integration with Salesforce scheduled for 2026 or 2027.
Help and Support Content Team
• Transition to Adobe's cloud solution (AEM Cloud) planned for January 2026. This multi-tenant migration is being carefully managed to ensure a smooth process.
• Work is underway to evaluate AI tools offered by Adobe for identifying relevant knowledge base articles for updates. Preliminary analysis confirms that Adobe's functionality will suffice, providing faster authoring and publishing capabilities post-migration.
• Efforts are underway to investigate acceleration improvements for identifying and updating knowledge base articles, aiming to enhance workflows and efficiency ahead of the cloud migration planned for January 2026.
C2C Initiatives
• UI/Suspense Payment Application: Deployment continues to automate payment matching with AI and bots, reallocating balances to correct accounts. The initiative has reduced cases by 50%. Having expanded to the ANZ, UK, and Ireland regions in May, further deployments are on hold due to developer bandwidth.
• C2C Customer Queries: The initiative uses large language models (LLMs) to predict customer inquiries, improving resolution times from 5 days to 2 in 80% of cases. Now handling around 25,000 queries monthly, the project team is now focused on phase 2 that will create workflows for the AI agent to automate responses to selected queries.
Details on Change Management:
The pathway to achieve the 2025 savings target has been identified and confirmed. Through April, CS&S is on track to achieve FY 2025 savings of $1.8M, steady m/m - actual reduction was 42 FTEs with a 2025 savings value of $1.2M.  Quarterly plan will be updated for June.
CXD has adopted the TR Enterprise AI OKR for 2025 and will ensure 50% of CXD employees are using Gen AI tools regularly as part of their daily task.  In April 50.1% of CXD employees used AI tools regularly (+ 2.8 pp m/m increase).  We expect this number to continue to rise naturally as we deploy additional AI tools across our CSS agent population the year and use our AI communication channels to promote AI learning opportunities and share innovative and inspiring ways our colleagues are using AI in their day-to-day work.  

2025 AI Communications plan was developed and Q1 and is being executed. The CXD AI Atrium page and the first monthly newsletter (AI Spark: AI Innovation in CXD) launched April 15th and the second newsletter   went out on May 15th.  The newsletters have been well received with an average open rate of 73% across ~2,300 recipients. 

A working group is partnering to stand up the CXD InnovAItion Hub to capture and govern AI ideas across CXD.  An initial version of the tool has been built and is being refined. It is expected the tool will roll out across CXD in mid-June.

Demand for MSFT  365 Copilot licenses remains high as groups find Copilot has proven to be an invaluable tool in streamlining our daily operations. Usage of these licenses is being monitored and remains very high.
Path Forward:
• Intelligent Assistant Expansion: Addition of internal content slated for May.  Data analysis to more deeply understand the impact of the tool.  Increased Adoption.
• Service Cloud Voice Deployment: Maintain the deployment schedule for Q2 in Product Support teams and continue coordinating with leadership teams to ensure smooth implementation and adoption.
• AI Self-Service Tools: Continue to monitor and enhance call deflection rates and request resolution through AI self-service tools.
• Help and Support Content: Transition to Adobe's cloud solution (AEM Cloud) to improve knowledge base article management and publishing. Evaluate AI tools to enhance content relevance and authoring efficiency.
• C2C Initiatives: Expand the UI/Suspense Payment Application and Customer Queries initiatives to additional regions, with a focus on automating payment matching and reducing resolution times to improve efficiency and customer satisfaction.
• AI Knowledge Tools: Address inefficiencies by implementing a robust categorization system and enabling broader data source access for Salesforce Einstein and Intelligent Assistant to enhance the knowledge base.
• AI Adoption and Savings Targets: Continue to promote AI tool usage among CXD employees to achieve the 2025 savings target of $1.8M and achieve Active Use OKR.
• AI Communications and Idea Space: Execute the 2025 AI Communications plan, roll out the Idea Space tool to capture and govern AI ideas across CXD, monitor impact of MSFT 365 Copilot licenses to streamline daily operations.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
As we move into 2025, our corporate AI strategy remains focused on leveraging internal and third-party tools to drive productivity gains, operational efficiencies, and enhanced customer satisfaction, ultimately improving Net Revenue Retention. Our key objectives are to maximize the potential of our existing tools, particularly Salesforce and Gainsight, and identify areas where additional solutions can further support our goals.

Current Progress and Initiatives:
We are optimizing the use of tools like MS Copilot, with expanded access across the organization, to enhance productivity and efficiency.
Copilot and Open Arena continue to be the most widely adopted GenAI tools across Corporates. 

Gong: A pilot of Gong was conducted in Q4-2024, with 20 out of 40 participants actively engaging. In Februaru, Corporates decided to move forward with 633 Gong and launch is set for June 3.  

Future Direction:
Our strategy for 2025 is to continue to fully utilize our current tools and assess potential gaps that may be addressed through additional solutions.
We will prioritize initiatives that drive tangible productivity gains, operational efficiencies, and customer satisfaction improvements, ultimately supporting our Net Revenue Retention goals.

By building on our existing foundation and strategically investing in AI-powered tools and initiatives, we are well-positioned to drive business growth, improve customer satisfaction, and maintain our competitive edge in the market.
Key Risks and Issues:
The successful execution of our Corporate Internal Gen AI strategy is contingent upon funding for tool access (another $200k scoped for Gong, waitlist building for Copilot), centralized team support and end-user adoption enablement. 

Revenue Intelligence: May 12 launch was pushed - launch TBC.  

Centralized Team Support: It was already called out and acknowledged in a February 4 meeting that more support is needed from centralized teams and product owners to drive AI adoption within the tools they support. To ensure end-users are aware of and proficient in using the Gen AI functionality, we require more active engagement and enablement from these teams. This includes supporting the roll out, providing training, documentation, and change management support to facilitate seamless adoption and optimal utilization of our AI-powered tools.

End-User Adoption and Enablement: The effective use of Gainsight, Salesforce, and Conversica, in particular, relies on end-users being aware of the Gen AI functionality and understanding how to leverage it to drive productivity gains and customer satisfaction improvements. Without sufficient training, support and enablement, we risk underutilization of these critical tools, which may negatively impact our ability to achieve our Net Revenue Retention goals.
Progress on Use Case this period:
Gong implementation started April 7 with a six-week implementation period and 633 licenses for Account Executive (sales), Account Specialist (retention) and Customer Success roles. Another 217 licenses is being scoped for Global Accounts, Solution Consulting and Partnership & Alliances teams - funding TBC and based on successful wave one launch. Gong launches to Corporates starting Tuesday, June 3. 

Revenue Intelligence: continued reginement on the tool in prep for May 12 launch, finalized channel roll out.
Details on Change Management: There has not been any new change management efforts since the start of 2025. The need has been raised above and will be the responsibility of all to consider the current state and how the solutions help address the current challenges.
Path Forward:
As we look to 2025, our path forward is focused on building on the foundation established in 2024, with a emphasis on optimizing the adoption of our current tools, expanding the use of AI-powered solutions, and driving business outcomes through targeted use cases. Key priorities include:

Optimizing Current Tools: We will focus on maximizing the potential of our existing tools, particularly Gainsight, enabling Einstein tools in Salesforce (particularly Revenue Intelligence to launch in late Q1), and Copilot to drive productivity gains, operational efficiencies, and customer satisfaction improvements.

Restarting and Expanding Conversica: We will restart and expand our use of Conversica, leveraging its capabilities to enhance our sales and customer engagement efforts and explore expansion across other teams in Corporates. 

Accelerating Professional Services Use Cases: We will prioritize the development of Professional Services use cases, focusing on internal process improvement initiatives that drive tangible business outcomes. 

Guidance from Corporate Leadership: We will seek guidance from Corporate leadership on the support and resources that will be provided to drive our Corporate Internal Gen AI strategy in 2025. This will ensure that our efforts are aligned with organizational priorities and that we have the necessary backing to achieve our objectives.

Gong: Rollout plan for Gong will follow as we move forward with 633 licenses to cover all Account Executives, Account Specialists, Customer Success Managers and their respective managers. 

Rev Intel and Collaborative Forecasting - to launch May 12
Questions / Assistance Needed from the W: None at this time.

Executive Summary: Additional use cases identified and underway for Product Management, Product Design, and Tax Research Content. Will continue to assess scope/usage and perform tests and experiments into second half of 2025.  Will assess financial savings in Q3/Q4 2025.
Key Risks and Issues:
RISK: Dynamic nature of product management role and activity, based on outcomes rather than outputs, make harder to find one single metric that can be utilized to single out efficiency gains by using AI. While we see the adoption of AI in these roles, it’s harder to estimate impact only based on time-savings dimension.
