While we evaluate options to bring a tool/system for PMs, our current hypothesis is that generic tools (like Copilot / Claude / OpenAI) might be best suited for the role – and we may create specific prompts or agents for the specific use cases that we target.
Progress on Use Case this period:
Four product manager use cases are being tracked in Launch stage and six in Ideation stage to be integrated into the product management workflow in support of the Product Operating Model. Product Requirements Document (PRD) Assistant and ADO User Story Builder launched, and ADO Epic & Feature Builder and Release Notes Generator are in beta, all leveraging both Open Arena and Copilot Chat Agent tools on the Atrium, promoted to the Innovation Team and product management Copilot license holders for feedback. 

Three Product Design use cases (AI Assisted Research, Design, and Frontend Engineering) remain in experimentation phase. We’re continuing AI-assisted design and front end engineering experimentation with a focus on Prototyping+, including active discovery with v0 by Vercel with onboarding and training in mid-June. Usage stats for AI Assisted Research via Stravito AI Insights are now enabled to support Product Design metrics in the TR AI Adoption dashboard.

In Product Content, we developed the requirements for the TaxLaw2Code project for analyzing differences and will begin the design work for creating ADO tickets automatically from the annotations. In addition, the Lead Tax Analysts are using Materia in their tax research. Finally, we have hired in May an AI Program Manager to identify all use cases, prioritize based on impact, and work towards implementation.  

Three Tax Research (Content) use cases are being tracked in the experimentation stage: TaxLaw2Code (ADO), Release Notes AI Creation, and Modernize iDesign Development Tool.  Given the constraints on Lab resources, we are working with AWS on a workshop to work on a backwards approach for a 'day in the life' for direct tax, indirect tax, and global trade. This will allow us to uncover additional use cases.  For the Modernize iDesign Development tool, we have received some EPC funding to begin the work in 2025 but will take 12-18 months.
Details on Change Management: Product Management, Design and Tax Research are focused on engagement for product manager-focused solutions via comms, Atrium page launch, Innovation Team and Copilot tester activation and promotion.
Path Forward:
Product Management path forward is to enhance existing AI solutions via Open Arena models and Copilot capabilities, while continuing innovation discovery and experimentation toward development of new use cases following the Product Operating Model, and in parallel exploring third-party AI tools.

Product Design’s path forward is to continue advancing experimentation with a focus on business-aligned pilots, prioritizing the selection of a strategic AI-assisted prototyping tool—v0, Lovable, or Figma Make—by Q3.

For Tax Research (Content), we are hiring a Program Manager to work on identifying all use cases across the organization in order to prioritize, determine impact, and ascertain resources.  With the number of regulatory changes in Q1, we have not been able to spend as much time moving projects forward. This Program Manager will drive the cases in development.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
We have increased the number of tools following the adoption of GHCP and AmazonQ. In May, we conducted extensive testing with engineering teams across Product Engineering, including Research teams, successfully evaluating Cursor, ClaudeCode, and Cline.
 
Cursor has received positive feedback from participants who preferred it over GitHub Copilot (GHCP). The rollout is scheduled to begin in the first week of June, with an initial procurement of 300 licenses at an annual cost of $32 each, representing 20% of the full price.
 
We are collaborating with the CIO, Internal AI, and ETS teams to integrate usage metrics for Cursor, ClaudeCode, and Cline by June 30th. Additionally, we are testing the performance of these tools across various development activities, including KTLO Enhancements, New Feature Development, and Quality Engineering.
 
Internal AI has released a usage dashboard for individuals and managers to monitor AI DevTools usage, with plans to add Cursor, ClaudeCode, and Cline data in June. The CIO team has identified a few issues with GHCP under usage reporting. They are currently investigating these issues and have raised a ticket with Microsoft for further assistance. We continue to push the teams to deliver this as quickly as possible.
Key Risks and Issues:
1. Cline offers potential for faster code development, but carries risks of IP loss and harm to TR systems. To mitigate these, we propose limiting use to internal LLMs, employing development containers for isolation, and implementing robust auditing.
You can find guidelines here: https://trten.sharepoint.com/sites/intr-isrm-business-and-product-security/SitePages/Securing-the-AI-coding-tool-chain.aspx
2.  Developer surveys indicate that while AI can suggest boilerplate code, it lacks the ability to ideate or strategize. Therefore, it is crucial to maintain a human in the loop for editing and guiding the output of AI, rather than relying on it solely as a source of output.
Progress on Use Case this period:
1. Our engineering community is using Viva Engage to share their usage of AI-Powered Dev Tools in their daily work, experiments, and engage across the organisation. Posts with short demos and everything related to AI-powered dev tools are available via AI-Powered Tools Topic: https://engage.cloud.microsoft/main/org/tr.com/topics/eyJfdHlwZSI6IlRvcGljIiwiaWQiOiJFVF9mNjhmOWZkNS05MWJiLTRlMTMtYWNmYy04ODVmNTgyNThhYmMifQ/all
2. The CIO team has identified a few issues with GHCP under usage reporting. They are currently investigating these issues and have raised a ticket with Microsoft for further assistance.
3. With enhanced usage tracking and increased leadership involvement, we anticipate a rise in adoption and usage.
Details on Change Management: None
Path Forward: We provide both open-source and licensed, commercial tools for developers to improve productivity, coding efficiency and developer experience, and measure usage and trends across these tools.

AI Use Cases: Fact extraction and summarisation with FactGenie,Translation to journalistic standards,Video Editing,Summarization
Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
While the newsroom build and deploy work continues, we are now also turning more focus towards the change management piece beyond the staff who use our integrated AI tools. The newsroom is still only at about 30% adoption so we are standing up a whole piece of work around helping the other 70% get involved through a variety of communications, trainings, peer sharing, champions etc. 
In the build space, we are making some changes to the scope of the workstreams to support a broader piece of change in Reuters Editorial towards more of a follow-the-sun model and to help more people work across both text and visuals. This feeds into our 2026 EPC ask for Newsroom AI which would help us build current tools into end-to-end workflows, add a planning stream using AI agents, and rebuild the video workflow as this is where we are suffering most red currently.
Key Risks and Issues: We increasingly need a way to automatically evaluate LLM output both so that we can move more towards automation and also so that we can move more quickly when a new model or approach comes out. We have been trying this particularly in the translation workstream but current internal solutions like the Content Console are not fit for purpose at scale. We will be limited in how much we can move to AI if we cannot keep track of errors and automate some of the tracking.
Progress on Use Case this period:
FactGenie - We decided to reorder our roadmap to accelerate a path to full automation of current FactGenie input/output and to push back the addition of web-watching feeds into FactGenie as that was turning out to be more complex than imagined. Automation teams are working on improving accuracy (issues still with company names and currency symbols) and relevance (model is too slow currently). Webwatching team is parallel pathing to define potential solutions.
LEON - development of highlighting AI edits is complete and released to Translation users in the four romance languages. We are looking at potential UIs for the drafting work to capture inputs, prompts and output. The AI Enablement team is looking at CoCo-mini from TR to see if we can re-use the work done there (POC running in June). The drafting skills themselves are in PoC with a small group of journalists to monitor and refine with Labs. The new genAI translation editor CheckMATE is now active in the romance languages. Issues in ongoing evaluations (see below)
LAMP - All Reuters Ready English-language channels have now migrated to LAMP and the team has moved on to the Legal channels next for a total of 46 out of 110 channels now migrated. (GREEN)
AVISTA - We are trying an automated shotlist with a small group of producers as there are still issues around filler words like um, and issues around performance and speed. Still waiting to get synthetic voice contract signed (AMBER)
Details on Change Management:
We have launched our new Newsroom change management group, led by our programme manager together with training and comms. We have set up a group of AI Champions in Asia, which is often left out of discussions given time zone complexity and are starting to do much more focused workshops by team or workflow. In comms we are aiming to tell more peer-to-peer stories about how journalists are integrating AI into their daily lives through the W/AI Forward series of emails, a new bimonthly AI townhall and a monthly AI clinic which is open to all. We will also rethink our communications to be able to answer questions by the next set of adopters (eg how do I use AI to transcribe something). 
We are also integrating with the team running the wider Reuters transformation programme and have a general manager assigned to help with change management where people's jobs are being altered significantly and where roles may, in the future, no longer be needed. 
We have found there is a bigger piece of work to be done on change management to get people off legacy tools and into the tools where AI is integrated. There are some parity issues that still need to be done e.g. on LEON to encourage deeper adoption. Jonathan Leff's new role should help us capture and deal with those more quickly.
Path Forward:
FactGenie - Continue work on accuracy and relevance to move towards automation. Ongoing work to deliver content from webwatcher and automations services to FactGenie via a new system to link the pieces together. This will expand FactGenie beyond corporate news to political and economic news and will be a big step forward. (Delayed due to complexity, may need to rethink approach with AI agents)
LEON: Drafting - test CoCo-mini as a potential plug-in solution to manage inputs and output. Results of PoC due by end-June but we recognise the CoCo team has a lot on their plate. 
LAMP: Release remaining Legal channels into LAMP and complete training the models for Reuters Ready in Italian, French and Spanish. Improve some of the Asset Association based on Editorial feedback. Continue working on the final piece of the AI tooling which ranks stories according to importance, relevance and timeliness. Move on to Top News tool for LSEG's Workspace which is similar but slightly different.
Translation: Start to move on to the non-romance languages with Korean a priority for LSEG.
AVISTA: Start work on a much bigger solution that is not just trying to retrofit AVISTA into our Newsroom workflow but which rethinks the whole workflow and tooling set-up (this is dependent on EPC funding)
Questions / Assistance Needed from the W: Reupping Q about Deep Research/Operator if others are using them? Also are other groups looking at evaluations and LLM as a judge?

AI Use Cases: RFX Content/Analysis Optimization,Contract Analysis,Services Gateway,Spend Analysis
Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
1. CoCounsel 2.0 and CoCounsel Drafting Implementation: CoCounsel 2.0 was deployed in Q1. CoCounsel Drafting will be deployed by end of Q2-2025. Initial CoCounsel 2.0 training sessions were completed on February 25 and 27. The CoCounsel Drafting strategy includes potential integrations with Contract Express for templates automation and Practical Law for legal playbooks automation. Procurement is partnering with Procurement Legal to establish a cross-functional working group focused on identifying efficiency opportunities in contracting processes, with primary focus on document comparison capabilities. A kick-off session is scheduled for April 3 to align on approach, define key use cases, and develop a plan to test, validate, and cascade standard prompts through the Prompts Library. While initially focusing on document comparison in CoCounsel, we will explore other Thomson Reuters AI solutions for contracting processes.

2. RFP Template Generation MVP: The MVP for collaborative RFP Template generation has been successfully configured in Kronos V2, our Sourcing Projects Management solution. UAT was successfully completed in May , engaging Sourcing SMEs from the RFP Optimization program. Go-live is set for the last week of June, with plans to expand RFP Template automation throughout Q3.

3. Services Gateway Chatbot Development: Development will proceed using Copilot Studio (Ask TR) following evaluation of the 'TR Ask Julius' chatbot. The initial MVP focusing on Travel & Expenses process is configured in Copilot Studio. Licensing and usage costs were discussed with Jacob Walls and team on March 6. We agreed to incorporate our Procurement use cases as part of the broader Ask TR solution. Our first priority use case remains the Travel & Expenses assistant, which will integrate travel booking, corporate card services, expense management, and travel safety resources into a unified conversational interface based on our internal policies, FAQs and procedures. Additional potential Procurement function use cases were also discussed.
Key Risks and Issues:
- Complex system integration risks: Integrating the AI solutions with existing systems, databases, and workflows.​
- User Adoption and change management risks: Resistance to change or difficulties in understanding and using the new solution could hinder project success.​
- Technical risk: Algorithm complexity could delay or impact the effectiveness of the solution."

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
Latam team has been included on the Gong Pilot until the end of the year. It was necessary additional alignments within the provider to understand what capabilities we should expect to test since not all the functionalities will be available since we are not going to connect Gong with the local CRMs we have in the Region. ​

The decision was made to move forward with the pilot without having additional projects being required and test only the functionalities that are available in this model.
Key Risks and Issues:
During the first discussions of the pilot, we’ve identified that Gong cannot connect the same instance of the tool with difference SFDC instances. Since Latam users are on S2E SFDC instance or SGD as their CRMs, we needed to understand the capabilities / options to be considered under the pilot scope before moving forward. ​

We explored the different options for your Gong implementation, including setting up a new instance, using the existing GSI Salesforce instance, or waiting for another time. ​

We reviewed a comparison matrix of Gong features that would be available under each option, highlighting the limitations of the existing GSI instance in terms of account-based functionality. ​

We will need to have a local person trained by the Gong team due to language limitation, with that our launch will be postponed, since there is the need of a new SOW for the train the trainer program.

Executive Summary:
The GCO is exploring all of the below:
Contract Review and Compliance: AI to be utilized for reviewing contracts to ensure compliance, manage obligations, and redline third-party NDAs against policies. Bulk contract reviews are being tested using CoCounsel High Volume.
Automation of Legal Processes: AI to automate tasks such as drafting correspondence for breaches of terms, creating chronologies of events from documents, and sending intake requests to HighQ, saving time and improving accuracy.
Self-Service Information Access: Chatbots are being tested across Practice Groups to provide self-serve business information. 
Enhancements in Legal Tracker: Working with the Legal Tracker product team to leverage AI for budgeting, reporting, and duplicate line-item reviews in invoices.

Compliance and Legal Risks: Concerns also include ensuring alignment between procurement and legal teams and addressing anomalies in contract negotiations.
Workflow Efficiency Risks: Challenges in leveraging AI for email workflows and timeline creation.
Contract Management Risks: Risks include inaccuracies in extracting contract data, automating contract templates, and redlining capabilities. Ensuring comprehensive playbook development and addressing non-negotiables in contract clauses are critical focus areas.

Executive Summary:
Talent Acquisition continues to advance multiple AI initiatives with measurable progress. The LinkedIn Hiring Assistant pilot with 20 recruiters has successfully generated 12 hires, while BrightHire pilot testing remains active pending Workday integration. The Open Arena-powered AI Recruiter Summary tool is live but experiencing low adoption rates, prompting a review of user feedback to enhance questioning capabilities and response generation. HiredScore exploration continues with the business case under finance and digital team review since April.

HR Services has achieved significant milestones across three key areas. Content Management & Experience completed governance tool demos and incorporated Workday Governance team feedback into taxonomy proposals, while developing approaches for Atrium navigation optimization. Global HR Services successfully moved key case management enhancements to production and completed current state analysis for DIS centralization with team training underway. HRX Regional HR established project scope and roadmap with a core team kickoff planned for June 2025.

Communications expanded AI experimentation significantly, completing testing on 27 use cases across multiple tools (Open Arena, Copilot, DAVE AI, Signal AI, Appreciate AI) with 10 additional cases in pipeline. The team gained DAVE AI access and is planning training sessions while continuously refining the communications prompt library for global team use. Chain creation in Open Arena is progressing for executive messaging and communications planning applications.

Other AI Experimentation encompasses diverse initiatives showing varied progress. My AI Coach is preparing for mid-year check-in launch to support performance conversations, while Talent Highlights remains on hold due to eligibility restrictions affecting 62% of employees until Workday's 2026R1 solution. CoCounsel expanded with 30 new HR users trained, and Copilot achieved 6,700+ interactions in May with all 78 PCSI licenses actively utilized. Workday illuminate now supports 17 task assistants in production, demonstrating significant case volume reduction potential based on customer success stories.
Key Risks and Issues:
Talent Acquisition faces technical and adoption challenges that could impact timeline delivery. Data privacy and CIO support confirmation for BrightHire's Workday production integration remains pending. Heavy reliance on capacity-constrained internal technical partners for AI Concept Hub development and Digital HR implementations poses delivery risks. Additionally, typical recruiter adoption patterns suggest months-long integration periods for new tools to become part of daily workflows.

HR Services encounters operational and coordination risks across workstreams. Content Management & Experience must address article naming mismatches with attached PDFs requiring correction. Global HR Services faces potential workload and efficiency impacts if implementation changes aren't executed smoothly. HRX Regional HR anticipates possible delays in role-based task analysis completion due to competing priorities, though clear project kickoff expectations aim to mitigate this risk.

Communications experiences resource allocation and priority management challenges. Delivery pressures create reluctance to interrupt current work for testing alternative approaches, while critical priorities consistently take precedence over AI workstream activities. Time constraints and competing demands limit experimentation capacity and tool adoption rates.

Talent Acquisition maintains comprehensive communication and training strategies across multiple channels. Continuous messaging on AI use cases occurs through AI Explorers supplementing All Hands meetings, individual team sessions, and Recruiting Collective Teams communications. Bi-weekly TA Office Hours provide dedicated forums for AI application sharing and Q&A sessions. Each rollout and pilot receives individual launch treatment with associated communication and training programs to ensure proper adoption.

HR Services employs stakeholder-focused engagement strategies tailored to each workstream. Content Management & Experience engages governance framework subject matter experts on their roles for building Workday and Atrium governance policies. Global HR Services conducts stakeholder meetings and shares executive summaries to align goals while actively involving GHS team members in discovery, validation, and testing phases. The approach includes training and upskilling initiatives to support team adaptation. HRX Regional HR engaged leadership teams to increase workstream visibility and identified the need for coordinated change management strategies with GHS due to interdependencies.

Communications builds upon 2024 foundations while addressing identified challenges. The team established four key focus areas (Content Development, Communications Planning, Sentiment Analysis, Translations) carried into 2025, adding Data Analysis and Workflow Enhancement Tools. Change management leverages existing touchpoints including AI as recurring All Hands agenda topics and weekly communications meeting demos. Key challenges include highly skilled teams delivering administrative tasks traditionally and limited AI usage in data gathering and analysis, addressed through updated prompt libraries and accessible global team resources.
Path Forward:
Talent Acquisition will focus on driving adoption of existing tools while expanding capabilities. Priority actions include monitoring AI Recruiter Summary adoption through targeted messaging, completing LinkedIn Hiring Assistant implementation and pilot monitoring, and finalizing HiredScore evaluation alongside Workday renewal discussions. Development of intake session recording and summarization tools will enhance recruiter efficiency.

HR Services will advance multiple strategic initiatives across all workstreams. Content Management & Experience will confirm taxonomy with portfolio leads, showcase governance tools to leadership, and develop business proposals for Workday content access optimization and Atrium user experience improvements. Global HR Services will review security roles and case routing patterns for consolidation while realigning Workday access for DIS work integration. HRX Regional HR will complete role-based task analysis, assess regional function transitions, and identify automation opportunities and appropriate role placements.

Communications will continue systematic testing and evaluation while expanding tool adoption. Key priorities include testing video creation using Adobe Express, strategizing Q2 task execution, and enhancing AI awareness across communications teams. The team will identify additional AI applications across Thomson Reuters, leverage training opportunities for existing tools, refine usage and productivity measurement methodology, and share best practices through town halls and office hours.

Other AI Experimentation will focus on optimization and expansion of successful initiatives. AI Coaching will refresh 2025 roadmap, address user feedback, and develop sustainable testing strategies. AI Use Cases: Agent Knowledge: Einstein Knowledge workflow,Agent Productivity: Salesforce Einstein Gen AI replies and summarization,Agent Productivity: Service Cloud (Salesforce) Voice,Customer Self-Service: WhatsApp Support for LatAm,Internal Productivity: Customer to Cash,Internal Productivity: Help and Support Content Acceleration
Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
The update highlights several impactful initiatives aimed at enhancing AI and customer service. Key efforts include the rollout of Service Cloud Voice for Customer Service and an expansion plan in August for Product Support and Reference Attorneys. The WhatsApp AI Self-Service Tool in Latin America is maintaining high engagement and automation, achieving a 34% call deflection rate and resolving 50% of requests without human intervention. The C2C initiative on Customer Queries is under ongoing investigation, including a potential proof of concept with Google.
The Intelligent Assistant continues to advance with new internal search capabilities and upcoming product additions, alongside the late-stage rollout of Salesforce Sherlock, which aims to improve case resolution speed for agents. Concurrently, the Help and Support Content Team is preparing for a transition to Adobe AEM Cloud and exploring the possibility of enlisting agents to expedite article creation and management while leveraging AI for content updates.
Financially, the organization remains on track to achieve its $1.8 million FY 2025 savings goal, supported by AI-driven efficiencies and a reduction of 49 FTEs. CXD’s adoption of AI tools is climbing, with 56.6% of employees regularly using generative AI as of May, and engagement boosted by newsletters and a new innovation hub. Efforts continue to address limitations in AI knowledge tools—such as improving content categorization for Salesforce and broadening data access—while monitoring the substantial productivity benefits of MSFT 365 Copilot. Collectively, these strategies reflect a coordinated drive toward greater efficiency, innovation, and future readiness.
Key Risks and Issues:
Effectiveness of our AI knowledge tools is being impacted by several issues.
Issue:  Help and Support content was written for web presentation to customers and is not categorized in a way that Salesforce understands, leading to inefficiencies in search and in some cases resulting in incorrect articles being returned by Einstein
Mitigation: Implement a robust categorization system that aligns with Salesforce's requirements. Enhance search functionalities by making filters sticky and improving the initial global search results. Regularly review and update the categorization to ensure it remains effective

Issue:  Intelligent Assistant and Salesforce Einstein are exclusively limited to knowledge articles and do not utilize other data sources in their AI grounding.  This restricts the range of accessible information as 1) migration of knowledge articles to AEM Guides is not yet complete, resulting in gaps within the knowledge base and 2) doesn’t leverage other possible sources like Salesforce and Flash cases and Flash cases
Mitigation: Complete the migration process by reviewing, categorizing, and publishing all articles in AEM Guides. Explore configurations to enable Salesforce Einstein and Intelligent Assistant to access other data sources like Salesforce cases and Flash cases, thereby enhancing the knowledge base
Progress on Use Case this period:
"Intelligent Assistant
•	The Intelligent Assistant post-peak usage rates have declined with call volume although feedback on content accuracy continues to be positive.  Internal article search functionality on track for late Q2 delivery.  Checkpoint products to be added in Q3.
 Sherlock
•	Salesforce Sherlock  an AI-powered search enhancement to surface top case resolutions in Salesforce to accelerate agent support, is in late testing with the goal to have training complete for all OIT/GST agents in July and using the tool by August 1.
Service Cloud Voice
•	Service Cloud Voice was successfully deployed to Customer Service teams on April 25th, alongside Einstein Next Best Actions.
•	The Q2 Service Cloud Voice deployment for Product Support teams is progressing as scheduled, with ongoing kick-offs involving Product Support leadership teams.
WhatsApp AI Self-Service Tool
•	Call deflection for the WhatsApp-based AI self-service tool in the LatAm region increase to 34% (-3pp m/m) in June.
•	50% (-1pp m/m) of requests were resolved without human interaction, maintaining efficiency levels observed in April. Early abandoned steady at 15%, indicating stable customer engagement.
•	GSI/Open Arena Integration: Implemented. This integration provides the agents with a formatted solution for every case opened in GSI. Positive feedbacks form agents, KPIs under construction
Help and Support Content Team
•	Transition to Adobe's cloud solution (AEM Cloud) planned for January 2026. This multi-tenant migration is being carefully managed to ensure a smooth process.
•	Work is underway to evaluate AI tools offered by Adobe for identifying relevant knowledge base articles for updates. Preliminary analysis confirms that Adobe's functionality will suffice, providing faster authoring and publishing capabilities post-migration.
•	Efforts are underway to investigate acceleration improvements for identifying and updating knowledge base articles, aiming to enhance workflows and efficiency ahead of the cloud migration planned for January 2026.
C2C Initiatives
•	UI/Suspense Payment Application: Deployment continues to automate payment matching with AI and bots, reallocating balances to correct accounts. The initiative has reduced cases by 50%. Having expanded to the ANZ, UK, and Ireland regions in May, further deployments are on hold due to developer bandwidth.
•	C2C Customer Queries: The initiative uses large language models (LLMs) to predict customer inquiries, improving resolution times from 5 days to 2 in 80% of cases. Now handling around 25,000 queries monthly, the project team is now focused on phase 2 that will create workflows for the AI agent to automate responses to selected queries.  Initial meeting with Google to discuss a POC for a customer agent to address."
Details on Change Management:
The pathway to achieve the 2025 savings target continues to be tracked through quarterly forecasting. Through May, CS&S is on track to achieve FY 2025 savings of $1.8M, steady m/m - actual reduction was 49 FTEs with a 2025 savings value of $1.3M.  Quarterly plan will be updated for June.
CXD has adopted the TR Enterprise AI OKR ensuring 50% of CXD employees are using Gen AI tools regularly as part of their daily task.  In May  56.6% of CXD employees used AI tools regularly (+ 6.6 pp m/m increase).  We expect this number to continue to rise naturally as we deploy additional AI tools across our CSS agent population the year and use our AI communication channels to promote AI learning opportunities and share innovative and inspiring ways our colleagues are using AI in their day-to-day work.  

2025 AI Communications plan is being executed. The AI Spark: AI Innovation in CXD newsletter (launched in April) continues to have an average open rate of 76% across ~2,300 recipients through May.

The CXD InnovAItion Hub to capture and govern AI ideas across CXD launched on June 23rd and has captured ~20 new ideas in the first week.

Demand for MSFT  365 Copilot licenses remains high as groups find Copilot has proven to be an invaluable tool in streamlining our daily operations. Usage of these licenses is being monitored and remains very high with underutilized licenses being recycled.  MSFT reporting shows an average savings of 22 hours per CXD Copilot user in H1 2025.
Path Forward:
• Intelligent Assistant Expansion: Addition of internal content slated for Q3.  Data analysis to more deeply understand the impact of the too underway.  Increased engagement by providing usage data to managers.
• Service Cloud Voice Deployment:  August deployment of Salesforce Voice planned for Reference Attorneys and Product Support group.  Preparation and trianing is underway.
• Help and Support Content: Transition to Adobe's cloud solution (AEM Cloud) to improve knowledge base article management and publishing. Evaluate AI tools to enhance content relevance and authoring efficiency.  Agents enslited to accelerate content creation forGST/OIT in preparation for fall peak, on track to create 800 new articles.
• C2C Initiatives: Expand the UI/Suspense Payment Application and Customer Queries initiatives to additional regions, with a focus on automating payment matching and reducing resolution times to improve efficiency and customer satisfaction.
• AI Knowledge Tools: Address inefficiencies by implementing a robust categorization system and enabling broader data source access for Salesforce Einstein and Intelligent Assistant to enhance the knowledge base.
• AI Adoption and Savings Targets: Continue to promote AI tool usage among CXD employees to achieve the 2025 savings target of $1.8M and achieve Active Use OKR.
• AI Communications and Idea Space: Execute the 2025 AI Communications plan, maximize the Idea Space tool to capture and govern AI ideas across CXD, monitor impact of MSFT 365 Copilot licenses to streamline daily operations.

AI Use Cases: Product Requirements Document (PRD) Assistant - Product Managers,ADO User Story - Product Managers,ADO Epic - Product Managers,ADO Feature - Product Managers,Release Notes Generator - Product Managers,ADO Agent Workflow - Product Managers,No Code Prototyping Tool - Product Managers,Centralized Customer Insights - Product Managers,Business Case to Product Delivery Workflow - Product Managers,EPC Investments Tracking - Product Managers,Roadmapper - Product Managers,QBR Automate - Product Managers,Product Info Bot - Product Managers,User Experience Deep Research,Prototyping+ / UI Vibecoding,Github Copilot Agent Assisted Development,Centralized IP - Design,TaxLaw2Code (ADO) – Tax Research (Content),Release Notes AI Creation - Tax Research (Content) ,Modernize iDesign Development Tool - Tax Research (Content)
Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary: Additional use cases identified and underway for Product Management, Product Design, and Tax Research Content. Will continue to assess scope/usage and perform tests and experiments into second half of 2025.  Will assess financial savings in Q3/Q4 2025.
Key Risks and Issues:
RISK: Dynamic nature of product management role and activity, based on outcomes rather than outputs, make harder to find one single metric that can be utilized to single out efficiency gains by using AI. While we see the adoption of AI in these roles, it’s harder to estimate impact only based on time-savings dimension.
RISK: Also connected with the above, there are limited specific AI tools for Product Managers, and some may even increase complexity or force strict processes. While we evaluate options to implement a no-code prototyping tool or product management system, our current hypothesis is that generic tools (like Copilot / AI Platform Open Arena) might be best suited for the role – and we may create specific prompts or agents for the specific use cases that we target.
Progress on Use Case this period:
Five Product Manager use cases are being tracked in Launch stage, three in the Experimentation stage, and five in Ideation stage to be integrated into the product management workflow in support of the Product Operating Model. Product Requirements Document (PRD) Assistant and ADO User Story Builder, ADO Epic & Feature Builder, and Release Notes Generator are Launched, all leveraging both Open Arena and Copilot Chat Agent tools promoted on the Atrium, to the Innovation Team, and Product Manager Copilot license holders for feedback. 

Product Design continued AI-assisted prototyping experiments focusing on the “Prototyping+” use case. In mid-June, the team kicked off an active discovery with Vercel’s v0 tool, including onboarding and training sessions spanning design, engineering, product management, as well the Tax Frisco Summer intern program. This culminated in presentations by high school interns using v0 for the first time as well as an internal hackathon-style evaluation where cross-functional teams rapidly built high-fidelity prototypes using natural language prompts building working prototypes 6x faster. The Prototyping+ pilot continues into July with a larger evaluator cohort. Results from this trial (e.g. survey feedback, prototype examples, time-savings metrics) will inform a recommendation on AI-Assisted Prototyping+ tool adoption for Product Design. The design research function made strides in using AI to accelerate user experience (UX) research. In June, the team operationalized this capability and began measuring its adoption and impact.

In Product Content, we developed the requirements for the TaxLaw2Code project for analyzing differences and will begin the design work for creating ADO tickets automatically from the annotations. In addition, the Lead Tax Analysts are using Materia in their tax research. Finally, we have hired in May an AI Program Manager to identify all use cases, prioritize based on impact, and work towards implementation.  In June, we held an AI workshop with AWS to refine the requirements for TaxLaw2Code. Beyond the structured outcomes, the workshop yielded valuable, unexpected benefits. Participants experienced strengthened relationships and the deep satisfaction of achieving alignment. This human interaction is crucial for true transformation, fostering trust and a shared sense of purpose that extends beyond the official goals of the workshop.
Details on Change Management: Product Management, Design and Tax Research are focused on engagement for product manager and design-focused solutions via comms, Atrium page and Viva Engage community launch, Innovation Teams, office hours, AI solution and tools focused trainings, and expansion of Copilot license activation and promotion.
Path Forward:
Product Management path forward is to enhance existing AI solutions via Open Arena models and Copilot capabilities, while continuing innovation discovery and experimentation toward development of new use cases following the Product Operating Model, and in parallel exploring external AI-prototyping tools to be included in upcoming "future of product management" trials, in collaboration with Design and Product Engineering cross-functional partners.

Product Design’s path forward is to continue advancing experimentation with a focus on business-aligned pilots for early adopters across the organization, prioritizing the selection of a strategic AI-assisted prototyping tool—v0, Lovable, or Figma Make—by Q3.

For Tax Research (Content), we are working on Phase II of TaxLaw2Code in Q3 with the creation of ADO tickets with user story requirements. In addition, we are working to secure an AI Engineer resource to allow for work to begin on Phase III which will allow recommendations to be rendered to Analyst on the needed changes to logic.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary: Adoption of AI-powered development tools is steadily increasing, with 61% of engineers now using them at least once—a 13% rise over the previous month. In addition to GitHubCoPilot and AmazonQ,  new tools such as Cursor, Cline, and Claude Code have been widely rolled out, alongside ongoing enhancements in telemetry and onboarding processes. Enablement initiatives, including the TechBytes session (650+ participants) and HerTechQuest hackathon (350+ participants), have driven strong engagement across the organization. Additionally, the new AI-Powered Dev Tools self-help assistant has been launched to provide easy access to information and training resources.
Key Risks and Issues:
1. Cline offers potential for faster code development, but carries risks of IP loss and harm to TR systems. To mitigate these, we propose limiting use to internal LLMs, employing development containers for isolation, and implementing robust auditing.
You can find guidelines here: https://trten.sharepoint.com/sites/intr-isrm-business-and-product-security/SitePages/Securing-the-AI-coding-tool-chain.aspx
2.  Developer surveys indicate that while AI can suggest boilerplate code, it lacks the ability to ideate or strategize. Therefore, it is crucial to maintain a human in the loop for editing and guiding the output of AI, rather than relying on it solely as a source of output.
Progress on Use Case this period:
1. Our engineering community is using Viva Engage actively.  Posts with short demos and everything related to AI-powered dev tools are available via AI-Powered Tools Topic: https://engage.cloud.microsoft/main/org/tr.com/topics/eyJfdHlwZSI6IlRvcGljIiwiaWQiOiJFVF9mNjhmOWZkNS05MWJiLTRlMTMtYWNmYy04ODVmNTgyNThhYmMifQ/all
2. The CIO team had identified a few issues with GHCP under usage reporting. Some of the issues got addressed with new API from GitHub, some others are  currently investigated
3. The second version of Tech Bytes: Unlock the power of AI Agents, happened on June 17th and covered: what AI Agents are, when to use them (instead of traditional workflows or RPA), and how to build them responsibly and effectively. More than 650 engineers attended the session.  The guidelines, the presentation from the session, and the recording are available on the TechBytes Atrium site. - https://trten.sharepoint.com/sites/intr-distinguished-engineer/SitePages/TechBytes.aspx?
4. HerTechQuest 3.0 was held on June 12th in Bangalore, Hyderabad, and Ahmedabad, with participants leveraging AI-powered tools: CLINE and GitHub CoPilot, for the creation of innovative solutions. The event saw 350 participants, mostly from Engineering, with positive feedback about the overall experience and mentor support. Read more on the outcome on Viva Engage - https://engage.cloud.microsoft/main/org/tr.com/search?search=hertechquest&type=threads
5. The AI-Powered Dev Tools Assistant is introduced —a new resource to answer your questions about AI-powered developer tools. Get help with available tools, access and setup, best practices, training resources, and connecting with experts.-https://dataandanalytics.int.thomsonreuters.com/ai-platform/ai-chains/use/290f7d77-a720-4e72-b393-276070a65378?sidebar=settings ( access with ZScaler) 
6. To mitigate some of the potential risks with Cline (mentioned in Key Risk and Issues), we rolled out LiteLLM that allows access to TR-approved LLMs. There is a Short Practical Guide to Using Cline that helps engineers start using Cline in a simple and secure way:https://trten.sharepoint.com/sites/intr-distinguished-engineer/SitePages/A-Short-Practical-Guide-to-Using-Cline.aspx
Details on Change Management: None
Path Forward: We provide both open-source and licensed, commercial tools for developers to improve productivity, coding efficiency and developer experience, and measure usage and trends across these tools.

AI Use Cases: Fact extraction and summarisation with FactGenie,Translation to journalistic standards,Video Editing
Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
As we wrap up the first half of 2025, we are looking at whether we start to run down some of our workstreams into BAU - and what BAU looks like in an AI world, including tracking model drift, prompt performance and tracking where AI has been used in production. We are also planning for late 25 and into 2026 to make sure that we stay ahead in the use of AI for news both in our own newsroom and in our products and are hoping to plan against EPC news this month. Main areas of focus will be use of agentic architecture for faster iteration and video. 
Where we have slowed down in our workstreams, the main reason has been misalignment between Editorial's expectations and the way Product has interpreted it. We need to rethink product development in an era of AI given what is now possible with an end user vibe coding a solution vs integration in to approved and maintained systems and processes. We need to retro not just what we have produced but now how we are producing it. 
Our change management training and support has ramped up a gear across June and we hope to see a positive change in the adoption numbers when they come out.
Key Risks and Issues:
Evaluations are still worrying us a lot. Who is doing interesting work in this elsewhere in TR? 
We plan to use Coco-mini for some of our drafting and RAG solutions and will need to work out responsibilities across TR and Reuters teams to ensure smooth deployment and future development, knowing that Reuters will be a smaller internal customer fighting for air time against major external legal customers. 
Are there any plug and play agentic solutions being built elsewhere in TR that we can learn from?
Progress on Use Case this period:
FactGenie - We hit the goal of 40% of our published alerts coming from FactGenie! Work ongoing to move towards more automation of alerting without pre-publication human checks and also to add non-corporate disclosure feeds to the LLM-based snapping solution. 
LEON - The Product team has decided to move ahead with CoCo-mini for drafting and RAG prototypes. There is a lot of work to do with the TR AI Platform team to get this working and establish the correct procedures for maintenance, ongoing development etc. 
LAMP - We are starting to roll out the non-English packaging products in LAMP. However we have hit two snags on non Reuters Ready packaging, particularly the Top News packaging we do for LSEG and sports packaging we do for third party content. Those two snags are RED and AMBER while all Reuters Ready is GREEN
Translation - Bedding down CheckMATE (the gen AI editing prompt) in the romance languages. Picky journalists are never happy with outcomes so some extra tweaking needed on prompt and potentially the model. Next step is to focus on Korean and Arabic as well as German and Turkish. 
AVISTA - Awaiting read out from small group of producers testing Avista as a scripting tool. Synthetic voice contract signed at the end of June and we will report on first results at the end of July.
Details on Change Management: There has been a lot of buzz on change management since the increased adoption goal to 100%. Our Newsroom change management group is ramping up (although will be slowed down a bit by summer holidays). We have now appointed a Newsroom AI Editor (Rob Lang) who will also be helping people at grass roots level. He held a hackathon for eight journalists in late June which proved both that there are ideas we can be solving using vibe coding tools like Cline but also that we need help from technology and product to shape the prototypes into something workable - and critically somewhere to run the programmes (an OpenArena for code)
Path Forward:
FactGenie - Continue work on accuracy and relevance to move towards full automation as well as expanding the funnel of incoming information - non corporate, social media etc. 
LEON: Drafting - work out integration plan for CoCo-mini as the core drafting interface. 
LAMP: Press on with release of non-English Reuters Ready and speed up solution for Top News and Sports packaging. Roll out story ranking (less of a priority than the others)
Translation: Evaluation is still a tricky task given the subjectivity of translation. We need to get a better balance between SMEs and a new objective measure of excellence. Next languages - Korean a priority for LSEG.
AVISTA: Start work on a much bigger solution that is not just trying to retrofit AVISTA into our Newsroom workflow but which rethinks the whole workflow and tooling set-up (this is dependent on EPC funding)
Questions / Assistance Needed from the W: Reupping Q about Deep Research/Operator if others are using them? Also are other groups looking at evaluations and LLM as a judge? Adding an ask for help finding examples of using Agents in internal processes.

The session focused on showcasing interesting new chains, new websearch on Arena and advertised champion program for Commercial teams as well as presented learnings from Reuters Events champions. During the call we run a few surveys, and our findings are:
•	70% claim to use AI tools daily or multiple times day, and 26% don’t get any barriers in using AI.

We will continue promoting relevant use cases with tools available as well as keep on educating about AI limitations and best practices; this should help address some of the challenges mentioned. We're launching the AI champion program in July, which will combine both active participation (driving own/group projects) as well as more passive (education etc.) giving champions the foundation to be active AI tools users and developers.

AI Use Cases: RFX Content/Analysis Optimization,Contract Analysis,Services Gateway,Spend Analysis
Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
1. CoCounsel 2.0 and CoCounsel Drafting Implementation: CoCounsel 2.0 was deployed in Q1. CoCounsel Drafting will be deployed by the end of Q3-2025.

The CoCounsel Drafting strategy includes potential integrations with Contract Express for template automation and Practical Law for legal playbook automation. Procurement is partnering with Procurement Legal to establish a cross-functional working group focused on identifying efficiency opportunities in contracting processes, with primary focus on document comparison capabilities.

2. RFP Template Generation MVP: The MVP for collaborative RFP template generation has been successfully configured in Kronos V2, our Sourcing Projects Management solution. UAT was successfully completed in May, engaging Sourcing SMEs from the RFP Optimization program. Go-live is set for the last week of June, with plans to expand RFP template automation throughout Q3. Now, with our expertise in Copilot Studio, we are brainstorming on how to scale the solution for RFP analysis and generation, providing more value.

3. Services Gateway Chatbot Development: This development will be split into separate AI agents, starting with the deployment of our Travel & Expenses agent in July. We are currently creating our internal governance model for AI agents and compiling a list of potential use cases to be developed through Q3-H1 2026.
Key Risks and Issues:
- Complex system integration risks: Integrating the AI solutions with existing systems, databases, and workflows.​
- User Adoption and change management risks: Resistance to change or difficulties in understanding and using the new solution could hinder project success.​
- Technical risk: Algorithm complexity could delay or impact the effectiveness of the solution."
Progress on Use Case this period: In   H1, Services achieved 65% utilization of key AI tools (CoCounsel V2, OpenArena, MS Copilot), with CoCounsel V2 reaching 53% adoption among Sourcing and Supplier & Contract Managers, contributing with use cases and opportunities to the Client Zero strategy. An AI Agent for T&E FAQs built in Copilot Studio is set for July pilot while Q3-Q4 plans include CoCounsel Drafting rollout alongside scaled OpenArena capabilities, Copilot Chat, and expanded AI Agents across E2E Procurement and REFM. We are also benchmarking AI use cases in Procurement across our industry peers with a view to further expand GenAI utilization and automation to additional areas.
Details on Change Management:
CoCounsel (Next Steps):
•	CoCounsel Core 2.0 Rollout: Phased upgrades through the end of 2025 as they become available.
•	Explore and deploy CoCounsel Drafting . We are in the process of aligning a dedicated training session for our team, which will dive deeper into the platform's features and integration with MS Word. We'll share more details as soon as they are available.

Efficient RFx Analysis
•	Run a formal User Acceptance Testing (UAT) for the Minimum Viable Product (MVP) of collaborative RFP Template generation deployed in Kronos, involving Sourcing SMEs from the RFP Optimization program to validate capabilities and fine-tune the solution.
Path Forward:
Further Integration and Training:
•	Continue and expand training sessions for AI tools such as CoCounsel Drafting and CoCounsel V2.0 and Copilot Studio to ensure full adoption and effective usage.
•	Develop standardized training materials and prompt libraries to support consistent use and efficiency.

Business Case Development:
•	Finalize and approve the business case for broader access to AI tools.
•	Develop additional business cases to secure incremental investments for AI initiatives.

Metrics and KPIs Refinement:
•	Implement newly defined impact-focused KPIs to better track productivity and efficiency gains.
•	Regularly review and adjust metrics to ensure alignment with business outcomes and strategic goals.

Communication and Showcasing:
•	Prepare for upcoming staff and all-hands meetings to showcase AI progress and demonstrate tangible benefits.
•	Highlight success stories and measurable impacts to reinforce the value of AI adoption.

Cultural Change and Leadership Engagement:
•	Continue addressing cultural resistance by involving leaders in planning and decision-making processes.
•	Foster a positive reinforcement environment to encourage leadership support for AI initiatives.

Ongoing Support and Evaluation:
•	Provide continuous support to teams using AI tools and address any challenges promptly.
Regularly evaluate the progress of AI initiatives and adjust strategies as needed to ensure successful adoption and value capture.

AI Use Cases: Gong
Overall Status: Amber - Delay/Risk/Challenges
Executive Summary:
Latam team has been included on the Gong Pilot until the end of the year. It was necessary additional alignments within the provider to understand what capabilities we should expect to test since not all the functionalities will be available since we are not going to connect Gong with the local CRMs we have in the Region. ​

The decision was made to move forward with the pilot without having additional projects being required and test only the functionalities that are available in this model.
Key Risks and Issues:
During the first discussions of the pilot, we’ve identified that Gong cannot connect the same instance of the tool with difference SFDC instances. Since Latam users are on S2E SFDC instance or SGD as their CRMs, we needed to understand the capabilities / options to be considered under the pilot scope before moving forward. ​

We explored the different options for your Gong implementation, including setting up a new instance, using the existing GSI Salesforce instance, or waiting for another time. ​

We reviewed a comparison matrix of Gong features that would be available under each option, highlighting the limitations of the existing GSI instance in terms of account-based functionality. ​

We will need to have a local person trained by the Gong team due to language limitation, with that our launch will be postponed, since there is the need of a new SOW for the train the trainer program.
Progress on Use Case this period:
Licenses were sent to all 10 users.​

The Train the trainer session was held on December 3rd. ​

We will now translate the training material and schedule local session in Portuguese and Spanish.​

Gong integration with Genesys was confirmed. ​

We have confirmed that we need to get consentient from the Customers, so the ‘opt in” option to record the call must be configured.

We have cretaed the business case for approval, it is under review.

Submit and Get approval on Business case.

We're looking to build a holistic program around AI that will include a monthly email newsletter to everyone in Corporates, an intro meeting with all the managers including a roadshow with each of the sales managers, a bi-weekly office hours for all that wants to attend, and an Idea-a-thon for sales to build a best-in-class prompt library
Key Risks and Issues:
'1. Not enough Copilot licenses for everyone that wants one. Including our rep that handles the Microsoft account!
2. Friction in getting Gong adopted (lots of steps to setup a call, customers not willing to give consent to be recorded, etc)
3. Collaborative forecasting capabilities not robust enough at the moment for full adoption, waiting on phase 2 enhancements
4. Not getting enough data to be ingested by our internal AI tools to help the field (i.e. Seismic data in Copilot Studio)
Progress on Use Case this period:
Collaborative Forecasting and Gong was rolled out to Corporates in late May/early June. We're still working through some early implementation troubles in order to get the tools fully adopted by our field. 

Due to hierarchy issues, Revenue Intelligence rollout was delayed until mid-July and Path to Plan is delayed to late July.

Corporates Command Center (taking a page out of LP's franchise playbook) was rolled out to all the leaders within Corporates in May. CC is a collection of the main dashboards that the leaders use to run their business. Access requires CRMA license and we've worked through a number of license shortage issues so far.

Corporates have 5 massive playbooks on the Atrium site as a one stop shop for our sellers to learn about all they need to know to effectively sell our products. As expected, the playbooks are too heavy for reps to consume so the Enablement team built the Enablement Navigator chatbot in Copilot Studio for front line employees to query the chatbot for their sales questions. So far, the chatbot was released to select people on the front lines and it's been receiving great reviews. We're looking for more content for this chatbot to consume, including content that's loaded in Seismic, and any internal documentation on driving a deal through our various systems.
Details on Change Management: Working closely with CE on Gong and Collaborative Forecast adoption. Developing playbooks for new tech rollout
Path Forward:
Coming into July, we will look to recycle our Copilot licenses to those that have requested licenses as well as ways to get more licenses. 

We'll continue to drive adoption for our recently implemented AI tools and address some of the challenges facing current adoption (no actuals in Collaborative Forecasting, call setup friction with Gong, etc)

I need some guidance and help on what content to present in terms of our internal AI tools and go forward strategy with these tools to point the team in the right direction. I would also like to learn more about RAG capabilities and see how we can utilize this in Corporates.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary: The GCO is actively piloting AI across several legal functions, both in day to day one-off work queries/projects and turning the focus to more scalable use cases. In partnership with the Customer Success team and other internal support that we received in July, we are focusing on three use cases for a sprint: (a) CoCounsel Playbooks – Test with C&C, Procurement and Privacy, as they are looking at it from buy side and sell side (and then Privacy needs additional support in terms of DPA for example on both sides (though bulk upload and sharing features are not yet supported); (b) CoCounsel High Volume – Using HV to (a) review post-acquisition contracts for non-negotiables; (b) review existing contracts for non-negotiables; and (c) in eDiscovery for active litigation; and (c) Chatbot Powered by Knowledge Search or Search a Database – Involve C&C, CoSec (KYC chatbot rather than entities) and M&A (antitrust advice). Separately, we are doing a real-time test of a use case where we review an NDA using CoCounsel CPC (Version 1.0). Some use cases are awaiting product skills on the product roadmap to be available. In Legal Tracker, AI is being explored for budgeting and reporting, while integration with HighQ is still facing technical hurdles.
Key Risks and Issues:
Technology Integration Risks: Integration challenges persist, particularly with CoCounsel and HighQ. The Legal Tracker and HighQ Integration initiative remains at risk, with ongoing troubleshooting of issues. Also, tech stack issues, sharing Playbooks to other registration keys within a single organization.
Change Management: For a wider use of the Playbook function, will need other stakeholders onboard and will need to be aligned on change management efforts to ensure consistency in contract terms and ongoing compliance.
Workflow Efficiency Risks: AI support for email workflows remains a challenge. Timeline creation automation too, indicating current limitations in extracting and structuring event chronologies from documents.
Contract Management Risks: While NDA automation shows progress, the workflow is being run on CPC Version 1.0, as there is key functionality missing in Version 2.0.
Progress on Use Case this period: Progress was made in July with the support of the Customer Zero team.
Details on Change Management: We continue to actively manage change management initiatives, including having AI Champions in each GCO segment, training campaigns on various internal AI offerings and skills and highlighting use case successes at Townhalls. We continue to look for opportunities to do additional training and have been provided internal Change Management resources for when a larger implementation of an AI use case is ready.
Path Forward: Continue scoping of use cases with each practice group and testing as and when ready and other internal support that we received in July.
Questions / Assistance Needed from the W: Assistance needed flagged in June and additional resources provided.

The internal comms team is now training DAVE AI with curated content and has completed a retrospective review to identify opportunity areas, with plans in place to shift from a linear to an accelerated rollout for use cases.

The BrightHire pilot was extended, and LinkedIn Hiring Assistant is in active pilot, yielding 17 hires to date. The Open Arena-powered AI Recruiter Summary is live but faces adoption challenges, prompting user feedback reviews. "My AI Coach" launched to all employees and saw engagement from over 3,300 users. Talent Highlights is on hold due to eligibility limitations identified in testing, while multiple Workday generative AI features—such as GenAI Dev Items and M365 Copilot—are in various stages of production or pilot. Progress on Use Case this period: See Internal AI Use Cases Tab
Details on Change Management:
HR Services:
The function continues to drive alignment and engagement through regular stakeholder meetings and targeted executive updates, ensuring regional nuances are addressed in both content management and global service activities. Content Governance SMEs are being actively engaged to clarify future roles, and targeted sessions are underway to ensure regional HR teams are included in validation and process standardization efforts. Notably, the HRX workstream is focused on defining the Blended Role, recognizing that regional differences and the need for consensus present explicit challenges to achieving operational efficiency and reducing manual workload across the regional HR function.

Communications:
Progress has been made in identifying and piloting AI-driven improvements in content development, planning, sentiment analysis, and translations, with new focus areas added for data analysis and workflow enhancement. However, challenges remain: the team is highly skilled but continues to perform administrative tasks traditionally, and there is limited AI usage in data gathering and analysis. To address these, a plan is being developed to engage the broader Global Comms team, update the prompt library for ease of access, and foster adoption and awareness of AI tools.

Talent Acquisition:
Ongoing change management efforts include continuous messaging and education about AI use cases via AI Explorers, all-hands meetings, and dedicated forums such as bi-weekly office hours. Each pilot or rollout is treated as a distinct change initiative, with tailored communication and training to drive adoption and user comfort.

Other AI Experimentation:
Engagement and adoption are being promoted through orientation sessions (e.g., for CoCounsel), ongoing feedback collection (e.g., for My AI Coach), and targeted expansion efforts for tools like People.ai and Workday AI features. Looking ahead, change management will continue to emphasize embedding new tools into core processes, tracking adoption metrics, and proactively addressing any challenges as they arise in explicit coordination with stakeholder groups.
Path Forward:
Next steps include finalizing and implementing taxonomy and metadata standards, supporting Atrium HR content clean-up, and advancing navigation enhancements. Global HR Services will focus on centralizing KE tasks, validating Workday security roles, refining case resolution processes, and consolidating case management. HRX will complete inventory consolidation, analyze cross-functional data, and draft recommendations for process improvements and role adjustments.

Communications:
The team will continue testing and identifying new use cases, evaluate additional AI tools (e.g., Poppulo, Transperfect), and execute an engagement plan to increase AI tool adoption. Emphasis will be placed on sharing best practices, refining usage tracking, and leveraging enterprise models to capture productivity gains.

Talent Acquisition:
Key priorities include completing the BrightHire pilot and assessment, driving recruiter adoption of the AI Recruiter Summary, finalizing LinkedIn Hiring Assistant implementation, and completing HiredScore evaluation in alignment with Workday renewal discussions.

Other AI Experimentation:
Plans include monitoring My AI Coach usage and feedback, prioritizing enhancements, and embedding the tool into ongoing programs. For other initiatives, efforts will continue on technical enhancements, adoption, and data governance (People.ai), production rollout of Workday AI features, and ongoing participation in design partner groups for new tools.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
Our Editorial organization is executing a comprehensive AI transformation strategy, combining immediate operational gains with strategic positioning for future growth.

Our AI initiatives in 2025 focus on efficiency gains and simplification to enable our four core strategic priorities:
•	Increased Content Currency
•	Enhanced Value Addition to Content
•	AI-Ready Content
•	Coverage Expansion
Primary Focus Areas:
•	Authored Content Updating: Four funded AI builds in development for 2025, positioning us for resource optimization advances.
•	Editorial Assistant Automation: Two funded AI builds in development for 2025; streamlines time-intensive, repetitive tasks; enhances consistency and quality; frees specialized resources for high-value activities.
•	Editorial Expertise: Leverages our unique intellectual capital; positions us as leaders in Legal and Tax AI innovation; supports broader AI transformation strategy.
•	Self-Service AI Solutions: Drives efficiency through "Fast Track" implementation; empowers editorial teams with AI-enhanced capabilities; improves precision and quality.

While executing on this strategy, we are expanding and amplifying how we use technology to drive future advancements in the Content and Editorial space.  We are adding a renewed focus on transforming the technology stack underpinning our Primary Law content assets by embracing the power of Agentic workflows.   While the rest of our 2025 strategy remains on point - the need to expedite delivery so we can expand solutions into more workflows is acute, and the Editorial and technology teams are exploring opportunities to do just that.
Key Risks and Issues:
Risk: These novel problem sets have complexity in chaining the various components together across various technologies.
Risk: LLM version changes and announcement of deprecation and Retirment of models introduces a new layer of complexity into both the build, but even more importantly the Maintenace of released solutions.  This is a critical new ingredient that all teams using LLMS for their solutions needs to be aware of and have some sort of approach to navigate.
Risk: Copyright risk is still present, but approach for managing this is in place and sound
Progress on Use Case this period:
Our Self-Service AI Solution strategy, which we call the "Fast Track" lane has delivered numerous additional smaller scale, but still impactful AI solutions to drive both efficiencies as well as quality consistency across a variety team.  There are more than 50 additional use cases in queue for this lane.

There was a pivotal stage gate reached on or Commentary Content Updating Phase 1 Use case.   We now have proven that Commentary Analytical Articles can be drafted in the first instance by Gen AI as opposed to using external authors.  The complexity of the problem the Content Innovation team in our Content Engineering organization has developed a solution for revolutionizes both the approach to creating this content, but as importantly it will allow us to transform this product offering into a much more current and timelier content product for the benefit of our customers.  The build to bring this game changing approach to production is currently underway.

Additionally in the Commentary space, the updating mechanism for this content, that pulls in the critical case updates for our customers, has been significantly improved with Gen AI.  The build to bring this to production is also in progress.

In our Practical Law space, the Content Updating use case also saw a leap forward as critical components of the end-to-end solution have been established as feasible and additional evaluation and refinement is now underway.  

Finally, both of the Editorial Assistant use cases which support our Practical Law Editors have advanced to build integration phases.
Details on Change Management: New lead of Editorial Change Management has been added to the Editorial Strategy organization, and we are partnering closely to further our progress in this area.
Path Forward:
Each of our large build projects are in different stages of the build process - but whether they are in the evaluation/refinement phase, UX design phase, integration phase, or re-visiting certain models based on user testing and feedback - each are moving forward. 

We are actively working to improve certain approaches to our planning and work forecasting to accelerate the delivery of these to production so we can benefit from these novel and impactful solutions.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
Significant progress was made this month across multiple AI-driven initiatives, positioning CXD to meet both operational and strategic goals.  Chatbot 2.0 for UltraTax, featuring generative AI, is on targeted for fall but no launch dat has been identified yet as the team works to improve accuracy and mitigate risk with concurrent platform upgrades. Sherlock for US Tax has been fully deployed to all core agent groups, with ongoing refinements based on user feedback. The WhatsApp AI self-service tool in LatAm continues to deliver strong results, deflecting 37% of calls and resolving over half of requests without human intervention, while C2C AI initiatives have halved payment matching cases and cut query resolution times from five to two days for most customers. Service Cloud Voice rollout is progressing, with enhancements underway to address increased handle times attributed to higher call volumes and the new system. Meanwhile, the team has prepared 800 new knowledge articles for the upcoming peak season and is preparing for a major migration to Adobe’s AEM Cloud to further streamline content management.

AI adoption remains high, with 64.5% of CXD employees now using generative AI tools daily, exceeding the 50% OKR and contributing toward the $1.8M FY25 savings target. The newly launched CXD InnovAItion Hub has already surfaced 41 grassroots AI ideas, many with high cross-team potential. Key risks related to knowledge article categorization and data source breadth have been addressed, with improved Salesforce integration and robust categorization systems now in place. Looking ahead, the focus will be on expanding internal content for Intelligent Assistant, completing the Service Cloud Voice deployment, accelerating the transition to AEM Cloud, and broadening the reach of successful AI initiatives to drive continued efficiency and customer satisfaction.
Key Risks and Issues:
Effectiveness of our AI knowledge tools is being impacted by several issues.
Issue 1:  Help and Support content was written for web presentation to customers and is not categorized in a way that Salesforce understands, leading to inefficiencies in search and in some cases resulting in incorrect articles being returned by Einstein
Mitigation: Implement a robust categorization system that aligns with Salesforce's requirements. Enhance search functionalities by making filters sticky and improving the initial global search results. Regularly review and update the categorization to ensure it remains effective
Update:  Categorization functionality in Salesforce on track to release July 12th.  Content will need to be subsequently categorized and republished.  COMPLETE.  Closed.

Issue 2:  Intelligent Assistant and Salesforce Einstein are exclusively limited to knowledge articles and do not utilize other data sources in their AI learning.  This restricts the range of accessible information as 1) migration of knowledge articles to AEM Guides is not yet complete, resulting in gaps within the knowledge base and 2) doesn’t leverage other possible sources like Salesforce and Flash cases.
Mitigation: Complete the migration process by reviewing, categorizing, and publishing all articles in AEM Guides. Explore configurations to enable Salesforce Einstein and Intelligent Assistant to access other data sources like Salesforce cases and Flash cases, thereby enhancing the knowledge base
Update: Salesforce Sherlock is being leveraged to return Gen AI answers based on case data for GST/OIT users.  Testing is nearing completion and agents should be trained and using the tool by August 1. COMPLETE.  Closed.
