Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary: Additional use cases identified and underway for Product Management, Product Design, and Tax Research Content. Will continue to assess scope/usage and perform tests and experiments into second half of 2025.  Will assess financial savings in Q3/Q4 2025.
Key Risks and Issues:
RISK: Dynamic nature of product management role and activity, based on outcomes rather than outputs, make harder to find one single metric that can be utilized to single out efficiency gains by using AI. While we see the adoption of AI in these roles, it’s harder to estimate impact only based on time-savings dimension.
RISK: Also connected with the above, there are limited specific AI tools for Product Managers, and some may even increase complexity or force strict processes. While we evaluate options to implement a no-code prototyping tool or product management system, our current hypothesis is that generic tools (like Copilot / AI Platform Open Arena) might be best suited for the role – and we may create specific prompts or agents for the specific use cases that we target.
RISK: To find funding this year to build from use case ide to actual implementation of an AI agent doing the workflow, we will have to find funding in the current budget which means holding on backfills. We are working to not cause any issues with upcoming regulatory updates but time to market might be impacted. Will do our very best to mitigate but hard decisions will need to take place for the long-term good.
Progress on Use Case this period:
Five Product Manager use cases are being tracked in Launch stage, three in the Experimentation stage, and five in Ideation stage to be integrated into the product management workflow in support of the Product Operating Model. Product Requirements Document (PRD) Assistant and ADO User Story Builder, ADO Epic & Feature Builder, and Release Notes Generator are Launched, all leveraging both Open Arena and Copilot Chat Agent tools promoted on the Atrium, to the Innovation Team, and Product Manager Copilot license holders for feedback.

Product Design launched trial licenses and proof-of-concept evaluation for low-code vibe coding tools v0 and Lovable, with Product Design use cases submitted for license request categorized into four themes: prototyping and design-to-code, accessibility, AI-enhanced workflows, and speed and collaboration. Cross-functional weekly sessions were initiated to foster experiential learning through mini-hackathon-style activities, demos, and vendor Q&A sessions. Post evaluation surveys will be collected to inform recommendations. UX Engineering expanded use of GitHub Copilot, particularly in Coding Agent mode, for agent-assisted development. The Research team continues to evaluate Stravito AI, Copilot Researcher, and Analyst, reporting quality aggregation and insight generation from the tools. Content is evaluating Open Arena chains for lightweight content validation, while Operations introduced a Copilot-integrated Power BI dashboard to enable richer insights using natural language. 

In Product Content, we developed the requirements for the TaxLaw2Code project for analyzing differences and will begin the design work for creating ADO tickets automatically from the annotations. In addition, the Lead Tax Analysts are using Materia in their tax research. Finally, we have hired an AI Program Manager to identify all use cases, prioritize based on impact, and work towards implementation.  In June, we held an AI workshop with AWS to refine the requirements for TaxLaw2Code. Beyond the structured outcomes, the workshop yielded valuable, unexpected benefits. Participants experienced strengthened relationships and the deep satisfaction of achieving alignment. This human interaction is crucial for true transformation, fostering trust and a shared sense of purpose that extends beyond the official goals of the workshop.
Details on Change Management: Product Management, Design and Tax Research are focused on engagement for product manager and design-focused solutions via comms, Atrium page and Viva Engage community launch, Innovation Teams, office hours, AI solution and tools focused trainings, expansion of Copilot license activation and promotion.
Path Forward:
Product Management path forward is to enhance existing AI solutions via Open Arena models and Copilot capabilities, while continuing innovation discovery and experimentation toward development of new use cases following the Product Operating Model, and in parallel exploring external AI-prototyping tools via "future of product management" tools trials, in collaboration with Design and Product Engineering cross-functional partners.

Product Design’s path forward is to continue advancing experimentation with a focus on business-aligned pilots for early adopters across the organization, prioritizing the selection of a strategic AI-assisted prototyping tool—v0, Lovable, or Figma Make—by Q3. Inform recommendation toward the adoption selected Research and Design vendor related tools in trial.

Product Content's path forward is to finalize the top 5 AI use cases based on impact and provide the funding needed to move those to implementation in Q4 of 2025.  With the type of work done, we cannot purchase off the shelf software so will need to be built based on custom workflows and/or partnership with a third-party. 

For Tax Research (Content), we are working on Phase II of TaxLaw2Code in Q3 with the creation of ADO tickets with user story requirements. In addition, we are working to secure an AI Engineer resource to allow for work to begin on Phase III which will allow recommendations to be rendered to Analyst on the needed changes to logic.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
High-frequency usage of AI development tools (15 days or more per month) has seen a significant increase, reaching 16%—a 7% rise since June. This indicates a growing integration of AI into our development workflows.   GitHub Copilot remains the preferred tool, while Cursor and Cline are steadily gaining traction. We've successfully addressed a concern related to usage of free  GitHub Copilot version; on July 18th, the Platform Engineering team implemented a fix to block access to the free version of GitHub Copilot. This action has not only remediated a potential security vulnerability but also ensured accurate reporting of tool usage.

Furthermore, all 300 Cursor licenses have been fully assigned to engineers. We are committed to optimizing our licensing strategy by providing one commercial tool (Cursor) complemented by open-source alternatives like Cline, ensuring our engineers have access to robust and secure development resources.
Key Risks and Issues:
1. Opensource tools like CLINE offers potential for faster code development, but carries risks of IP loss and harm to TR systems and usage of LLMs not approved by TR. To mitigate these, we released the guidelines: https://trten.sharepoint.com/sites/intr-isrm-business-and-product-security/SitePages/Securing-the-AI-coding-tool-chain.aspx. To enable usage of TR-approved LLMs we piloted and onboarded LiteLLM (hosted by AI-Platform). To get engineers started in the right direction, we also released following guidelines: https://trten.sharepoint.com/sites/intr-distinguished-engineer/SitePages/A-Short-Practical-Guide-to-Using-Cline.aspx
2.  Developer surveys indicate that while AI can suggest boilerplate code, it lacks the ability to ideate or strategize. Therefore, it is crucial to maintain a human in the loop for editing and guiding the output of AI, rather than relying on it solely as a source of output.
Progress on Use Case this period:
1. Our engineering community is actively using Viva Engage. Posts with short demos and everything related to AI-powered dev tools are available via the "AI-Powered Tools" topic: https://engage.cloud.microsoft/main/org/tr.com/topics/eyJfdHlwZSI6IlRvcGljIiwiaWQiOiJFVF9mNjhmOWZkNS05MWJiLTRlMTMtYWNmYy04ODVmNTgyNThhYmMifQ/all
2.The GHCP API is now stable and addresses the usage reporting issue.
3. ClaudeCode is now rolled out to everyone after a successful pilot with TR Labs. The self-help guide on how to get started with ClaudeCode is available at: https://trten.sharepoint.com/:u:/r/sites/intr-distinguished-engineer/SitePages/Getting-Started-with-Claude-Code.aspx?csf=1&web=1&e=1udkSy
4.A/B Testing: We are continuing to monitor trends in ADO over the next several sprints to rigorously evaluate the impact of these tools on key productivity indicators, including story completion, bug reduction, and increased PR commits.
5. The next session of TechBytes with focus on Claude Code is planned for September.
Details on Change Management: None
Path Forward: We provide both open-source and licensed, commercial tools for developers to improve productivity, coding efficiency and developer experience, and measure usage and trends across these tools.
Questions / Assistance Needed from the W: None

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
This quarter, it was necessary to temporarily pause some of our initiatives in order to prioritize those with greater impact and urgency. One example of this prioritization was our focus on the “AI Feedback – Analysis of the Quality and Efficiency of Telephone Support” initiative. This process aims to analyze large-scale transcripts of telephone conversations, providing detailed information about the quality and efficiency of the service provided.

By concentrating our efforts in this area, we seek to ensure greater assertiveness in decision-making, identify opportunities for continuous improvement, and raise the quality standard of the support offered to our clients. In this way, we hope to optimize our processes, increase user satisfaction, and strengthen our ability to respond to operational challenges.

The other paused initiatives will be reassessed and resumed according to the evolution of demands and the availability of resources.
Key Risks and Issues:
RISK - There is a potential risk that the anticipated productivity gains in various AI initiatives will overlap, impacting our overall estimates. Effective implementation of these initiatives will be essential to identify and correct overlapping areas, ensuring accurate productivity estimates.
RISK - The potential risk of unsuccessful initiatives may negatively impact the customer experience due to the reduction in new hires for the support team that is currently happening.
Progress on Use Case this period:
We have made progress in experimenting with and implementing various AI solutions, with significant milestones as follows: 
• 30% in the initiative of suggested responses for representatives. 
• 80% in ticket creation – CS detractors / email channel. 
• 80% in ticket creation – chat channel.
Details on Change Management: The change management plan is ongoing, with a focus on user training and ongoing communication. We monitor performance and troubleshoot issues as they arise, ensuring a smooth transition to new AI solutions.
Path Forward: In the coming months, we will continue to focus on the implementation and integration of advanced-stage use cases.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
1. CoCounsel 2.0 and CoCounsel Drafting Implementation: CoCounsel 2.0 was deployed in Q1. CoCounsel Drafting will be deployed by the end of Q3-2025.

The CoCounsel Drafting strategy includes potential integrations with Contract Express for template automation and Practical Law for legal playbook automation. Procurement is partnering with Procurement Legal to establish a cross-functional working group focused on identifying efficiency opportunities in contracting processes, with primary focus on document comparison capabilities.

2. RFP Template Generation MVP: The MVP for collaborative RFP template generation has been successfully configured in Kronos V2, our Sourcing Projects Management solution. UAT was successfully completed in May, engaging Sourcing SMEs from the RFP Optimization program. Go-live is set for the last week of June, with plans to expand RFP template automation throughout Q3. Now, with our expertise in Copilot Studio, we are brainstorming on how to scale the solution for RFP analysis and generation, providing more value.

3. Services Gateway Chatbot Development: This development will be split into separate AI agents, starting with the deployment of our Travel & Expenses agent in July. We are currently creating our internal governance model for AI agents and compiling a list of potential use cases to be developed through Q3-H1 2026.
Key Risks and Issues:
- Complex system integration risks: Integrating the AI solutions with existing systems, databases, and workflows.​
- User Adoption and change management risks: Resistance to change or difficulties in understanding and using the new solution could hinder project success.​
- Technical risk: Algorithm complexity could delay or impact the effectiveness of the solution."
Progress on Use Case this period: In   H1, Services achieved 65% utilization of key AI tools (CoCounsel V2, OpenArena, MS Copilot), with CoCounsel V2 reaching 53% adoption among Sourcing and Supplier & Contract Managers, contributing with use cases and opportunities to the Client Zero strategy. An AI Agent for T&E FAQs built in Copilot Studio is set for July pilot while Q3-Q4 plans include CoCounsel Drafting rollout alongside scaled OpenArena capabilities, Copilot Chat, and expanded AI Agents across E2E Procurement and REFM. We are also benchmarking AI use cases in Procurement across our industry peers with a view to further expand GenAI utilization and automation to additional areas.

We are evolving slowly with power automate, and for next step we will need agentic AI.
AI tools don´t work with tables with more than 20 lines.

Overall Status: Amber - Delay/Risk/Challenges
Executive Summary:
Latam team has been included on the Gong Pilot until the end of the year. It was necessary additional alignments within the provider to understand what capabilities we should expect to test since not all the functionalities will be available since we are not going to connect Gong with the local CRMs we have in the Region. ​

The decision was made to move forward with the pilot without having additional projects being required and test only the functionalities that are available in this model.
Key Risks and Issues:
During the first discussions of the pilot, we’ve identified that Gong cannot connect the same instance of the tool with difference SFDC instances. Since Latam users are on S2E SFDC instance or SGD as their CRMs, we needed to understand the capabilities / options to be considered under the pilot scope before moving forward. ​

We explored the different options for your Gong implementation, including setting up a new instance, using the existing GSI Salesforce instance, or waiting for another time. ​

We reviewed a comparison matrix of Gong features that would be available under each option, highlighting the limitations of the existing GSI instance in terms of account-based functionality. ​

We will need to have a local person trained by the Gong team due to language limitation, with that our launch will be postponed, since there is the need of a new SOW for the train the trainer program.
Progress on Use Case this period:
Licenses were sent to all 10 users.​

The Train the trainer session was held on December 3rd. ​

We will now translate the training material and schedule local session in Portuguese and Spanish.​

Gong integration with Genesys was confirmed. ​

We have confirmed that we need to get consentient from the Customers, so the ‘opt in” option to record the call must be configured.

We have cretaed the business case for approval, it is under review.
Details on Change Management: We have identified our local resource to be trained by the Gong team and then train our team in the tool, as the trainer. We are now waiting for the SOW procedures to be finished and to schedule the train the trainer sessions with our local resource and finally train our users.
Path Forward:
Submit and Get approval on Business case.

Change Management for all Latam users

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary: This month Corporates have a new AI champion (Billy Wang) who's tasked with developing the Corporates AI strategy and how we can get our teams to use AI more. We're looking to build a holistic program around AI that will include a monthly email newsletter to everyone in Corporates, an intro meeting with all the managers including a roadshow with each of the sales managers, a bi-weekly office hours for all that wants to attend, and an Idea-a-thon for sales to build a best-in-class prompt library
Key Risks and Issues:
'1. Not enough Copilot licenses for everyone that wants one. Including our rep that handles the Microsoft account!
2. Friction in getting Gong adopted (lots of steps to setup a call, customers not willing to give consent to be recorded, etc)
3. Collaborative forecasting capabilities not robust enough at the moment for full adoption, waiting on phase 2 enhancements
4. Not getting enough data to be ingested by our internal AI tools to help the field (i.e. Seismic data in Copilot Studio)
Progress on Use Case this period:
Collaborative Forecasting and Gong was rolled out to Corporates in late May/early June. We're still working through some early implementation troubles in order to get the tools fully adopted by our field. 

Due to hierarchy issues, Revenue Intelligence rollout was delayed until mid-July and Path to Plan is delayed to late July.

Corporates Command Center (taking a page out of LP's franchise playbook) was rolled out to all the leaders within Corporates in May. CC is a collection of the main dashboards that the leaders use to run their business. Access requires CRMA license and we've worked through a number of license shortage issues so far.

Corporates have 5 massive playbooks on the Atrium site as a one stop shop for our sellers to learn about all they need to know to effectively sell our products. As expected, the playbooks are too heavy for reps to consume so the Enablement team built the Enablement Navigator chatbot in Copilot Studio for front line employees to query the chatbot for their sales questions. So far, the chatbot was released to select people on the front lines and it's been receiving great reviews. We're looking for more content for this chatbot to consume, including content that's loaded in Seismic, and any internal documentation on driving a deal through our various systems.
Details on Change Management: Working closely with CE on Gong and Collaborative Forecast adoption. Developing playbooks for new tech rollout
Path Forward:
Coming into July, we will look to recycle our Copilot licenses to those that have requested licenses as well as ways to get more licenses. 

We'll continue to drive adoption for our recently implemented AI tools and address some of the challenges facing current adoption (no actuals in Collaborative Forecasting, call setup friction with Gong, etc)
Questions / Assistance Needed from the W: I want to run an intro call with all the managers and above in Corporates (100+ people). I need some guidance and help on what content to present in terms of our internal AI tools and go forward strategy with these tools to point the team in the right direction. I would also like to learn more about RAG capabilities and see how we can utilize this in Corporates.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
The newly appointed AI Champion for Corporates (Billy Wang), formally introduced himself and outlined his vision during the all-managers call. He emphasized the imperative to leverage existing AI tools and the importance of data collection—particularly through Gong sales calls—to enhance AI intelligence and drive productivity.

A major milestone was the rollout of the Enablement Navigator, a chatbot interface built using Copilot Studio in a no-code environment. This tool ingests all five sales playbooks from the Atrium site and allows reps to query them directly via Teams—even on mobile. It marks the first self-published AI tool from Corporates and sets the stage for future innovation.
Key Risks and Issues:
'1. Not enough Copilot license remains our top issue as reps that were approved for license from June still have not received their license. Furthermore, until new request system is up and running, current AI Champion cannot see current license requests from July.
2. Lack of data access continues to be an issue. After release Enablement Navigator, multiple Sales VPs asked whether Advisor data is ingested and asked for that data to be ingested. Eric Kim (product owner) have reached out to Seismic and still awaiting feedback.
Progress on Use Case this period:
Gong uptake is picking up momentum as reps work through setup friction and begin to find ways to get customers to consent to be recorded. 

Collaborative forecasting still lags adoption. Sales ops announced at the end of July that they will use content from Collaborative Forecasting in their forecast calls with the sales President going forward, we expect immediate uptake in Collaborative forecasting. 

Rev Intel was delayed until early August, but it will include Path to Plan once released, which will replace one more Excel model
Details on Change Management: We released a program around AI adoption, including a monthly call with all the managers and selected reps and a monthly AI newsletter. AI Champion is getting pulled into multiple teams conversations on how they can adopt AI more
Path Forward:
Driving adoption will be the key focus to get folks who have not engaged with any AI tools to start to utilize the AI tools at their disposal. Helping teams that are already AI proficient to get even more value from AI will be another area of focus to drive even more value creation. 

ACES for Corporates is anticipated to be released in August, that will help greatly the account planning process for Corporates reps

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary: We are into summer holidays across July and August so work has slowed down a bit due to resources. That said, with the launch of the Reimagine/Modernisation programme, we are using the good work we have done in the Newsroom so far as a model of how to re-think teams and workflows but stepping it all up several gears. We have also launched a Newsroom Modernisation programme which has three pillars: AI Tools, Follow-the-Sun and One Newsroom (merging visuals and text) so we may reprioritise some of our streams to align with the broader piece.
Key Risks and Issues:
Speed of teams building new tools. We need to get much more agile on the build side of things.
Potential distraction of leadership as we also launch the Modernisation Programme
Evaluation of output still a concern
Progress on Use Case this period:
FactGenie - work ongoing to monitor non-feed sources like web watchers. This is going to be critical as we develop more AI news monitoring tools to feed the Follow The Sun project in the Newsroom. I suspect we need to start thinking more agentically in this space as well. 
LEON - Sadly, we had to reverse our June decision to use CoCo-mini as our drafting interface due to priorities on that team. We are now looking at the requirements to build our own AI Assistant which is compatible with the TR AI Platform. This puts Drafting back to AMBER.
Translation - we have a v1 of an editing prompt for Arabic, Korean and Japanese so will start testing with users in August. Also working on an auto-evaluation process for quality of translation but it has been harder than imagined. This feels like something we need more focus on across all streams with AI Platform on quality of output as judged by SMEs training LLMs.
Packaging - launched first two non-English Reuters Ready channels so we are at 61/110 channels complete - 
Video - feedback on AI-assisted metadata has been lukewarm at best. The AI is just too slow for our producers. Reviewing all the requirements to get something usable. AMBER overall even if individual actions are marked as GREEN because they are learning things.
Details on Change Management: We are expanding our Mindset workshops to new teams (aim is 3/week from now on). We are also planning the Reuters side of Learning Day on Sept 16. The messaging around the Reuters Modernisation plan and integrating AI into all our workflows is just starting to trickle through. Working with Luke Seal on this. We expect there will be some pushback in some corners where staff is unionised.
Path Forward:
Alerting - Turn on web watching and start to scale sources coming into FactGenie. Refine relevance ranking so we can move towards automation and cut the amount of noise in the system.
Drafting - design and decide on AI Assistant build (am thinking it might be something we do using Claude.ai and some of the work TAP is doing for Synergy?) Still need to complete prompts and evals. 
Translation - launch new Gemini 2.5 Flash CheckMATE for superusers, test new languages, starting with Arabic, create sample files for evaluation and decide which tool to use
Packaging - plan to launch next languages, test a v2 of Asset Association and v1 of a story-ranker (by story importance/relevance/recency)
Video - need to start shipping tools that actually work for the teams. Focus will be on AI-assisted scripting/metadata and Co-Producer (a tool to speed up search/discovery/first edit in video)
Questions / Assistance Needed from the W:
What training do we have for tools being used across the company and by role/process? Short "how-to" videos, not recordings of calls to listen to. 
How can we make the use case repository searchable for all employees to find colleagues elsewhere working on something similar so we can team up across TR?

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
The GCO is exploring all of the below:
Contract Review and Compliance: AI to be utilized for reviewing contracts to ensure compliance, manage obligations, and redline third-party NDAs against policies. Bulk contract reviews are being tested using CoCounsel High Volume.
Automation of Legal Processes: AI to automate tasks such as drafting correspondence for breaches of terms, creating chronologies of events from documents, and sending intake requests to HighQ, saving time and improving accuracy.
Self-Service Information Access: Chatbots are being tested across Practice Groups to provide self-serve business information. 
Enhancements in Legal Tracker: Working with the Legal Tracker product team to leverage AI for budgeting, reporting, and duplicate line-item reviews in invoices.
Development of AI-Assisted Playbooks: AI to assist in creating and updating comprehensive playbooks with pro-customer and pro-supplier arguments, streamlining the process of legal strategy documentation.
Key Risks and Issues:
Technology Integration Risks: Potential risks include challenges in integrating AI tools like CoCounsel into existing systems (e.g., High Q sites) and ensuring seamless interaction between tools for document production and summarization. Issues may arise in automating workflows for DSARs and privacy policy updates.
Compliance and Legal Risks: Concerns also include ensuring alignment between procurement and legal teams and addressing anomalies in contract negotiations.
Workflow Efficiency Risks: Challenges in leveraging AI for email workflows and timeline creation.
Contract Management Risks: Risks include inaccuracies in extracting contract data, automating contract templates, and redlining capabilities. Ensuring comprehensive playbook development and addressing non-negotiables in contract clauses are critical focus areas.
Progress on Use Case this period:
A lot of progress was made during Q2 with the Customer Zero Labs team having scoped some use cases the GCO needs AI to help with.

The three priority use cases that were identified are as follows:

1. CoCounsel Playbook Skill​ (Developing and improving AI redlining capability)
2. CoCounsel High Volume​
#1: Using High Volume to review post-acquisition contracts for non-negotiables​
#2: Using High Volume to review existing contracts for non-negotiables​
#3: Using High Volume in eDiscovery for active litigation
3. GCO Chatbots
Details on Change Management: Customer Zero team has identified change management resources for the future.
Path Forward: Continue detailed scoping of use cases with each practice group and testing as and when ready.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
During the reporting period, PCSI advanced several AI initiatives across Talent Acquisition, HR Services, Communications, and Other AI Experimentation. In Talent Acquisition, the BrightHire pilot has been extended, LinkedIn Hiring Assistant continues its pilot with notable hires achieved, and Open Arena-powered AI Recruiter Summary has been launched though recruiter adoption remains low. Exploration of HiredScore integration with Workday is underway. Communications workstream expanded AI experimentation, testing over thirty use cases and introducing platforms like WRITER and Transperfect’s AI-translation tool, while actively developing plans for broader Global Communications AI engagement. HR Services saw successful pilot completions, implementation of content strategies, navigation enhancements, and further consolidation and automation of global workflows. Other AI Experimentation included the launch of My AI Coach, progress with Workday generative AI features, and continued engagement with early adopter programs and new tools aimed at enhancing talent management and HR operations.

Throughout the month, all workstreams demonstrated meaningful progress in piloting, launching, and refining AI solutions, with some tools already showing measurable engagement and operational impact. Adoption rates, feedback collection, and process enhancements were actively managed, and several new AI features were either rolled out or are in testing phases. Coordination with technical partners and ongoing evaluation of user experience were key focuses, ensuring continued momentum in both experimentation and operational integration.
Key Risks and Issues:
Key risks across PCSI workstreams include dependencies on capacity-constrained internal technical partners, which may affect timely delivery and integration of AI solutions. Data privacy and CIO support for BrightHire have been addressed, but ongoing technical capacity and adoption challenges remain, particularly in Talent Acquisition where recruiter buy-in takes time. Communications faces competing priorities and delivery pressures, which limit bandwidth for AI experimentation and process change.

HR Services is managing regional differences in validation processes, pending access revocation, and workflow variations that could delay automation and standardization efforts. The HRX workstream is addressing high task volumes and team availability constraints, which may impact deadlines for final recommendations and task transitions. Effective buy-in from receiving teams and standardization of region-specific processes remain critical for smooth implementation. No specific risks or issues were reported for Other AI Experimentation.
Progress on Use Case this period: See Internal AI Use Cases Tab
Details on Change Management:
Change management efforts have been robust across PCSI, with targeted communication and training plans supporting AI rollouts and process transitions. In Talent Acquisition, ongoing messaging and bi-weekly office hours facilitate engagement, while each pilot is accompanied by dedicated communication and training initiatives. Communications has expanded experimentation, developed prompt libraries, and partnered with internal AI leaders to drive engagement and learning across the global team.

HR Services continues to emphasize stakeholder engagement and training, with regular updates and sessions designed to address regional nuances and maintain alignment. Proactive planning and coordination are underway in HRX to socialize recommendations and ensure smooth transitions, including early engagement with digital automation leads. No significant change management activities were reported for Other AI Experimentation during this period.

Across all workstreams, the emphasis on proactive communication, stakeholder engagement, and tailored training has supported the adoption and integration of AI solutions within PCSI. By maintaining structured rollout plans and leveraging regular forums for feedback and knowledge sharing, the function is positioned to manage ongoing change effectively while preparing for broader implementation of future AI enhancements.
Path Forward:
Looking ahead, each workstream will continue to progress independently, with a clear emphasis on completing active pilots, evaluating their impact, and determining next steps for broader deployment. Talent Acquisition is focused on finalizing the BrightHire pilot and driving further adoption of AI Recruiter Summary, while completing LinkedIn Hiring Assistant training and business case development for HiredScore. Communications will maintain active testing, expand use case evaluation, and refine engagement plans to accelerate AI adoption and productivity savings across the team.

HR Services will implement feedback-driven improvements, launch new navigation features, and further standardize workflows, supported by enhanced KPI tracking and ongoing team upskilling. Regional HR will finalize comprehensive task analyses and recommendations, resolve any duplications, and begin stakeholder engagement to socialize automation opportunities. Other AI Experimentation will monitor user engagement, continue tool iteration, and prepare for future launches contingent on vendor updates, with several new Workday AI features scheduled for testing and rollout.
Questions / Assistance Needed from the W: There are no questions or assistance needed from the Working Group at this time.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
We continue to test and scale the AI use cases that have demonstrated highest ROI across our major functional areas. The AI adoption rate is strong in Global Print, with 72% active usage as of July, and the team is on track to deliver committed productivity gains in 2026. 

In the month of August, Global Print implemented a proactive and centrally managed governance process on existing segment Copilot licenses. Additional licenses have been requested as use cases across the business continue to expand, and requests are on backlog awaiting fulfilment once available.

Meetings are also underway across the leadership team to identify focus areas for AI and automation in support of the Reimagine initiative, as well as business transformation targets. 

Key AI use cases include research and analysis, meeting management, customer relationship management, technical support, and creative design.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
Our Editorial organization is executing a comprehensive AI transformation strategy, combining immediate operational gains with strategic positioning for future growth.

Our AI initiatives in 2025 focus on efficiency gains and simplification to enable our four core strategic priorities:
•	Increased Content Currency
•	Enhanced Value Addition to Content
•	AI-Ready Content
•	Coverage Expansion
Primary Focus Areas:
•	Authored Content Updating: Four funded AI builds in development for 2025, positioning us for resource optimization advances.
•	Editorial Assistant Automation: Two funded AI builds in development for 2025; streamlines time-intensive, repetitive tasks; enhances consistency and quality; frees specialized resources for high-value activities.
•	Editorial Expertise: Leverages our unique intellectual capital; positions us as leaders in Legal and Tax AI innovation; supports broader AI transformation strategy.
•	Self-Service AI Solutions: Drives efficiency through "Fast Track" implementation; empowers editorial teams with AI-enhanced capabilities; improves precision and quality.
Key Risks and Issues:
Issue: Resources - certain key resources have been tapped to work on additional/alternative projects, and this will impact our projects to some degree.
Risk: Copyright risk will grow as we tackle more advanced use cases; but process is in place to track and manage this
Progress on Use Case this period:
Our Self-Service AI Solution strategy, which we call the "Fast Track" lane has continues to deliver smaller scale, but still impactful AI solutions to drive both efficiencies as well as quality consistency across a variety teams within our Editorial organization.  There are more than 157 use cases in queue for this lane: 37 currently being actively built.  We have released 28 for production use to date.  Not only does this drive the efficiency goals we have, it also serves as the most impactful AI learning and engagement tool we have.

The team is in active discussions on UI experience and approach that will allow us to deliver the first publication into the new cutting-edge Commentary Content updating approach (We now have proven that Commentary Analytical Articles can be drafted in the first instance by Gen AI as opposed to using external authors.  The complexity of the problem the Content Innovation team in our Content Engineering organization has developed a solution for revolutionizes both the approach to creating this content, but as importantly it will allow us to transform this product offering into a much more current and timelier content product for the benefit of our customers.  The build to bring this game changing approach to production is currently underway.)

The team has also moved onto the UI experience stage of development for the additonal Care updating project in the Commentary space.  (The updating mechanism for this content, that pulls in the critical case updates for our customers, has been significantly improved with Gen AI.  The build to bring this to production is also in progress.)  Of note, the product and technology teams use of Claude.ai significantly helped on this.

In our Practical Law space, the Content Updating use case continues to progress towards the end-to-end solution for delivery.

The Editorial Assistant use cases which support our Practical Law Editors have advanced to build integration phases, though there have been some impacts to progress due to resource allocation issues.

Finally, the dedicated Codes Reimagine POC has made significant progress in the past couple weeks.
Details on Change Management:
New Change Management lead identified and actively rolling out and addressing key change material and issues.
Continue to leverage established communication and learning approaches (newsletters, dedicated atrium site, team meeting presentations, clinics, town halls, trainings, etc).
Path Forward:
Projects will advance following ways of working and development cadence.
Keeping a very close eye on impacts to deliverables based on resource constraints.
Focusing and firming up with specificity delivery dates for each large build proejct; and working with our content segment partners to start to plan for launch to editorial teams.

AI Use Cases: Agent Knowledge: Einstein Knowledge workflow,Agent Productivity: Salesforce Einstein Gen AI replies and summarization,Agent Productivity: Service Cloud (Salesforce) Voice,Customer Self-Service: WhatsApp Support for LatAm,Internal Productivity: Customer to Cash,Internal Productivity: Help and Support Content Acceleration
Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary: August demonstrated continued progress in AI transformation across CXD, with AI adoption reaching 76.1% of employees using AI tools daily (+10.6pp month-over-month), significantly exceeding the 50% OKR target. The organization successfully executed Service Cloud Voice Phase II rollout to GST/OIT teams on August 9th, implemented comprehensive fall peak readiness enhancements, and maintained strong financial performance with $1.37M in annualized AI savings, tracking ahead of the $1.8M annual target. Key achievements include successful deployment of four critical fall peak technology enhancements: Sherlock AI tool for historical case data searches, publication of 800 new articles addressing top call drivers, and Service Cloud Voice deployment enabling transcript capture and Einstein AI next best actions. Chatbot 2.0 development progressed with accuracy testing showing 52-54% performance across UltraTax and Coveo solutions, while content ingestion improvements were implemented through 12 content update tickets. The CXD InnovAItion Hub demonstrated strong engagement with 86 total ideas submitted, 69% scored and reviewed, 43% identified as high-potential, and 65 showing cross-team applicability. WhatsApp AI self-service maintained steady performance with 30% call deflection and 48% of requests resolved without human intervention. Financial performance remained robust with YTD AI savings of $638K versus planned $513K, reflecting successful workforce optimization and strategic AI implementation.
Key Risks and Issues:
"Issue: Service Cloud Voice AHT Impact Concerns
Overall, the initial findings show Salesforce Voice impact is muted in relation to Average Handle Time (AHT) even after 3 months of deployment. The team has incorporated learnings from the initial deployment into plans for subsequent rollouts to address these concerns and improve effectiveness.

Mitigation Strategy: Enhanced training protocols, improved UAT procedures including OAuth configuration validation, and refined deployment strategies for future phases based on Customer Service Phase 1 learnings.
Progress on Use Case this period:
Service Cloud Voice Phase II – GST/OIT Rollout GST/OIT Product Support teams became operational on August 9th. Initial issues were encountered and resolved, with US Tax agents currently utilizing the feature during peak periods. P1 ticket resolution: Clients were unable to connect via Chat Support due to chat delivery configuration issues, resolved through client configuration updates for Genesys chat delivery.  Updated UAT protocols now include OAuth configuration validation for future deployments. 17 live agent training courses were delivered incorporating learnings from Customer Service Phase 1. 

Chatbot 2.0 Development Significant advancement in generative AI model testing and accuracy ratings for Chatbot 2.0 UltraTax and Coveo Gen AI solutions, with outputs showing comparable performance (52% vs. 54% respectively). Content ingestion issues were addressed through completion of 12 content update tickets to resolve gaps in missing or incorrectly tagged content. Internal review revealed that content adhering to TR standards demonstrated superior quality in voice, tone, and structure, prompting team reassessment of whether structured content improves accuracy.

Fall Peak Readiness Technology Enhancements three critical enhancements implemented: 1) Sherlock AI tool deployed for US Tax agents searching historical case data, 2) Top 800 call drivers addressed through new and updated published articles, 3)  Service Cloud Voice deployed for GST/OIT agents with transcript capture and Einstein AI next best action capabilities.

CXD InnovAItion Hub Performance
The Innovation Hub continued to demonstrate strong engagement with 79 total ideas submitted since launch. Of these submissions, 65% have been scored and reviewed, with 58 ideas showing cross-team applicability, indicating significant potential for organization-wide impact and scalability.

C2C Initiatives1. Customer Queries Analysis - Phase 2: The team is awaiting security approval to proceed with a Google agent POC, as internal support from the Enterprise AI and D&A teams has been declined. The scope of the POC with Google is limited to advanced receipts for Canada, to validate the solution before expanding to additional use cases. 2. Unapplied Payments/Suspense Payments: Work on the Unapplied Suspense Payments initiative has resumed after developer resources became available, with requirements gathering underway for the ANZ region and development expected to start soon. The team aims to launch ANZ by September or early October, while standardization for UKI and other regions is progressing in parallel. 3. Order Management Agent: Leveraging Copilot studio to help support OM processing team with AI agent to query their current SOPs to get the right information faster. The Order Management Agent project resolved previous issues with incorrect data retrieval and has been retested with positive initial results. The team expects to launch the agent in September, following a small pilot to confirm accuracy.

LatAm Projects and Innovation: LatAm Call deflection achieved 30% in August with YTD average of 31%. 48% of requests were resolved without human intervention, with early abandon rate steady at 15%. Open Arena integration into Onvio is planned for completion by end of Q3, enabling customers in Argentina to access AI-based self-support features directly through the product. AI innovation SQUAD training is scheduled from September 9 to October 2, with implementation initiatives currently under analysis. AI-based automated call transcription quality assurance is under testing for Spanish and Portuguese languages. The first GTM hackathon concluded successfully, producing several AI-driven automation proposals with implementation activities pending planning.
Details on Change Management: CXD has significantly exceeded the TR Enterprise AI OKR target, with 76.1% of employees now using AI tools daily (+10.6 percentage point month-over-month increase), far surpassing the 50% goal and demonstrating accelerated adoption across the organization. This substantial increase reflects successful deployment of additional AI tools and effective communication channels promoting AI learning opportunities and innovative applications. The 2025 AI Communications plan continues  with the AI Spark newsletter showing declining engagement across approximately 2,300 recipients.  Value being reconsidered.  The CXD InnovAItion Hub demonstrates exceptional grassroots innovation with 86 total ideas submitted, 69% scored and reviewed, 43% identified as high-potential initiatives, and 65 showing cross-team applicability. CXD is participating in the Claude.ai pilot with 15+ use cases being tested by approximately 40 users. Early feedback is positive, especially around visualizations and project-based sharing capabilities. Demand for Microsoft 365 Copilot licenses remains consistently high, with usage monitoring showing sustained high utilization and effective license recycling practices to maximize organizational benefit.
Path Forward:
1.  Chatbot 2.0/CommEng R.A.G. Next Steps - Key activities include data gathering and analysis of SurePrep agent feedback, finalizing cross-business requirements, and conducting gap analysis with Coveo out-of-the-box solution against vendor roadmap capabilities.
2.  Service Cloud Voice Expansion - Rollout for Reference Attorney teams is planned as the next phase of deployment, incorporating lessons learned from the GST/OIT implementation.
3.  Knowledge Management Enhancement  - Partnering with CS&S leadership, Content teams, and Salesforce to develop detailed delivery timelines for top CS&S products to be integrated into Knowledge Management tools, ensuring comprehensive coverage and optimal agent support.
4.  Continued Innovation and Adoption - Maintain momentum in AI tool deployment, Innovation Hub idea development, and communication initiatives to sustain high adoption rates and drive continued efficiency gains toward full organizational AI integration.
Questions / Assistance Needed from the W: None

AI Use Cases: Product Requirements Document (PRD) Assistant - Product Managers,ADO User Story - Product Managers,ADO Epic - Product Managers,ADO Feature - Product Managers,Release Notes Generator - Product Managers,ADO Agent Workflow - Product Managers,No Code Prototyping Tool - Product Managers,Business Case to Product Delivery Workflow - Product Managers,EPC Investments Tracking - Product Managers,Roadmapper - Product Managers,QBR Automate - Product Managers,Product Info Bot - Product Managers,User Experience Deep Research,Prototyping+ / UI Vibecoding,Github Copilot Agent Assisted Development,Centralized IP - Design,TaxLaw2Code (ADO) – Tax Research (Content),Release Notes AI Creation - Tax Research (Content) ,Modernize iDesign Development Tool - Tax Research (Content)
Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary: Additional use cases identified and underway for Product Management, Product Design, and Tax Research Content. Will continue to assess scope/usage and perform tests and experiments into second half of 2025.  The teams are building AI Chains and Chatbots into the current workflows.
Key Risks and Issues:
RISK: Dynamic nature of product management role and activity, based on outcomes rather than outputs, make harder to find one single metric that can be utilized to single out efficiency gains by using AI. While we see the adoption of AI in these roles, it’s harder to estimate impact only based on time-savings dimension.
RISK: Also connected with the above, there are limited specific AI tools for Product Managers, and some may even increase complexity or force strict processes. While we evaluate options to implement a no-code prototyping tool or product management system, our current hypothesis is that generic tools (like Copilot / AI Platform Open Arena) might be best suited for the role – and we may create specific prompts or agents for the specific use cases that we target.
Progress on Use Case this period:
Five Product Manager use cases are being tracked in Launch stage, three in the Experimentation stage, and five in Ideation stage to be integrated into the product management workflow in support of the Product Operating Model. Product Requirements Document (PRD) Assistant and ADO User Story Builder, ADO Epic & Feature Builder, and Release Notes Generator are Launched, all leveraging both Open Arena and Copilot Chat Agent tools promoted on the Atrium, to the Innovation Team, and Product Manager Copilot license holders for feedback. AI for Product Management Tools Trial is in progress, examining via POC 4 no-code AI prototyping tools for product manager use; recommendation ETA by end of Sept.

Product Design continues to advance AI-assisted prototyping through the ongoing “Prototyping+” program trial. In August, the team expanded participation across design, engineering, product management, and executive leadership onboarding, learning, and experimenting with multiple tools. six core use-case domains have emerged across teams trialing the tools including realistic design exploration, accessibility reviews, smoother engineering handoff of which are all showing early signs of accelerating communication and improving cross-functional collaboration. The trial remains active, with additional feedback and tool evaluations expected through September. These efforts directly support the Product Operating Model by embedding prototyping into early-stage workflows and are showing signs of enabling faster, more informed decision-making across teams. Teams are exploring the use of model context protocol (MCP) for integrating multiple systems using developer tools with the paella project. The Centralized IP project is evolving, incorporating integrations with AskJulius and Figma as starting points. The design research function is partnering to explore opportunities for a Research Bank Hackathon project to explore bringing research content and AI synthesis in-house.

In Tax Content Research, we have developed a comprehensive list of AI use cases across all of the teams.  We have prioritized the top cases that will have the largest impact.  We are actively working 10 use cases and have implemented 4 of these in the month of September.  We are mapping the roles across the organization to analyze where there is whitespace that we need to determine how AI can be incorporated into the development workflow.
Details on Change Management: Product Management, Design and Tax Research are focused on engagement for product manager, content analysts, and design-focused solutions via comms, Atrium page and Viva Engage community launch, Innovation Teams, office hours, AI solution and tools focused trainings, expansion of Copilot license activation and promotion, and 3rd party tools trials.  In addition, for Tax & Trade Content Research, we are working to reimagine 2-3 workflows across OSR, Direct Tax, and Indirect Tax. From this, we will determine what additional skills are needed to build agents.
Path Forward:
Product Management path forward is to enhance existing AI solutions via Open Arena models and Copilot capabilities, while continuing innovation discovery and experimentation toward development of new use cases following the Product Operating Model, and in parallel exploring external AI-prototyping tools via "future of product management" tools trials, in collaboration with Design and Product Engineering cross-functional partners.

Product Design’s path forward is to continue advancing experimentation with a focus on business-aligned pilots for early adopters across the organization, prioritizing the selection of a strategic AI-assisted prototyping tools and business use cases.

For Tax Research (Content), we are continuing to work on progress with the development of AI chains for the use cases prioritized.  We are determining if there are additional skillsets we need to hire for to accelerate AI implementation. We have mastered AI Chains and have incorporated several into the processes.  The next step is mastering the development of Agents.
Lead: Perez, Pablo (TR Product);Shaler, Sara (TR Product);Abadir, Nadia (TR Product);West, Jennifer (TR Product);Coleman, Claudia B. (TR Product);Howard, Robert (TR Product)

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary: AI Dev Tools adoption has reached 79% as of August 30, up 27 points since May, with 26% of users now in high-frequency usage of 15 days or more. GitHub Copilot leads, while Cursor and Cline are gaining traction. The engineering team continues active engagement via Teams and Viva Engage to showcase automation demos using AI Dev Tools. Next, Anthropic-led ClaudeCode workshops will run across Toronto, MSP, Bangalore, and Hyderabad, TechBytes in September with focus on the Claude Code, In-person workshop in Bangalore, Hyderbad and Mexico City with focus on GitHub and GitHub Copilot. Phase 2 will target end-to-end development workflow automation measured by composite DORA metrics, R&D cost as a share of revenue, and feature adoption.
Key Risks and Issues:
1. Cline offers potential for faster code development, but carries risks of IP loss and harm to TR systems. To mitigate these, we propose limiting use to internal LLMs, employing development containers for isolation, and implementing robust auditing.
You can find guidelines here: https://trten.sharepoint.com/sites/intr-isrm-business-and-product-security/SitePages/Securing-the-AI-coding-tool-chain.aspx
2. Developer surveys indicate that while AI can suggest boilerplate code, it lacks the ability to ideate or strategize. Therefore, it is crucial to maintain a human in the loop for editing and guiding the output of AI, rather than relying on it solely as a source of output.
3. Engineers could use free version of GH Copilot. This was blocked by Platform Engineering.
Progress on Use Case this period:
Adoption Metrics:

o	High-frequency usage, towards our PE OKR goal of 75% (minimum 15 uses per month), has reached 25%, reflecting a good 9% increase since July.  
o	GitHub Copilot remains the most popular tool, while Cursor and Cline are gaining popularity. Both GHCP and ClaudeCode see higher average use of 10 days or more.

Support & Enablement:

o	The Enterprise InternalAI dashboard now provides managers and individuals with access to a list of users who have not used the system.
o	During CodeRed standup team regularly shares impressive demos and shares on Viva Engage, including end-to-end automation using ClaudeCode agents for tasks from ADO to GitHub.
Details on Change Management: None
Path Forward:

o.     TechBytes in September with focus on the Claude Code
o.     In-person workshop in Bangalore, Hyderbad and Mexico City with focus on GitHub and GitHub Copilot. 
o	As we move into Phase 2 of the enterprise Internal AI program, we will focus on end-to-end workflow automation for development tasks. Our key measures for this phase will include composite DORA metrics, R&D cost as a percentage of revenue, and feature adoption rate.

Executive Summary:
Gong: Month 5 of Legal Professionals usage was filled with additional change management activities to drive adoption and partnership with Gong to explore the "art of the possible" within the tool. Successfully launched Gong to Legal Customer Success Team (70 licenses).

Open Arena Highlight: SLF launched The Sixth on July 10 and drove a 26% adoption increase in under a month. 78% improvement in deal velocity with average days to close dropping from 23 to 5. 68% lift in average deal value and win rate increased in deals using the Sixth vs. non-AI-Assisted deals.

Gong: Adoption has averaged 30% and in order to increase, we need to track metrics and report out consistently. Currently, the Gong team has created a dashboard but data continues to be a challenge and more manual work is needed.

Gainsight: With Customer Education planning to onboard 60+ folks in October, we need to build out additional AI use cases for this team to help drive fast adoption.
Progress on Use Case this period:
Gong: Early efficiency and cost impacts are meaningful across use cases: an estimated $728K saved from March to July (approximately $146K per month) and 7,285 hours saved from May to July. Gong Team is working on creating short use case videos while partnering with Channel Enablement to create an over AI Page that will feature Gong Hall of Fame across LP. In addition, we will be capturing other use case videos to help drive adoption across all AI tools.

Gainsight: Successfully completed the design and build of Gainsight.  

Open Arena: our platform for streamlined deal execution and collaboration and more, continues to ramp since launch. Adoption is averaging 33% across subsegments and approximately 700 users. SLF leads with performance, posting the highest growth since launch.

Copilot: Business sub-segments have 10-30 licenses each. Early impact indicators are promising - we estimate 1,104–2,208 hours saved per month and 30–50% faster execution across common use cases.

Also rolling out Gong to Gov in H2 (100 licenses approved).

Pros:
- Reduces a lot of debugging time giving time for experimentation.
- Optimization suggestions beyond general options
- Accelerates learning curve of any new technology

Cons:

- Has better support for common language like Python but could improve for others. I understand this is connected to abundant Python resources but it could do better for others after tuning.
- No Built-in Preference System: No dedicated settings file for project-specific defaults e.g. colours, logos, connections, etc.
- Doesn't remember consistently rejected suggestions"

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
Still making progress on our 2025 goals despite a lot of people being absent over August and some key personnel changes. We are increasingly viewing the Newsroom AI project as one pillar of the overall Newsroom Modernisation plan which will require us to support the "Follow the Sun" model of breaking news monitoring and coverage, the "One Newsroom" plan to collapse the silos between text and visual newsplanning, reporting and production and the broader goals of the TR Reimagine programme. 
The newsroom is still behind the rest of Reuters and TR in terms of adoption and we are engaging the senior leadership and managers to engage their teams much more regularly to ensure that people are not being left behind in the general AI transformation of work.
Key Risks and Issues:
Evaluations are still top of mind. Our new Newsroom AI Editor Rob Lang is working on options with our head of Applied Innovation Ian Knopke. Jonathan Leff taking the lead on that.
Our Head of Product left Reuters in August and our president is taking over the team on an interim basis. That might lead to a change in focus, team structure and priorities over the next month as we consider how our efforts are balanced on internal and external opportunities. There is a little tension between what we can build in our own newsroom that we could make available to our Agency customers and what the newsroom itself needs for its own structural changes. Also on current plans vs moving into more agentic workflows and getting the right staff and knowledge to do that.
Our attention is now being split between what we are building for the newsroom and the broader Reimagine programme. NB Matt Keen is in charge of Reimagine for Reuters with Jane leading on the AI Transformation piece (not costs/staffing)
Progress on Use Case this period:
FactGenie - We are moving fully into Phase 2 of FactGenie which is in three parts: 1) expanding to non-corporate releases and focusing first on central bank announcements 2) tuning our current corporate alert filtering and generation to move towards full automation and faster processing 3) creating an LLM backstop for our ML-based results alerting tool PLX. Next steps are below.
LEON - Having had to move away from the plan to use CoCo-mini for our AI Assistant, the team has built v1 of the Reuters Assistant which can hopefully sit across all our publication tools. 
LAMP - Italian, Spanish and French models are live in production. No major issues reported but ongoing maintenance will be needed
Translation - We have launched CheckMATE (the gen AI editing prompt) in the romance languages. Korean and Arabic CheckMATE has been released for super users and we are gathering feedback. 
AVISTA - Drew up first requirements for AI-shotlisting workflow and tooling v2 rather than retrofitting Avista into the Newsroom. On the positive side, we are on track to launch a prototype of CoProducer (AI-assisted video search + edit which could then become agentic) by the end of Q3.
Details on Change Management:
Newsroom adoption is at 46% with a clear gap opening up between those who are embracing AI and learning new skills/tools and those who are not. We are using Learning Day to get people to consider where they are - Getting Started, Engaged (daily use), Proficient (using multiple tools beyond Copilot/Open Arena) - and showing them how other colleagues have moved up through those levels and what it might look like for them. 
We are also continuing to offer more training courses and mindset workshops to help people find the human in the AI transformation and focus on that so there is less threat and more engagement.
Path Forward:
FactGenie - On central bank announcements, we need to tweak and test the prompt. We have seen some hallucination creep into the results which we need to analyse and stamp out. On automation, we are working to reduce duplicate alerts, filter out low-relevance and implement rules to enable/disable autofiling. 
LEON: testing the first skill through the AI Assistant of drafting an "urgent" - the first two paragraph story that follows on from the inital alerts. We also need to calculate our current human baseline time-to-client so that we can measure progress as we turn on the AI drafting tool. NB we have pushed back our goal of using the AI Assistant for "Stocks Buzz" to Q4 as an effective solution will need real-time access to market data which was not scoped at the start of Q3.
LAMP: Upping the priority for Arabic Reuters Ready ahead of launch of Arabic app and site in Q4. Team is still working on the "single package solution" to satisfy both Agency and LSEG clients on a story, which has turned out to be much trickier than imagined. Training models on the story ranking challenge too.
Translation: Evaluation working group to launch in early September to build on initial processes which have now been created and mapped. 
AVISTA: Taking rethought requirements into a dev plan, integrating subeditor prompt into VESPA (if AI Assistant dev work stays on track) and testing CoProducer v0 with three producers
2026 planning: We are starting to plan for 2026 goals for Newsroom AI and fitting it into the broader Modernisation/Reimagine programme.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
1. CoCounsel 2.0 and CoCounsel Drafting Implementation

CoCounsel 2.0 was deployed in Q1, with CoCounsel Drafting scheduled for deployment by the end of Q3-2025. An updated CoCounsel Prompts Library will be deployed to support Sourcing and Supplier & Contract Managers on their contract review and contract drafting activities. The primary focus for these teams will be Contract Comparison documents, which represents the most time-consuming task in their workflow.

Continuous Improvement Plan (Q4): The CoCounsel Drafting strategy includes potential integrations with Contract Express for template automation and Practical Law for legal playbook automation.

2. RFP Template Generation MVP

The solution is being split into two distinct use cases:

2.1 RFP Proposal Responses Summarization (Delivery: September 2025):
Specific Outcomes: Versatile proposal summarization AI workflow adaptable to multiple proposal categories while maintaining quality standards
MVP Definition: Initial version with clear boundaries around proposal types and complexity levels
Continuous Improvement Plan: Extended version with an AI Agent featuring real-time guidance and RFP FAQ automation

2.2 Intelligent RFP Template Generator (Delivery: Q4 2025):
Concept: Prompt-based testing with available LLMs will assess the feasibility and quality of AI-generated RFP content. If AI output proves unsatisfactory, focus will shift to developing modular, category-specific templates
The original MVP for collaborative RFP template generation was successfully configured in Kronos V2, with UAT completed in May and go-live achieved in the last week of June. With our expertise in Copilot Studio, we are now scaling the solution for comprehensive RFP analysis and generation.

3. Services Gateway Chatbot Development

This development is being split into separate AI agents:

3.1 Travel & Expenses Agent: Deployment scheduled for September 2025

3.2 Procurement Agent:
Focus: E2E Process Orchestration
Specific Outcomes: Intelligent agent streamlining end-to-end procurement journey with real-time guidance and FAQ automation
MVP Definition: AI agent in Copilot Studio orchestrating procurement workflows, integrating with existing H2O systems
Timeline: MVP delivery by end of September with continuous improvements in Q4
Continuous Improvement Plan: Incorporate new procurement policy for compliance capabilities upon availability
We are currently developing our internal governance model for AI agents and compiling a comprehensive list of potential use cases to be developed through Q3-H1 2026.
Key Risks and Issues:
- Complex system integration risks: Integrating the AI solutions with existing systems, databases, and workflows.​
- User Adoption and change management risks: Resistance to change or difficulties in understanding and using the new solution could hinder project success.​
- Technical risk: Algorithm complexity could delay or impact the effectiveness of the solution."
Progress on Use Case this period: In August, Services achieved 73% utilization of key AI tools (CoCounsel V2, OpenArena, MS Copilot 365, and MS Copilot Chat), with CoCounsel V2 reaching 53% adoption among Sourcing and Supplier & Contract Managers, contributing with use cases and opportunities to the Client Zero strategy.
Details on Change Management:
CoCounsel (Next Steps):
•	CoCounsel Core 2.0 Rollout: Phased upgrades through the end of 2025 as they become available.
•	Explore and deploy CoCounsel Drafting
Path Forward:
Q3 Progress & Outlook: The Travel & Expenses AI Agent pilot has been rescheduled from July to September, with development now underway for a Procurement Agent focused on E2E process orchestration. CoCounsel Drafting deployment remains on track for end of Q3-2025, with an updated CoCounsel Prompts Library specifically designed to support contract comparison activities - the most time-intensive task for our Sourcing and Contract Management teams.

RFP Automation Expansion: Following successful UAT completion and June go-live of our RFP Template Generation MVP in Kronos V2, we are now scaling the solution into two specialized use cases: RFP Proposal Responses Summarization (September delivery) and Intelligent RFP Template Generator (Q4 delivery), leveraging our Copilot Studio expertise.

Q4 Strategic Initiatives: Plans include CoCounsel Drafting continuous improvements with potential Contract Express and Practical Law integrations, expanded AI Agents across E2E Procurement, and the Procurement Agent MVP with real-time guidance capabilities integrated with existing H2O systems. We continue benchmarking AI use cases in Procurement across industry peers while developing our internal AI agent governance model and compiling use cases for development through H1 2026.

Overall Status: Amber - Delay/Risk/Challenges
Executive Summary:
Latam team has been included on the Gong Pilot until the end of the year. It was necessary additional alignments within the provider to understand what capabilities we should expect to test since not all the functionalities will be available since we are not going to connect Gong with the local CRMs we have in the Region. ​

The decision was made to move forward with the pilot without having additional projects being required and test only the functionalities that are available in this model.
Key Risks and Issues:
During the first discussions of the pilot, we’ve identified that Gong cannot connect the same instance of the tool with difference SFDC instances. Since Latam users are on S2E SFDC instance or SGD as their CRMs, we needed to understand the capabilities / options to be considered under the pilot scope before moving forward. ​

We explored the different options for your Gong implementation, including setting up a new instance, using the existing GSI Salesforce instance, or waiting for another time. ​

We reviewed a comparison matrix of Gong features that would be available under each option, highlighting the limitations of the existing GSI instance in terms of account-based functionality. ​
Progress on Use Case this period: The business case is currently under approval. We have adjusted the pilot users by removing those who were not actively using the tool, to ensure visibility of real usage.

Executive Summary:
In August, Corporates accelerated its internal AI transformation, launching a new account-planning AI tool and deepening adoption efforts. Building on July’s momentum, the segment introduced an AI-driven account planning assistant (ACES) and formally established a Corporates AI Champions Network to foster grassroots engagement. Corporates held off on fully launching ACES as Europe is not part of the user base yet, targeting a mid-September EU pilot launch with a full launch by beginning of October. 

Gong usage continues to be a challenge and we're putting more emphasis on Gong usage on the next Corporates Conversations to everyone in Corporates.
Key Risks and Issues:
'1. Limited Copilot License Availability: The shortage of Microsoft Copilot (M365) licenses remains the most pressing issue. Our head of Professional Services and CSMs have requested paid Copilot licenses for all their teams. 
2. Data Silos and Missing Integrations: Several key data sources are not yet connected to our AI tools, impeding their effectiveness. For example, our sales chatbot lacks access to Seismic Advisor (product marketing content) and Gong call data isn’t fully integrated with Copilot/Open Arena queries. Mindtickle and Adobe are additional silos though of lesser importance to GTM vs Advisor.
Progress on Use Case this period:
After June’s rollout of Gong to 600+ Sales, CS, and Account Specialist roles, adoption gained some traction in August with the extention of Gong collaborator licenses to over 850 additional team members (across Professional Services, Solutions Consulting, Product & Industry, and Partnerships teams) so managers and adjacent roles can view call recordings and insights. To further drive usage, the team scheduled extra Gong office hours on Aug 19, 26, and 27 for hands-on support and even launched a Gong/CoPilot SPIFF incentive for sales reps. 

Revenue Intelligence & Forecasting – Path-to-Plan Delivered: The Revenue Intelligence dashboard (Salesforce Einstein analytics) finally went live for Corporates after a delay, with the crucial “Path-to-Plan” feature delivered in early August replacing previously manual Excel effort.
Details on Change Management:
Communications and Training: We are rolling out a steady drumbeat of AI-focused communications to keep people informed and engaged. The first monthly AI Newsletter will be released in September and we have a regular monthly cadence on the weekly manager's huddle targeting 225 people managers in Corporates. This will be supplemented by an Atrium page serving as a one-stop hub for AI in Corporates (resources, FAQs, contacts), which is slated to go live in late September. 

Cultural Shift Initiatives: Changing mindsets is as important as changing processes. We’re cultivating a culture where experimenting with AI is celebrated. In team meetings, managers now routinely ask for an “AI moment” – e.g., “Has anyone used an AI tool in a new way this week?” – to spark peer sharing
Path Forward: Sustain Adoption and Accelerate Innovation. As we head into the fall, driving adoption of our AI tools across 100% of the team remains the top priority. Our company-wide goal is full AI tool usage by year-end, and we aim to achieve this through encouragement and enablement rather than mandate. In practice, this means continuing the high-touch approach in place: regular manager huddles spotlighting AI wins, more office hours and training (e.g. Gong sessions, Path-to-Plan tutorials), and the launch of monthly AI newsletters and an Atrium site to share tips and success stories segment-wide.

Executive Summary:
TAAP is executing a comprehensive strategy to drive AI adoption, productivity, and sales effectiveness through internal AI usage, Gong optimization, and targeted enablement. With a year-end goal of 100% active AI usage, we are leveraging dashboards, new hire AI primer paths, and targeted workflow-centric enablement and training by role, tool, and use case to close usage gaps.

Enhanced Training & Enablement: Our training initiatives now include targeted enablement for GTM roles in Gong and mandatory Gong MindTickle modules for new reps and managers, to help them get started w/ Gong. We are also working with GTM leads and central teams to create comprehensive resource hubs relevant to all GTM segments—not just TAAP—for both Gong and enterprise accessible internal AI tools and resources of relevance to the GTM teams.

Gong AI Use Cases: Gong's AI agents are now central to our rep & manager productivity strategy, including:
-Custom AI briefs that synthesize calls, deals, and accounts for structured knowledge transfer
-Prompt frameworks leveraging AI Call Reviewer for enhanced coaching and AI Deal Reviewer for pipeline qualification
-AI alerts and warnings through Deal Monitor for pipeline health and Deal Predictor for closing likelihood
-Gong AI Transcript analyzer for Product teams to extract conversation insights by product (solution currently in Beta - owned by Commercial Excellence)

Other AI Initiatives:
-Aura Copilot discovery (owned by central teams) enabling Seismic users to query sales tools and resources
-ACES Customer Research tool enhancements for pre-call planning across all segments (currently in pilot, owned by Commercial Excellence)

Strategic Expansion: These AI agents eliminate manual work and enhance productivity by integrating seamlessly into GTM workflows, creating an integrated, workflow-centric approach that makes users more effective and efficient in their rep and managerial responsibilities.

Looking ahead, we are prioritizing the latter half of 2025 and early 2026 to focus on non-quota carrying roles and functions, identifying AI opportunities for activities that can be tech-enabled or leverage AI automation.

Key Focus Areas:
-Change management and targeted enablement efforts
-Gong coaching optimization to drive rep performance
-Pipeline management through AI-driven insights and alerts
-Leveraging Gong AI for rep productivity to impact sales metrics and OKRs
-Expanding discovery and AI use case exploration for non-quota carrying roles

This integrated approach positions us to achieve our 100% active usage goal while building scalable AI capabilities across the TAAP organization.

Adoption Gaps: Continued risk of non-compliance with AI usage goals among certain user groups.

AI Tool Integration Limitations: Ex: Gainsight R360 integration is dependent on platform readiness and the C360 integration with Gong was not useful to TAAP.

Resource Hub Fragmentation & Duplication: GTM AI business leads across segments are independently creating resource hubs and curating Gong enablement resources, tools, and videos that could benefit all teams. This creates inefficiency and duplication of efforts. We recommend the central team responsible for Gong ownership create a unified resource hub accessible through Advisor, with capability to link out to segment-specific pages highlighting unique use cases and success stories.

Seismic Aura Copilot Delays: No visible progress updates on the Seismic Aura Copilot bot deployment for Advisor, which would enable sales reps to quickly query and find resources and information through an AI-powered interface. Central teams need to help accelerate this initiative as it benefits all segment GTM teams and is owned by Commercial Excellence.
