Executive Summary:
The GCO is exploring all of the below:
Contract Review and Compliance: AI to be utilized for reviewing contracts to ensure compliance, manage obligations, and redline third-party NDAs against policies. Bulk contract reviews are being tested using CoCounsel High Volume.
Automation of Legal Processes: AI to automate tasks such as drafting correspondence for breaches of terms, creating chronologies of events from documents, and sending intake requests to HighQ, saving time and improving accuracy.
Self-Service Information Access: Chatbots are being tested across Practice Groups to provide self-serve business information. 
Enhancements in Legal Tracker: Working with the Legal Tracker product team to leverage AI for budgeting, reporting, and duplicate line-item reviews in invoices.
Development of AI-Assisted Playbooks: AI to assist in creating and updating comprehensive playbooks with pro-customer and pro-supplier arguments, streamlining the process of legal strategy documentation.
Key Risks and Issues:
Technology Integration Risks: Potential risks include challenges in integrating AI tools like CoCounsel into existing systems (e.g., High Q sites) and ensuring seamless interaction between tools for document production and summarization. Issues may arise in automating workflows for DSARs and privacy policy updates.
Compliance and Legal Risks: Concerns also include ensuring alignment between procurement and legal teams and addressing anomalies in contract negotiations.
Workflow Efficiency Risks: Challenges in leveraging AI for email workflows and timeline creation.
Contract Management Risks: Risks include inaccuracies in extracting contract data, automating contract templates, and redlining capabilities. Ensuring comprehensive playbook development and addressing non-negotiables in contract clauses are critical focus areas.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
The PCSI function continues to advance AI-driven transformation across Talent Acquisition, HR Services, Communications, and Other AI Experimentation. In Talent Acquisition, pilot programs for BrightHire and LinkedIn Hiring Assistant are ongoing, with feedback loops established to inform future adoption and investment decisions. The Open Arena-powered AI Recruiter Summary tool is live, though recruiter adoption remains low, prompting ongoing reviews of user feedback. HiredScore is under evaluation, with a submitted business case pending review. HR Services has successfully completed pilot testing of content governance tools, initiated migration planning for HR policies, and transitioned regional case management operations, showing steady improvements in resolution timelines and NPS scores. HRX (Regional HR) delivered key task analysis recommendations and is conducting deep-dives into complex processes for further refinement.
Communications workstreams have completed AI tool testing on 30 use cases and are actively experimenting with platforms such as WRITER and DAVE AI, with a Global Communications AI-focused event scheduled to source additional use cases. The team is accelerating implementation and rollout plans to integrate AI across the function. Other AI Experimentation includes successful launches of My AI Coach and new Workday features supporting talent, feedback, and learning management, with usage metrics indicating strong engagement. Several projects, such as Talent Highlights, are on hold pending vendor updates, while ongoing development and feature testing continue across CoCounsel, Copilot, People.ai, and Workday illuminate.
Key Risks and Issues:
Talent Acquisition faces dependencies on internal technical capacity, adoption lags among recruiters, and ongoing confirmation of data privacy and CIO support for new tools. Integration and configuration efforts are subject to resource availability, which may impact timelines for tool deployment. HR Services is addressing challenges in updating user information, security permission workflows, and regional variations that could delay automation milestones and standardization. Pending access revocations and operational dependencies in regional HR admin activities require immediate attention to avoid capacity constraints and inefficiencies.
HRX's progress is contingent on timely delivery and alignment of consolidated recommendations, with external data dependencies posing risks to project timelines and completeness. Achieving consensus with stakeholder groups on complex processes is critical to delivering actionable outcomes. Communications workstreams are challenged by competing priorities and limited time for team members to engage with new AI solutions. For Other AI Experimentation, ongoing risks include adoption challenges, integration complexity, and reliance on vendor updates for stalled initiatives.
Progress on Use Case this period:
PCSI function demonstrated notable progress in advancing its AI-enabled use cases across Talent Acquisition, HR Services, Communications, and broader AI Experimentation. Talent Acquisition continued its evaluation and pilot activities, with the BrightHire pilot extended through July and LinkedIn Hiring Assistant engaging 20 recruiters globally until September. The Open Arena-powered AI Recruiter Summary tool achieved full deployment, though user adoption remains under review, and HiredScore's candidate scoring solution progressed through business case submission and ongoing evaluation. HR Services made substantial headway with the completion of content governance tool pilots, the initiation of country HR policy migration planning, and steady improvements in case management operations across multiple regions, reflected in positive resolution timelines and NPS scores.
Communications further expanded its experimentation efforts, successfully testing 30 AI-driven use cases and preparing for a major Global Communications AI-focused event to drive future adoption. The team leveraged platforms such as WRITER, DAVE AI, and Transperfect to enhance content creation and translation workflows, while laying the groundwork for accelerated rollout and increased engagement. Other AI Experimentation saw the launch of My AI Coach to all employees, with over 4,800 users engaged, and new Workday features supporting talent management, feedback, and learning content summarization. Although some projects, like Talent Highlights, remain on hold pending vendor updates, the period was marked by strong momentum in piloting, adopting, and refining AI solutions to drive operational efficiency and user experience across the PCSI portfolio.
Details on Change Management:
Change management efforts in Talent Acquisition include continual messaging on AI use cases through various forums, bi-weekly office hours, and dedicated launch communications and training for each new tool. HR Services has prepared comprehensive communication and training plans for content owners and maintains sustained stakeholder engagement through regular meetings, targeted sessions, and operational alignment. Regional HR teams are actively partnering to support case management transitions and validation processes.
Communications has advanced experimentation with AI to improve delivery and efficiency.
Path Forward:
Talent Acquisition will complete the BrightHire pilot and present findings to leadership, while continuing to drive recruiter adoption of AI tools and monitor pilot progress for LinkedIn Hiring Assistant. The team will finalize HiredScore evaluations in alignment with Workday renewal discussions and refine reporting cadence in collaboration with People Analytics. HR Services is focused on implementing feedback from pilot testing, rolling out governance tools, and migrating HR policies to Workday, with automation initiatives targeting a 40% increase in workflow efficiency for GHS by end state.
HRX will review and formalize consolidated recommendations, present findings to leadership, and continue data collection to support process improvements. Communications will expand AI experimentation, evaluate new tools, and develop engagement plans to drive regular usage and productivity gains, while refining methodologies for measuring impact. Other AI Experimentation will continue promoting new features, conduct further pilot testing, and develop additional use cases, including policy agents and data automation solutions, ensuring alignment with broader HR initiatives and compliance requirements.
Questions / Assistance Needed from the W: There are no questions or assistance needed from the Working Group at this time.

Executive Summary:
Our Editorial organization is executing a comprehensive AI transformation strategy, combining immediate operational gains with strategic positioning for future growth. As we move into the agentic space, we are expanding our vision to include AI systems that not only assist but also act autonomously within defined editorial parameters—amplifying our ability to scale, adapt, and lead.

Our AI initiatives in 2025 focus on efficiency gains, simplification, and agentic enablement to support our four core strategic priorities:

Increased Content Currency
Enhanced Value Addition to Content
AI-Ready Content
Coverage Expansion

Primary Focus Areas:

Authored Content Updating
Four funded AI builds are in development for 2025, positioning us for resource optimization advances. These systems are being designed with agentic capabilities in mind—able to proactively identify and update content based on editorial triggers.


Editorial Assistant Automation
Two funded AI builds are in development for 2025. These tools streamline time-intensive, repetitive tasks, enhance consistency and quality, and free specialized resources for high-value activities. As we evolve, these assistants will increasingly operate with more autonomy, initiating actions based on editorial context.


Editorial Expertise
We continue to leverage our unique intellectual capital to position ourselves as leaders in Legal and Tax AI innovation. Our move into agentic systems further differentiates us, enabling AI to act on editorial knowledge rather than just respond to it.


Self-Service AI Solutions
Through “Fast Track” implementation, we empower editorial teams with AI-enhanced capabilities that improve precision and quality.
Key Risks and Issues:
Issue: Resources - certain key resources have been tapped to work on additional/alternative projects, and this will impact our projects to some degree.
Risk: Copyright risk persists; but process is in place to track and manage this.
Progress on Use Case this period:
Our Self-Service AI Solution strategy, which we call the "Fast Track" lane has continues to deliver smaller scale, but still impactful AI solutions to drive both efficiencies as well as quality consistency across a variety teams within our Editorial organization.  At the conclusion of Q3 we have now launched almost 50 solutions to "in use" status.  This rapid uptick in delivery resulted from an adjustment to our risk assessment process and the increasing familiarity, comfort with, and skill level of editors with AI tools they can use.  The connection between "theory" and "practice" is being actively wired and this is proof of that.  

Delivery dates of beta releases for our cutting-edge Commentary Content updating approach has been finalized and the final development effort to connect the different systems together are underway. (We now have proven that Commentary Analytical Articles can be drafted in the first instance by Gen AI as opposed to using external authors.  The complexity of the problem the Content Innovation team in our Content Engineering organization has developed a solution for revolutionizes both the approach to creating this content, but as importantly it will allow us to transform this product offering into a much more current and timelier content product for the benefit of our customers.  The build to bring this game changing approach to production is currently underway.)

The Care updating project in the Commentary space has also progressed to connecting plumbing and getting additional end users feedback on system designs.

In our Practical Law space, the Content Updating use case continues to progress towards the end-to-end solution for delivery and is being integrated into the new Content Development UI tool positioning us for an end of year beta release.

The Editorial Assistant use cases which support our Practical Law Editors have progressed as resources were able to rejoin the team, and we are optimistic we will have betas for these features in the next month or two.

The dedicated Codes Reimagine POC completed its first delivery related to the publication of Idaho Bills content using agentic technology.  This is a small step for the program, but a giant leap for establishing the framework and approach the team will use for this entire project.

Finally, we are finalizing our delivery pipeline for 2026, outlining the key initiatives we will pursue and working to solidify our teams, requirements, and priorities so we can start the work.
Details on Change Management:
New Change Management lead for Content & Editorial has joined the Internal AI program.
Continue to leverage established communication and learning approaches (newsletters, dedicated atrium site, team meeting presentations, clinics, town halls, trainings, etc).
Path Forward: As we near the betas for each of our large releases, we are partnering closely to ensure we have a solid plan for rolling the features out to the various teams, establishing the protocols for feedback, and ensuring we have a clear change management and onboarding plan in place.  We are also positioning the technology teams to be able to address any urgent feedback that needs to be addressed prior to a full roll out.

Executive Summary: Additional use cases identified and underway for Product Management, Product Design, and Tax Research Content. Will continue to assess scope/usage and perform tests and experiments into second half of 2025.  Will assess financial savings in Q3/Q4 2025.
Key Risks and Issues:
RISK: Dynamic nature of product management role and activity, based on outcomes rather than outputs, make harder to find one single metric that can be utilized to single out efficiency gains by using AI. While we see the adoption of AI in these roles, it’s harder to estimate impact only based on time-savings dimension.
RISK: Also connected with the above, there are limited specific AI tools for Product Managers, and some may even increase complexity or force strict processes. While we evaluate options to implement a no-code prototyping tool or product management system, our current hypothesis is that generic tools (like Copilot / AI Platform Open Arena) might be best suited for the role – and we may create specific prompts or agents for the specific use cases that we target.
Progress on Use Case this period:
Five Product Manager use cases are being tracked in Launch stage, three in the Experimentation stage, and five in Ideation stage to be integrated into the product management workflow in support of the Product Operating Model. Product Requirements Document (PRD) Assistant and ADO User Story Builder, ADO Epic & Feature Builder, and Release Notes Generator are Launched, all leveraging both Open Arena and Copilot Chat Agent tools promoted on the Atrium, to the Innovation Team, and Product Manager Copilot license holders for feedback. AI for Product Management Tools Trial is in progress, examining via POC 4 no-code AI prototyping tools for product manager use; recommendation ETA by end of Sept.

Product Design continued to expand AI-assisted use cases with an active focus on the "Prototyping+" program trial. September marked a significant milestone with the recommendation to approve v0 by Vercel for a 1 year term as the primary prototyping+ tool for builders for ideation, collaboration, and communication. Builder licenses will be distributed across Product Design (260) and Product Management (40), enabling teams to continue exploration of advanced prototyping use cases such as multi-step user journeys, accessibility review, and collaborative prototyping across UX, content, research, and engineering roles. We are actively sourcing additional use cases, partnering with teams across design to benchmark and reimagine processes and identify opportunities for transformation. Feedback and tool evaluations remain ongoing, with early anecdotal signs of improvements in cross-functional collaboration and faster decision-making. We are seeing great progress in these efforts directly supporting the Product Operating Model by embedding prototyping into early-stage workflows and encouraging scalable experimentation.

In Tax Content Research, we have developed a comprehensive list of AI use cases across all of the teams.  We have prioritized the top cases that will have the largest impact.  We held AWS AI workshops on Direct Tax and Global Trade to determine the biggest areas where AI would have the largest efficiency gains. From this, we are scheduling EBA workshops with AWS to develop POCs on the top 2 areas.  In Direct Tax, we now have a YOY comparison tool.  With AWS, we are building an AI chain that will filter the differences down to those items where changes have to be made in the calculations.  Once developed, we will hook this up a script which we have created that will create the ADO user stories.  We are also hiring two AI Engineers to begin working on those identified use case that need AI agents developed or where Analsyst need assistance on writing code for the AI chains that have been developed.
Details on Change Management: Product Management, Design and Tax Research are focused on engagement for product manager, content analysts, and design-focused solutions via comms, Atrium page and Viva Engage community launch, Innovation Teams, office hours, AI solution and tools focused trainings, expansion of Copilot license activation and promotion, and 3rd party tools trials.  In addition, for Tax & Trade Content Research, we will need to develop reimagined workflows and so additional AI Engineers are needed and being hired.
Path Forward:
Product Management path forward is to enhance existing AI solutions via Open Arena models and Copilot capabilities, while continuing innovation discovery and experimentation toward development of new use cases following the Product Operating Model, and in parallel exploring external AI-prototyping tools via "future of product management" tools trials, in collaboration with Design and Product Engineering cross-functional partners.

For Product Design, we plan to scale adoption of AI-assisted prototyping with deeper dives into Figma Make, Figma's AI solution, in addition to integration of v0 by Vercel to accelerate concept testing and customer iteration cycles. The team is shifting a bit from tool experimentation to strategic integration into the TR enterprise with architecture and security reviews underway. The hope is to enable teams to focus on high-impact product market business use cases that highlight measurable time-to-value outcomes. Synthesis of survey feedback from trails will continue to inform tooling decisions and identify opportunities for reimagining new workflows into 2026.

For Tax Research (Content), we are continuing to work on progress with the development of AI chains for the use cases prioritized.  We have identified a gap in skills and so are hiring 2-3 AI Engineers to help push forward the cases which are more complex in development.
Lead: Perez, Pablo (TR Product);Shaler, Sara (TR Product);Abadir, Nadia (TR Product);Coleman, Claudia B. (TR Product);Howard, Robert (TR Product);West, Jennifer (TR Product);Noriega, Jude (TR Product)

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
The CodeRed Program successfully concluded, achieving an 81% AI Development Tools adoption rate (a 27% increase in four months) and receiving a 4.8/5 effectiveness rating for team engagement, driven by strong communication, demonstrations, and support. High-frequency usage, now at 26%, demonstrates significant integration into productivity, with GitHub Copilot and ClaudeCode showing sustained engagement. 

Key results include enhanced leadership visibility via new weekly dashboards and a successful Toronto ClaudeCode workshop that fostered 12 cross-functional modernization use cases. This workshop model will be scaled to Bangalore, Hyderabad, and Eagan to further drive modernization initiatives using AI Development Tools.
Key Risks and Issues:
1. While open-source tools like CLINE offer potential for faster code development, they present risks of IP loss and harm to TR systems. To mitigate these, we are limiting their use to internal Large Language Models (LLMs) such as LiteLLM, employing development containers for isolation, and implementing robust auditing. Guidelines are available here: https://trten.sharepoint.com/sites/intr-isrm-business-and-product-security/SitePages/Securing-the-AI-coding-tool-chain.aspx
2. Developer surveys highlight that while AI effectively handles planning and execution of development tasks, it demonstrably lacks capabilities in ideation and strategic thinking. Consequently, it is imperative to retain a human-in-the-loop for reviewing AI-generated output, moving beyond sole reliance on it as a definitive source.
Progress on Use Case this period:
* CodeRed Program concluded early September with 81% AI developer tool adoption (27% increase since May kickoff)
* High-frequency usage reached 26% (10% increase since July); GitHub Copilot leads adoption, Cursor and Cline gaining traction
* Program effectiveness rated 4.4/5 by leaders; communication channels rated 4.8/5
* PE Internal AI dashboard now updates weekly for leadership visibility
* Toronto ClaudeCode hackathon (Sept 9) delivered 83% success rate across 12 use cases with 100+ participants
Details on Change Management: None
Path Forward:
* From Toronto workshop, 4 strategic projects identified for follow-on presentations, including legacy modernization and reusable Angular frameworks
* ClaudeCode workshops scheduled for Bangalore and Hyderabad on October 10th,  MSP (Eagan) session planning underway to extend reach
* Continue leveraging weekly dashboards to drive sustained adoption and identify opportunities
* Scale successful hackathon use cases (legacy modernization, automation frameworks) across broader engineering teams
* Monitor emerging tool adoption trends (Cursor, Cline) and adjust enablement strategy accordingly

Overall Status: Amber - Delay/Risk/Challenges
Executive Summary: The Newsroom AI program has made significant strides this period, notably with the integration of non-corporate alerting into FactGenie, the launch of a new multilingual CheckMATE UI for translation, now supporting five languages, and the successful launch of Super Summaries for LSEG. Content production such as Drafting AI Assistant and Co-Producer, experienced delays. Co-Producer's delivery of MVP is now expected mid-October. Video understanding initiatives faced challenges due to unclear workflows and technical debt. Overall, the team continues to refine its approach to prompt tuning, product integration, and change management to drive greater adoption and impact.
Key Risks and Issues: Key risks include persistent delays in the delivery of critical tools such as Co-Producer and Drafting AI Assistant, and significant technical debt and team structure challenges impeding video understanding advancements. These issues could impact overall timelines and the ability to meet business objectives. Mitigation efforts include ongoing discussions to clarify end-states, increased collaboration between product and editorial teams, and focused change management activities to boost user engagement.
Progress on Use Case this period: Progress was achieved in integrating non-corporate alerting into FactGenie, providing a model for future journalist and data scientist collaboration, and launching the CheckMATE UI for translation, which now supports five languages with plans for further expansion. Super Summaries were successfully launched for LSEG, publishing across 1,500 companies. However, Drafting AI Assistant and Co-Producer experienced delays, with Drafting shifting to a custom-built solution and Co-Producer's timeline moved to mid-October. Packaging encountered obstacles due to workflow ambiguities and asset association model delays, while video understanding remains stalled due to team structure and technical debt.
Details on Change Management: Change management is advancing with targeted interventions planned for October, focusing on zero and low users through three training formats: general office hours for support, in-person classroom-style demonstrations, and manager-focused sessions to ensure clarity and alignment. These efforts are concentrated in London and New York, where user engagement is currently lowest, aiming to drive adoption and maximize the impact of AI solutions across the organization.
Path Forward: The immediate focus is on accelerating the delivery of MVPs for Drafting AI Assistant and Co-Producer, resolving workflow and asset association issues in Packaging, and addressing technical and structural challenges in video understanding. Continued expansion of translation capabilities and prompt tuning cycles will support further newsroom and agency development. Change management efforts will intensify, especially targeting low-usage teams in London and New York through tailored training and support sessions to ensure broader adoption and effective utilization of AI tools. The plan is still to close off Packaging, Translation and FactGenie as tracked workstreams by the end of the year.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
1. CoCounsel 2.0 and CoCounsel Drafting Implementation

CoCounsel 2.0 was deployed in Q1, with CoCounsel Drafting scheduled for deployment by the end of Q3-2025. An updated CoCounsel Prompts Library will be deployed to support Sourcing and Supplier & Contract Managers on their contract review and contract drafting activities (October 17). The primary focus for these teams will be Contract Comparison documents, which represents the most time-consuming task in their workflow.

Continuous Improvement Plan (Q4): The CoCounsel Drafting strategy includes potential integrations with Contract Express for template automation and Practical Law for legal playbook automation.

2. RFP Template Generation MVP

The solution is being split into two distinct use cases:

2.1 RFP Proposal Responses Summarization (Delivery: October 2025):
Specific Outcomes: Versatile proposal summarization AI workflow adaptable to multiple proposal categories while maintaining quality standards
MVP Definition: Initial version with clear boundaries around proposal types and complexity levels
Continuous Improvement Plan: Extended version with an AI Agent featuring real-time guidance and RFP FAQ automation

2.2 Intelligent RFP Template Generator (Delivery: Q4 2025):
Concept: Prompt-based testing with available LLMs will assess the feasibility and quality of AI-generated RFP content. If AI output proves unsatisfactory, focus will shift to developing modular, category-specific templates
The original MVP for collaborative RFP template generation was successfully configured in Kronos V2, with UAT completed in May and go-live achieved in the last week of June. With our expertise in Copilot Studio, we are now scaling the solution for comprehensive RFP analysis and generation.

3. Services Gateway Chatbot Development

This development is being split into separate AI agents:

3.1 Travel & Expenses Agent: Deployment scheduled for October 2025

3.2 Procurement Agent:
Focus: E2E Process Orchestration: Deployment scheduled for November 2025
Specific Outcomes: Intelligent agent streamlining end-to-end procurement journey with real-time guidance and FAQ automation
MVP Definition: AI agent in Copilot Studio orchestrating procurement workflows, integrating with existing H2O systems
Timeline: MVP delivery by end of September with continuous improvements in Q4
Continuous Improvement Plan: Incorporate new procurement policy for compliance capabilities upon availability
We are currently developing our internal governance model for AI agents and compiling a comprehensive list of potential use cases to be developed through Q3-H1 2026.
Key Risks and Issues:
- Complex system integration risks: Integrating the AI solutions with existing systems, databases, and workflows.​
- User Adoption and change management risks: Resistance to change or difficulties in understanding and using the new solution could hinder project success.​
- Technical risk: Algorithm complexity could delay or impact the effectiveness of the solution."
Progress on Use Case this period: In August, Services achieved 73% utilization of key AI tools (CoCounsel V2, OpenArena, MS Copilot 365, and MS Copilot Chat), with CoCounsel V2 reaching 53% adoption among Sourcing and Supplier & Contract Managers, contributing with use cases and opportunities to the Client Zero strategy.
Details on Change Management:
CoCounsel (Next Steps):
•	CoCounsel Core 2.0 Rollout: Phased upgrades through the end of 2025 as they become available.
•	Explore and deploy CoCounsel Drafting
Path Forward:
Q3 Progress & Outlook: The Travel & Expenses AI Agent pilot has been rescheduled from July to September, with development now underway for a Procurement Agent focused on E2E process orchestration. CoCounsel Drafting deployment remains on track for end of Q3-2025, with an updated CoCounsel Prompts Library specifically designed to support contract comparison activities - the most time-intensive task for our Sourcing and Contract Management teams.

RFP Automation Expansion: Following successful UAT completion and June go-live of our RFP Template Generation MVP in Kronos V2, we are now scaling the solution into two specialized use cases: RFP Proposal Responses Summarization (September delivery) and Intelligent RFP Template Generator (Q4 delivery), leveraging our Copilot Studio expertise.

Q4 Strategic Initiatives: Plans include CoCounsel Drafting continuous improvements with potential Contract Express and Practical Law integrations, expanded AI Agents across E2E Procurement, and the Procurement Agent MVP with real-time guidance capabilities integrated with existing H2O systems. Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary:
TAAP is executing a comprehensive strategy to drive AI adoption, productivity, and sales effectiveness through internal AI usage, Gong optimization, and targeted enablement. With a year-end goal of 100% active AI usage, we are leveraging dashboards, new hire AI primer paths, and targeted workflow-centric enablement and training by role, tool, and use case to close usage gaps.

Enhanced Training & Enablement: Our training initiatives now include targeted enablement for GTM roles in Gong and mandatory Gong MindTickle modules for new reps and managers, to help them get started w/ Gong. We are also working with GTM leads and central teams to create comprehensive resource hubs relevant to all GTM segments—not just TAAP—for both Gong and enterprise accessible internal AI tools and resources of relevance to the GTM teams.

Gong AI Use Cases: Gong's AI agents are now central to our rep & manager productivity strategy, including:
-Custom AI briefs that synthesize calls, deals, and accounts for structured knowledge transfer
-Prompt frameworks leveraging AI Call Reviewer for enhanced coaching and AI Deal Reviewer for pipeline qualification
-AI alerts and warnings through Deal Monitor for pipeline health and Deal Predictor for closing likelihood
-Gong AI Transcript analyzer for Product teams to extract conversation insights by product (solution currently in Beta - owned by Commercial Excellence)
-AI generated meeting prep

Other AI Initiatives:
-Aura Copilot discovery (owned by central teams) enabling Seismic users to query sales tools and resources
-ACES Customer Research tool enhancements for pre-call planning across all segments (currently in pilot, owned by Commercial Excellence)

Strategic Expansion: These AI agents eliminate manual work and enhance productivity by integrating seamlessly into GTM workflows, creating an integrated, workflow-centric approach that makes users more effective and efficient in their rep and managerial responsibilities.

Looking ahead, we are prioritizing the latter half of 2025 and early 2026 to focus on non-quota carrying roles and functions, identifying AI opportunities for activities that can be tech-enabled or leverage AI automation.

Key Focus Areas:
-Change management and targeted enablement efforts
-Gong coaching optimization to drive rep performance
-Pipeline management through AI-driven insights and alerts
-Leveraging Gong AI for rep productivity to impact sales metrics and OKRs
-Expanding discovery and AI use case exploration for non-quota carrying roles

This integrated approach positions us to achieve our 100% active usage goal while building scalable AI capabilities across the TAAP organization.
Key Risks and Issues:
Adoption Gaps: Continued risk of non-compliance with AI usage goals among certain user groups.

Need visibility and access to non active users (blocked due to RLS) to help drive 100% usage.

Resource Hub Fragmentation & Duplication: GTM AI business leads across segments are independently creating resource hubs and curating Gong enablement resources, tools, and videos that could benefit all teams. This creates inefficiency and duplication of efforts. We recommend the central team responsible for Gong ownership create a unified resource hub accessible through Advisor, with capability to link out to segment-specific pages highlighting unique use cases and success stories.

Seismic Aura Copilot Delays: No visible progress updates on the Seismic Aura Copilot bot deployment for Advisor, which would enable sales reps to quickly query and find resources and information through an AI-powered interface. Central teams need to help accelerate this initiative as it benefits all segment GTM teams and is owned by Commercial Excellence.

Overall Status: Green - As per plan or better
Executive Summary: As we closed out Q3 2025, the Corporates segment continued to advance its internal AI enablement journey. We maintained focus on driving adoption of our AI tools across all teams, emphasizing Gong, Microsoft 365 Copilot, and other productivity enhancers. In September, we built on prior rollouts by turning to engagement and usage – ensuring that employees integrate AI into daily work to unlock productivity gains and improved customer outcomes. These efforts keep us aligned with TR’s enterprise goal of 100% active AI tool usage by end of 2025, ultimately supporting higher sales productivity and Net Revenue Retention through smarter, AI-driven workflows
Key Risks and Issues:
The biggest risk to our internal AI program remains uneven adoption. A subset of employees still have not engaged with any of the AI tools, which could jeopardize our 100% adoption target and limit the segment’s overall productivity gains. We are addressing this through targeted outreach and training, but resistance to change and fear of the unknown remain obstacles in a few pockets. We also note that Gong usage is lagging behind expectations – if teams do not consistently record calls or use Gong’s features, we won’t fully realize the benefits of conversational intelligence. This under-utilization has been identified as a critical gap, so leadership is now setting clearer expectations that Gong become part of standard sales routines.

Another issue encountered in September was data quality and trust. When rolling out the Revenue Intelligence dashboards, we faced some data integration issues (e.g. user role mappings and quota data mismatches) that delayed the roll-out and caused initial skepticism. While we resolved the major discrepancies (and instituted a faster data update process to prevent recurrences), this highlighted the importance of reliable data for AI tools – any lingering accuracy issues could undermine user trust in AI insights. 

We’re also mindful of change fatigue. With several new tools introduced this year, employees may feel overwhelmed or confused about where to focus. There’s a risk that without careful coordination, our messages urging use of Gong, Copilot, Revenue Intelligence, etc. could blend into noise. To mitigate this, we are streamlining communications (e.g., a single newsletter, consolidated training site) and pacing our initiatives so as not to overload teams. Finally, on the horizon, licensing and support for Copilot could pose challenges – if demand for M365 Copilot accelerates faster than we can supply licenses or support users, it may cause frustration. We’re working with ETS to manage the trial-to-production transition carefully.
Progress on Use Case this period:
September saw a concerted push on Gong adoption. We launched a Gong resources page on Atrium with on-demand training, tip sheets, and FAQs to help teams maximize Gong’s AI-powered conversation intelligence. Sales and Customer Success teams engaged in role-specific Gong training sessions and began leveraging features like AI-generated call summaries and follow-up email drafts, streamlining their workflows. We also held leadership discussions (e.g. a CLT offsite on Sept 18) to review Gong usage data and share best practices – reinforcing how underutilization of Gong is a missed opportunity that we’re actively addressing. 

Finally, we continued leveraging Gainsight to drive customer success workflows with AI insights. While no new Gainsight features launched in September, usage remains strong and it’s fully integrated into our customer health and retention playbooks. Overall, the month’s focus shifted from introducing new tools to driving active usage of the ones we’ve deployed – setting the stage for tangible productivity wins in Q4
Details on Change Management:
September was a very active month for change management in Corporates, with several new programs and communications launched to drive awareness and adoption of AI tools:

Leadership Engagement: Segment leaders visibly championed AI adoption this month. At the September CLT offsite, our GM and leadership team reviewed AI usage metrics and discussed barriers to adoption, resulting in a clear mandate to their teams to increase usage of tools like Gong and Copilot. This top-down encouragement is proving effective, as managers are now including AI tool utilization in their team check-ins and funnel reviews (making AI a regular part of the conversation).

AI Newsletter Launch: We introduced the inaugural “AI@Work” monthly newsletter in early September, delivered to all ~1,600 team members. This communication showcases recent AI tool developments, quick tips, and success stories, and serves as a friendly guide for those who might not know where to start. The first issue included a welcome message from our segment AI champion (underscoring our vision and the personal value of adopting AI) and links to help resources. Response has been positive – employees have cited the newsletter as a useful one-stop update, and we plan to continue this publication to sustain awareness.

Champion Network: Our network of AI Champions (early adopters and power users across functions) continues to play a crucial role. Champions met twice this month to exchange tips and coordinate outreach. They’ve been pairing up with less active colleagues for 1:1 mentoring (“buddy system” for AI). We see promising results from this grassroots approach – for instance, a few account executives who were hesitant to use Gong are now regularly recording calls after a champion on their team walked them through it and shared the benefits they personally experienced.
Path Forward:
Looking ahead to Q4 2025, our priority is to accelerate full adoption and deepen the impact of AI tools in daily operations. We will intensify change management to convert the remaining hesitant users into active AI users, ensuring we hit our segment-wide usage goals. We also intend to broaden our internal use case library and success stories: in the coming weeks, we’ll spotlight how top performers are leveraging AI (e.g. Gong analytics driving deal coaching, Copilot reducing deck prep time) and share these wins across the segment to inspire peers.

In summary, the path forward is about driving usage depth (not just breadth), launching our remaining planned AI tool (ACES), and systematically capturing value. We will continue to refine our approach based on feedback and aim to enter 2026 with a fully AI-empowered workforce and proven results from these tools.

Executive Summary:
September marked significant advancement in CXD's AI transformation journey, with strategic pivots and operational achievements positioning the organization for accelerated Q4 delivery. The portfolio encompasses 10 active AI initiatives supporting over +1,900 FTE equivalent positions across customer service, agent productivity, and internal operations, with 73% maintaining green status despite complex technical integrations and regulatory challenges.

Momentum continues in AI transformation across CXD, with AI adoption reaching 77.9% of employees using AI tools daily (+1.8-point increase from previous month), significantly exceeding the 50% OKR target.

Customer Self-Service Excellence: WhatsApp Support for LatAm achieved breakthrough performance with 37% AI deflection rates (+7pp month-over-month) and 51% automated resolution without human intervention, validating the hybrid AI strategy while supporting 195 FTE coverage. The platform processed 31% reduction in monthly human contact demand, demonstrating scalable self-service adoption. Chatbot 2.0 strategically pivoted from internal RAG development to Coveo's generative AI solution, positioning for Q3 UltraTax deployment with targeted 80% accuracy rates. The India expansion remains strategically paused pending regulatory clearance, with continuous market monitoring for reentry opportunities.

Agent Productivity Transformation: Salesforce Einstein suite deployment reached 821 cumulative users across email generation (307 users), chat replies (159 users), and wrap-up summaries (154 users), with Service Cloud Voice achieving full operational status for GST/OIT teams on August 9th. Strategic decision to pause Service Cloud Voice expansion and redirect resources to Agentforce development reflects organizational agility in maximizing AI investment returns. Intelligent Assistant maintained stable 20% adoption across non-Salesforce environments, with Q4 expansion planned for 10 additional products including CheckPoint, SMART Audit, and Onvio Platform. Sherlock AI for US Tax achieved complete deployment on August 19th, strategically timed for fall peak readiness with 300 agents now accessing 18-month historical case resolution patterns.

Operational Performance Metrics: Platform utilization demonstrates strong adoption trajectories with Einstein Knowledge workflow supporting 360 users despite technical challenges requiring manual categorization fixes pending October permanent resolution. Customer to Cash initiatives completed Phase One LLM deployment for query analysis while advancing Phase Two autonomous case resolution capabilities, supporting 260 FTE positions across collections and research functions. Critical Q4 milestones include Agentforce platform launch, completion of 10-product Intelligent Assistant expansion, and implementation of multilingual call transcription QA for Spanish and Portuguese markets by October 15th. Strategic partnerships with Data Analytics teams revealed 30% engagement scores for live training versus 7.6% self-directed learning, informing future deployment strategies and demonstrating compounding effects on CSAT and Average Handle Time metrics.
Key Risks and Issues:
Technical Integration Challenges: Critical failures in AEM-Salesforce synchronization compromise Einstein Knowledge effectiveness, while Service Cloud Voice faces unresolved summarization and routing deficiencies blocking expansion. Customer to Cash encounters Google AI approval constraints, forcing alternative solutions that threaten Phase Two autonomous case handling and 260 FTE optimization targets.

Strategic Platform Uncertainties: Multiple architectural transitions create cascading risks—Chatbot 2.0's pivot to Coveo requires complete technical revalidation, AEM Cloud's deferral to late 2025 disrupts content automation planning, and Agentforce prioritization over Service Cloud Voice introduces resource reallocation challenges with potential cross-initiative delays.

Regulatory & Compliance Blockers: WhatsApp India remains indefinitely suspended pending regulatory clearance, eliminating market expansion opportunities. Multilingual QA faces October 15th deadline pressure, while cross-border data requirements restrict AI model training and knowledge base sharing across regions.

Resource & Dependency Constraints: Simultaneous Q4 commitments for 10-product Intelligent Assistant expansion, Agentforce deployment, and multi-team Einstein rollouts strain technical resources. Service Cloud Voice pause creates specialized skill gaps, while Customer to Cash's scope may require phased division, extending timelines and diluting delivery accountability.
Progress on Use Case this period:
WhatsApp LatAm Performance Leadership: Achieved exceptional operational metrics with AI deflection reaching 28% current (31% YTD) while automated resolution maintained 52% efficiency, successfully processing customer requests without human intervention. Platform demonstrated 25% improvement in Average Speed to Answer for chat transitions (4.8 minutes versus 6.4 minutes YTD), though customer AI engagement declined to 31% from 40% YTD requiring strategic attention. AI-assisted ticket resolution increased 19% month-over-month to 44%, validating the hybrid support model's effectiveness despite 27% decline in embedded AI usage attributed to Brazilian fiscal deadline seasonality.

Salesforce Ecosystem Advancement: Service Cloud Voice achieved critical milestone with GST/OIT teams transitioning to full operational status on August 9th, entering comprehensive hypercare phase throughout September to optimize performance and address case summarization and chat routing challenges. Einstein Knowledge workflow encountered AEM feed synchronization bug preventing optimal article recommendations, with manual categorization workaround implemented pending permanent Adobe fix scheduled for late October. Product team maintained intensive hands-on engagement ensuring generative AI replies and summarization features met business expectations across 821 deployed users.

Strategic Platform Pivots: Chatbot 2.0 executed major strategic realignment from internal Commercial Engine RAG to Coveo generative AI solution, fundamentally changing implementation approach while maintaining Q3 UltraTax deployment targets. Service Cloud Voice expansion strategically paused to prioritize Agentforce development, with teams reassigned to accelerate next-generation AI capabilities and establish infrastructure synergies for 2026 re-evaluation. Help and Support Content Acceleration initiative deferred pending late 2025 AEM Cloud migration, requiring complete strategy redefinition and Q4 discovery phase planning.

Intelligent Assistant Expansion: Continued deployment progress across non-Salesforce products with internal article search successfully launching in August, maintaining stable 20% adoption rates since December while preparing for Q4 ten-product expansion. Sherlock AI achieved full GST/OIT deployment as of August 19th, strategically positioned for fall peak season with comprehensive monitoring capturing feedback and usage metrics through interactive dashboards developed with WFM and Data Analytics teams.

Innovation Delivery Milestones: Open Arena integration scheduled for September 30th completion enabling Argentine Onvio platform customers to access AI-powered self-service capabilities. AI Innovation Squad training program concluding October 2nd with implementation-ready project selection, while multilingual call transcription QA for Spanish and Portuguese markets targets October 15th launch. Go-to-Market Hackathon successfully concluded, identifying multiple AI automation proposals for November 24th implementation deadline.

Customer to Cash Evolution: Phase One LLM deployment completed successfully, analyzing and categorizing customer queries with root cause analysis capabilities using OpenArena and Cloud AI integration through Data Lake architecture. Phase Two autonomous agent development progressing despite Google AI technical constraints, exploring alternative solutions for SAP and Service Cloud case resolution automation while considering phased approach to manage broad scope and high case volumes.
Details on Change Management:
Momentum continues in AI transformation across CXD, with AI adoption reaching 77.9% of employees using AI tools regularly in their work (+1.8-point increase from previous month), continuing our steady progress toward our 100% adoption by year-end goal. This increase reflects successful deployment of additional AI tools and effective communication channels promoting AI learning opportunities and innovative applications. 

The 2025 AI Communications plan continues with the AI Spark newsletter showing declining engagement across approximately 2,300 recipients. Value being reconsidered through a comprehensive assessment that will evaluate current performance metrics, stakeholder feedback from AI leads across CXD business areas, and content effectiveness to determine how the AI Spark program will evolve and adapt strategic approaches for increased engagement levels.

The CXD InnovAItion Hub demonstrates exceptional grassroots innovation with 91 total ideas submitted, 66% scored and reviewed, 41% identified as high-potential initiatives, and 70 showing cross-team applicability. Upcoming enhancements are being targeted during Q4 2025 that will include additional metadata attributes for an expanded overview around the hub.

CXD continues participating in the Claude.ai pilot with 13+ use cases being tested by approximately 36 users. Early feedback trending positive, especially around visualizations and project-based sharing capabilities. The pilot has achieved notable success with three functional automation scripts implemented for report generation, comment analysis, and file management. Testing results show a 92% success rate across 50 completed project management test cases with strong user adoption for playbooks, templates, and process analysis, though most use cases remain in discovery phases as teams continue learning and expanding AI integration.

Demand for Microsoft 365 Copilot licenses remains consistently high, with usage monitoring showing sustained high utilization and effective license recycling practices to maximize organizational benefit.

Training Optimization Strategy: Critical insights show live training sessions achieve 30% engagement versus 7.6% for self-directed learning, with measurable impacts on CSAT and handle times. This data drives mandatory instructor-led training for complex deployments like Sherlock AI and Intelligent Assistant, ensuring proficiency before peak season demands.

Deployment Support Framework: Comprehensive hypercare programs for Service Cloud Voice and Sherlock AI provide intensive monitoring and hands-on support throughout September. GST/OIT teams received dedicated assistance ensuring stable AI workflow adoption, while continuous feedback loops inform interface improvements and training refinements based on actual user experience data.

Leadership Communication & Engagement: Executive teams actively manage expectations through transparent updates on platform pivots (Chatbot 2.0 to Coveo, Service Cloud Voice to Agentforce), while AI Innovation Squad sessions and Go-to-Market Hackathon participation maintain organizational momentum. Success stories like WhatsApp's 37% deflection rates build confidence despite technical challenges.

Adoption Monitoring & Intervention: WFM and Data Analytics partnerships provide real-time dashboards tracking engagement metrics, enabling targeted interventions for plateaued adoption (Intelligent Assistant at 20%, Customer AI declining to 31% YTD). Peer champion programs and success story sharing address resistance while dedicated support channels assist struggling users in achieving demonstrated productivity gains.
Path Forward:
Q4 2025 Execution: Complete 10-product Intelligent Assistant expansion (Checkpoint, SMART, ProView, Onvio suite) alongside Agentforce deployment, with multilingual QA launch by October 15th and Open Arena Argentine integration by September 30th for fall peak readiness.

Platform Strategy Alignment: Finalize AEM Cloud and Agentforce discovery by November 30th, establishing unified AI architecture across Coveo, Einstein, and Open Arena platforms to maximize cross-platform synergies and eliminate redundancies while defining clear 2026 ROI projections.

Adoption Acceleration: Mandate instructor-led training based on proven 30% engagement rates, targeting 40% platform adoption by Q1 2026 through peer mentorship and success campaigns focused on recovering Customer AI engagement and breaking Intelligent Assistant's 20% plateau.

Performance Targets: Achieve 45% WhatsApp deflection and 60% automated resolution by year-end through fall peak data optimization, while implementing permanent Einstein and Service Cloud Voice fixes to reach $2M annualized savings target and establish stable 2026 expansion foundation.

AI Use Cases: Sales Intelligence Driven by Gong,Paola/Mate,CElia – Latam CE Chatbot,SIA - Smart Insight AI
Overall Status: Amber - Delay/Risk/Challenges
Executive Summary:
Sales Intelligence Driven by Gong: We’re running a Gong pilot without CRM integration, using 10 licenses for the LATAM team until the end of the year. Since some features require CRM connectivity, we decided to proceed with the pilot as is, focusing only on the functionalities available in this setup and avoiding additional projects.

Paola/Mate: Paola/Mate is a tool designed to provide client intelligence before sales calls. It gathers and presents relevant information such as company size, estimated revenue, websites, social media presence, ownership structure, and other strategic data. This allows sales representatives to enter meetings better prepared, with context and knowledge about the client, improving the quality of interactions and the efficiency of negotiations.

Celia: Although CElia was not originally designed for GTM, it can be effectively used as a support tool for territory management. This helps reduce the time spent searching for essential data and supports more efficient territory planning and decision-making.

SIA: SIA is a tool developed to support the Latam sales team, offering artificial intelligence for data analysis, and automation on the decision-making support. The solution integrates information about forecast, pipeline, and commercial performance, making it easier to access strategic insights and optimizing the workflow for sales representatives.

The second phase of the project will focus on delivering data and insights in a self-service format, aiming to provide sales users with a simple and interactive way to engage with their Pipeline, Forecast and Territory.
Key Risks and Issues:
Sales Intelligence Driven by Gong: Limited functionalities: Without CRM integration, it won’t be possible to test all features.
Low adoption: Some users were not active, which may impact results.
Uncertainty about CRM

Paola/Mate: Tool launched, but awareness is still low among the sales team. 

CElia: Since CElia was created a long time ago, we don’t have the flexibility to easily add or remove documents. We need to open a case and wait for it to be processed. As sales territories change and accounts are added during the week, this waiting time becomes a problem.

SIA: We need to reproduce this information at the user level, so each seller or manager should only see their own numbers. We also need to understand how AI will handle this and ensure it only provides information related to the user’s own accounts and deals.
Progress on Use Case this period:
Sales Intelligence Driven by Gong: We are considering changing our CRM. Since no decision has been made yet, we decided not to purchase new licenses for now to avoid extra costs. In parallel, we adjusted the pilot users by removing those who were not actively using the tool, ensuring visibility of real usage.

Paola/Mate: Tool launched

CElia: CElia is working in Teams and in the Open Arena.

SIA: We are actively collaborating with the technical team to design, develop, and implement the tool, ensuring it meets business requirements and provides a seamless experience for end users.
Details on Change Management: N/A
Path Forward:
Sales Intelligence Driven by Gong: Change Management for all Latam users

Paola/Mate: Focus will be on internal communication and enablement to ensure sellers understand the value and start using it.

CElia: Focus on internal promotion of the tool within territory teams, encouraging users to direct their questions to the chatbot. CElia will be featured in internal channels to increase visibility and usage.

SIA: The technical team presented us with a solution similar to what is already being used globally. We are now working on understanding how to adapt and replicate this approach for our data and requirements.
